title: Foreign Affairs; The Global Casino
description: So I decided to put a little money into global markets last year. I brushed up on Spanish and invested in Argentina. Took a Berlitz course in Japanese and bought a few Tokyo bonds. Lavishly tipped the waiters at the House of Hunan Chinese restaurant and picked up some stock tips in Shanghai. I even learned the difference between G.N.P., G.D.P., DDT and AT&T and invested in equities from Paris to Istanbul. For old times' sake my broker suggested I buy some Lebanese bonds, but I told him our house already had wallpaper.

title: Oneidas Seeking Casino at Monticello Raceway
description: The Oneida Indian Nation wants to establish a casino at Monticello Raceway in Sullivan County, just 90 miles from New York City. But Gov. George E. Pataki pledged yesterday to block the plan.

title: John Melser; Principal, 73, Was Innovator
description: John Melser, an innovative educator and retired principal of an alternative elementary public school in Greenwich Village, died on Friday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 73.

title: Carrying On in a Master's Steps: Erick Hawkins's Muse and Mate
description: Lucia Dlugoszewski has been looked upon for years, at least in the dance world, as the favorite composer of Erick Hawkins. Small, round and occasionally excitable, she was the longtime companion who provided the modern-dance master with sounds -- sometimes frenzied and propulsive, sometimes filled with meditative clarity, but always gutsy -- that set his dances into motion. Together, she said, they created work that allowed him to "revise metaphor."

title: Bishops Assail Pataki's Budget, Calling It Devastating to the Poor
description: New York State's Roman Catholic bishops harshly criticized Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget today, saying its deep cuts would be devastating for the poor.

title: Sidney Cowell, 92, Ethnomusicologist And Teacher
description: Sidney Robertson Cowell, an ethnomusicologist, writer and the widow of the composer Henry Cowell, died on Thursday at her home in Shady, N.Y., said Sean Hartnett, her executor. She was 92.

title: Devils Send Down Three
description: The Devils announced three demotions last night to shore up their Albany farm team in the American Hockey League for a six-games-in-nine-days stretch. Sent down were center Sergei Brylin and defensemen Jaroslav Modry and Kevin Dean.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Music Notes column on Saturday about the decision of the London Philharmonic to cancel its concerts in New York City and San Francisco this month misstated the Lincoln Center telephone number for ticket refunds and exchanges. It is (212) 799-1521.

title: Haitians Remember Carter's Role Bitterly
description: To the Editor:

title: Southland Corp.(SLCMC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-After an extraordinary gain on debt redemption of $ 98,968,000, or 24 cents a share, and a charge for post-employment benefits of $ 16,537,000, or 4 cents a share.(Loss)

title: PHH Corp.(PHH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Netscape Knows Fame And Aspires to Fortune
description: It would seem to be a bonanza for the Netscape Communications Corporation. Only a few months after releasing its first software, the company seems to be the runaway leader in a field with growth rates not seen since the early, heady days of the personal computer business.

title: U.S. Is Wary As Iran Adds Troops in Gulf
description: Iran has sharply increased its military forces on three islands at the mouth of the Persian Gulf in recent months, provoking alarm at the Pentagon and among America's gulf allies, senior military officials said today.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
A New Offer for National Gypsum
description: The National Gypsum Company received another unsolicited takeover offer yesterday, a $1.12 billion cash bid from BPB Industries P.L.C., Europe's largest manufacturer of plasterboard.

title: Communities Fear the Pain Base Closings Will Cause
description: New Jersey would suffer the heaviest blow in the metropolitan region under the list of military base closings released yesterday by the Pentagon, though New York and Connecticut face hard losses, too.

title: City Ballet Shows Off Its Dancers in New Roles
description: The New York City Ballet, trying out talent in new roles up to the last minute, offered a spate of debuts in George Balanchine's "Jewels" on Saturday afternoon and then closed its winter season on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater with some new faces in Jerome Robbins's "Gershwin Concerto."

title: METRO DIGEST
description: BISHOPS ASSAIL PATAKI'S BUDGET CUTS

title: Netcom Names a President
description: Netcom On-Line Communication Services Inc. said today that it had named David W. Garrison as president and chief operating officer.

title: Mayor Details Plan for Small Businesses
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced several measures yesterday intended to assist small businesses by providing working capital, financing and financial benefits.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Donna Karan's new campaign stresses the ultra-glamorous look.
description: ENSCONCED next to an enormous movie camera, the improbably named Shalom Harlow is applying lipstick to an already richly rouged mouth. The outfit says Hollywood unchained.

title: New McGraw-Hill Unit
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. has formed a unit to consider opportunities for its information products and publications. The group combines Business Week magazine; the publication services group, with more than a million clients in computer, communications and other fields, and Tower Group International, a provider of trade management services.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 21 discussed a battle over the ownership of the Union Bank of Switzerland. It recounted recent moves to permit more foreign investment in Swiss companies, including banks, after years of tight restrictions. Recalling the evolution of the banking law over the last 20 years, the article referred to what legislators and bankers perceived as a threat from "Arab investors and drug cartels."

title: Guards Argue and 1 Dies
description: A private security guard at the King's County Department of Juvenile Probation was shot and killed about 7:30 last night after an altercation with a second guard, said a police spokesman, Officer Scott Bloch.

title: Prosecutor Contends That Witness for Simpson Was Coached
description: Mired for days over a maid named Rosa Lopez, O. J. Simpson's murder trial ground to a halt this afternoon as prosecutors asked for and received a day to digest documents about her that the defense had dumped belatedly into their laps.

title: U.S. Must Lead to Curb Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Deutsche Bank Suit on Barings
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. sought an order of attachment yesterday in a New York State court to recover $47.9 million it says Barings P.L.C. took from it in a currency exchange.

title: New Round of Base Closings Hits 34,200 Civilian Jobs
description: In what may be the last round of military base closings, the Defense Department said today that about 34,200 civilians would lose their jobs as it shuts down 33 big installations and shrinks or consolidates 86 smaller sites.

title: Doomed Plane Wasn't Told It Was Flying in Ice-Prone Area
description: Air traffic controllers failed to warn American Eagle 4184 that they were directing it to fly a holding pattern in an area prone to ice formation, investigators demonstrated today in close questioning of several air traffic officials.

title: New Look at a Mexican Murder
description: President Ernesto Zedillo, already reeling from the consequences of two inherited crises -- an overvalued peso and the armed conflict with peasant rebels in Chiapas -- has courageously taken on a third, the unsolved assassination of Luis Donaldo Colosio. Mr. Colosio was the front-running presidential candidate when he was shot at a campaign rally last March. Mr. Zedillo, his campaign manager, was chosen by the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, to take his place.

title: Wilpon Labels Himself 'Moderate'
description: Ever the diplomat, Fred Wilpon today defended ownership's decision to hire replacement players while at the same time saying that he was dragged into accepting replacement baseball in the first place.

title: Marines Dig In in Somalia
description: The American-led operation to provide security for the withdrawal of United Nations troops from Somalia went smoothly today, with American and Italian marines digging into their positions and catching up on sleep after their arrival overnight.

title: Topics of The Times; The Geography of Nowhere
description: The cultural historian George Steiner describes Anglo-American culture as a "blanket" that could one day cover the world, extinguishing all that is local and culturally unique. The creeping sameness is clearly evident in multinational advertising, with golden arches and Coca-Cola logos multiplying across the globe.

title: Sheik's Talk at Issue in Trial
description: Jurors in the sedition trial of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman and 10 others were shown one of the cleric's sermons yesterday in which he encouraged devout Muslims to fight a guerrilla war against all enemies of Islam, including the United States.

title: Use of Drugs to Lower Cholesterol Is Tied to a Higher Depression Risk
description: HEART disease patients who are taking medicine to lower their cholesterol are at a heightened risk for depression, according to research being reported today at a meeting of the American Psychosomatic Society in New Orleans.

title: Court Ruling Restores Job For a Worker With Epilepsy
description: For Richard Granziel Jr., a long, hard lesson about discrimination started in 1987 when he had an epileptic seizure.

title: Port-au-Prince Journal; Carnival's Theme: Let Lent Come, Haiti Has Hope
description: With the country living under a military dictatorship and harsh economic sanctions, Haitians did not feel much like celebrating the annual pre-Lenten Carnival last year. No wonder, then, that with President Jean-Bertrand Aristide back in power, this year's celebration was quickly baptized "the Carnival of Hope."

title: Festival of Mexican Culture
description: A festival celebrating Mexican culture is to take place through this month at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. This series, a Festival of Mexican Performing Arts, is to begin at 4:30 P.M. on Saturday with a piano recital by Maria Teresa Rodriguez playing works by Carlos Chavez.

title: Slocan Forest reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 20.8 million and $ 27.4 million in the quarter and year, respectively, both on the recovery of countervailing duties.c-Included a gain of $ 19.1 million on retirement of debt in both the quarter and year.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Value Health Inc.(VH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 499,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 511,000, or 1 cent a share, in the year.Year-ago quarter and year's loss from continuing operations of $ 16,543,000, or 41 cents a share, and income from continuing operations of $ 6,998,000, or 17 cents a share, both included pretax merger-related expenses of $ 38,409,000.Fiscal 1994's income from continuing operations of $ 49,621,000, or $ 1.19 a share, included pretax merger-related expenses of $ 5,986,000.(Loss)

title: Fast-Moving Fire Kills 4, Including a Baby, in Brooklyn
description: A fire that started in a basement spread quickly throughout a two-story apartment building in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon and killed four people, including an 8-month-old baby.

title: More Corruption Charges Against Former Principal
description: Until yesterday, prosecutors had charged only that Stuart Possner, the former principal of Public School 100 in Coney Island, was a corrupt administrator who stole money from the city's school system and coerced teachers into doing his political bidding.

title: Tibetan New Year: Offerings and Feasts
description: TOMORROW morning, Nima Dorjee, a 56-year-old Tibetan who lives in Manhattan, will rise at 5, two hours earlier than usual. He will dress, not in his usual Western-style clothes, but in a black cotton chuba, a Tibetan robe that fastens on the side.

title: S.I. Carjacking Victim's Condition Has Improved
description: The 43-year-old Brooklyn woman who was shot through the heart and lung on Monday when her car was stolen in the Staten Island Mall's parking lot had "dramatic improvement" in her condition yesterday, hospital officials said.

title: Toro Co. (TTC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Sports of The Times; Once Is Enough, Even for L.T.
description: IF everybody's dignity has a price, Lawrence Taylor's price apparently is $500,000.

title: Prosecutor for the Breach
description: Deputy Attorney General Charles R. Buckley, 61, has been appointed interim Bergen County Prosecutor until Gov. Christine Todd Whitman chooses a successor to Prosecutor John J. Fahy, a Democrat who leaves office today. Aides to the Governor have interviewed four Republicans for the permanent position.

title: No. 9 Wake Forest Topples No. 2 North Carolina
description: Wake Forest last finished in first place in the Atlantic Coast Conference in 1962, when Dean Smith was in his first year as head coach at North Carolina. Tonight, on Smith's 64th birthday, the Demon Deacons moved within reach of repeating that achievement by defeating second-ranked North Carolina, 79-70.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11 MEXICO ARRESTS A SALINAS The Mexican police arrested the elder brother of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari on charges of having ordered and paid for the killing of a governing party official last year. A1 Raul Salinas's presence has been felt in other illicit deals. A9

title: WAL-MART STORES INC. (WMT,N)
description: As usual, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the country's largest retail company, has met analysts' expectations for fourth-quarter earnings to the penny.

title: Transatlantic Holdings Inc.(TRH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a benefit of $ 46,340,000, or $ 2.02 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.The latest periods included investment gains of $ 1.5 million, or 7 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 9.7 million, or 42 cents a share, in the year, compared with investment gains in year-ago periods of $ 1.4 million, or 6 cents a share, and $ 3.7 million, or 16 cents a share, in quarter and year, respectively.

title: Finally, 16 Months Late, Denver Has a New Airport
description: Denver International Airport finally opened today, hailed by its proponents as a mighty catalyst for the economy of the Rocky Mountain region and ridiculed by detractors as a $4.9 billion monument to boosterism and boondoggling.

title: Developments in Washington
description: SENATE -- Senate Republicans -- one Democrat short of the 67 senators they need to pass a balanced-budget amendment -- reneged on a promise to vote on the measure and abruptly threw the chamber into recess instead. The move by Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, drew a bitter rebuke from the chief opponent of the amendment, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, who damned it as "a sleazy, tawdry effort to win a victory." Asked later when the Senate might vote on the amendment, Mr. Dole replied with a half-smile, "Maybe this week." HOUSE -- The House approved far-reaching changes in how Federal agencies enforce health, safety and environmental laws, directing regulatory agencies to address the most serious risks first and to base rules primarily on economic considerations, not on the health standards that underpin many existing laws. The bill, backed by industry groups and opposed by environmentalists, is the most comprehensive of several anti-regulatory initiatives being debated in the House.

title: A Rebound, and Now a Tribute
description: More than a decade ago, Thomas V. Karaban, a Wall Street stockbroker, suffered a financial calamity and lost his house. He bounced back, and the experience so moved him that he started the Rainbow Foundation to aid families caring for seriously ill children. More than 4,000 families have been helped. On March 28, Mr. Karaban will receive the Madeline Worthy Williams Youth Advocacy Award from Governor Whitman.

title: Spiegel Inc.(SPGLA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wine Talk
description: EVERY year at this time, Americans find out how much wine they drank last year, what kind it was, and what their vinous intake for the year ahead is likely to be. And it looks like wine drinking is going up.

title: Barings Officials Optimistic on Finding a Buyer
description: Optimism ran high within Barings P.L.C. today that the failed firm could be sold within days, probably in pieces, despite the $1 billion loss sitting on its books.

title: Renewal Built on Used Cars
description: In 1911, the Johns-Manville Corporation built a 1.8-million-square-foot roofing-products plant in a 216-acre field and lent its company name to the town that sprang up nearby. But in 1986, beset by asbestos-lawsuit problems and filing for bankruptcy protection, Johns-Manville closed the plant and dealt a huge blow to the town's economy.

title: YPF to Buy Maxus for $740 Million
description: The Maxus Energy Corporation of Dallas, one of the largest independent oil companies in the United States, has agreed to be bought by YPF S.A., Argentina's biggest oil company, in a $740 million transaction.

title: The Case of the Missing Ivories
description: Officials of a moving company here know where their truck was when thieves got it -- a motel parking lot in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. And they know where the truck was found, in the Florida community of Miramar.

title: Meggett Gets Patriots' Offer
description: David Meggett received an offer from the New England Patriots yesterday that is believed to be slightly better than the one offered to him by the Giants on Monday.

title: Psychiatric Care at St. Luke's Yields to Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Backs Removing Bank Curb
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve today joined the White House and key Congressional Republicans in calling for an end to the legal barriers that have separated the nation's commercial banks and securities firms since the 1930's.

title: Arkansas Banker Is Indicted in Transactions Tied to Clinton's 1990 Campaign for Governor
description: A former Arkansas banker who lent Bill Clinton money for his 1990 race for governor was indicted today on charges that he conspired to violate Federal banking laws in a scheme that involved campaign officials.

title: Topics of The Times; Mr. Gramm's Candor
description: The Washington Post recently reported that just before the November elections, with control of the Senate in the balance, the National Republican Senatorial Committee, then headed by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, made a $175,000 contribution to the National Right to Life Committee. Mr. Gramm, who is running for his party's Presidential nomination, explained that he had decided to make the unusual donation in order to "help activate pro-life voters in some key states where they would be pivotal to the election."

title: System Software Associates Inc.(SSAX,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: System Software Associates Inc. said all of its revenue was related to its AS/400-based software.

title: Simon Property Group Inc.(SPG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from prepayment of debt of $ 1,526,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 10,037,000, or 21 cents a share, in the year.c-Net incomeFiscal 1993's revenue included non-recurring gain of $ 8.9 million from the sale of an anchor store.Year-ago results are pro forma as if the company's Decmber 1993 initial public offering had occured on Jan. 1, 1993.(Loss)

title: Oneida Ltd. (OCQ,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Monteverdi and Purcell
description: It is a common fallacy to equate the recently revived art of the countertenor with the presumably unrevivable art of the castrato. Certain of today's star countertenors, it's true, have essayed castrato roles, particularly in Handel operas. But the core of their repertory remains music from the Renaissance to the present day written expressly for male falsetto, rather than male soprano. Michael Chance ended his splendid recital on Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection with perhaps the finest examples of the countertenor's art, the songs of Henry Purcell.

title: Forget Its Reputation: Mackerel Has a Multitude of Virtues
description: MACKEREL is a symbol of stinkiness, widely considered to be too strong-flavored, too oily, too fishy.

title: SHARES OF AST RESEARCH RISE ON PLAN BY SAMSUNG
description: Shares of AST Research Inc., a maker of personal computers based in Irvine, Calif., rose sharply yesterday after the Samsung Electronics Company of Korea said late Monday that it was buying a 40.25 percent stake in AST for $378 million. The move is expected to help AST resolve cash problems that it encountered after missing several crucial product introductions, resulting in a loss of $62.2 million in the first half of the 1995 fiscal year. Shares of AST rose $1.8125, to $16, in Nasdaq trading.

title: 'Megan's Law' Sees a Setback
description: Terming its provisions a "lifelong albatross," a Federal judge has ruled that it was unconstitutional to apply "Megan's Law," which calls for notifying communities of a sex offender's presence, in cases of crimes committed before the law took effect in 1994. A1.

title: Top Quark Remains a Mystery, but Only for One More Day
description: Scientists at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Illinois said yesterday that they had definitely found and measured the top quark, a fundamental but elusive building block of matter.

title: Stant Corp.(STNT,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge for early retirement of debt of $ 435,000, or 3 cents a share, in both the quarter and year. The year also included a charge for implementation of SFAS 112 of $ 418,000, or 2 cents a share.c-After an extraordinary charge for early retirement of debt of $ 3,322,000, or 25 cents a share, and a charge for implementation of SFAS 106 and SFAS 109 of $ 7,105,000, or 53 cents a share.Stant Corp. said latest-quarter and year's results included a $ 1.7 million charge to operations, or 6 cents a share after tax, for termination of automotive mirror and antenna product lines.The company also said about $ 13.5 million of the increase in net sales in latest quarter resulted from Dec. 13 acquisition of Trico Products Corp., and about $ 5 million came from Fedco Automotive Components Co., acquired in the latest third quarter.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALBERTSON'S INC., Boise, Idaho, which owns and operates supermarkets, food stores and drugstores, said it would invest $3.37 billion in opening 351 stores during the next five years. The expansion will increase the number of Albertson's stores to 1,013 by the end of 1999. ALPHA HOSPITALITY CORP., Valhalla, N.Y., a casino and hotel operator, said its unit, Alpha Rising Sun, had reached an agreement with Bally Entertainment Corp., Chicago, to develop and manage a $100 million casino and resort complex in Indiana.

title: Affirmative Action Must Go
description: There are many indications that affirmative action may soon provoke what it has never provoked before: a national debate on group preferences that will be so open and contentious that no important politician will be able to avoid a hard yea or nay position.

title: INSIDE
description: Denver Airport Opens

title: Steve Howe Attends Union Meeting
description: Steve Howe, relief pitcher and Yankee player representative, attended the union meeting for minor league players tonight in West Palm Beach but had little to say afterward.

title: Washington Talk; Christopher Drops Hint: Is Yeltsin Essential?
description: It was just one line in an otherwise unremarkable meeting on Monday, but it surprised the officials in the room: Secretary of State Warren Christopher suggested that the West should begin to think about a Russia without Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC. (FD,N)
description: A variety of one-time charges related to the acquisition of R. H. Macy & Company and the consolidation of divisions muddied fourth-quarter results at Federated Department Stores Inc., which operates Bloomingdale's, Macy's and several other department store chains.

title: Genesco Inc.(GCO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included income of $ 10,449,000, or 43 cents a share, from discontinued operations, which is a reversal of the $ 68.6 million provision for future losses of discontinued operations taken in the third quarter. The reversal reflected the favorable consequences of a transfer, not anticipated at the time the provision was recorded, of a licensing agreement for men's apparel to another manufacturer.c-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $ 22.1 million relating to the disposition of the University Brands and Mitre businesses and other facility consolidations, and a pretax gain on divestiture of $ 4.9 million. The period also included a loss of $ 62,678,000, or $ 2.58 a share, from discontinued operations.d-Net losse-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $ 12,319,000 in the quarter and year. The year also included a pretax gain on divestiture of $ 677,000. Period also included losses from discontinued operations of $ 23,494,000, or 96 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 21,986,000, or 91 cents a share, in the year. The year was also after a charge of $ 2,273,000, or 9 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting, and after an extraordinary charge of $ 240,000, or 1 cent a share, from early retirement of debt.(Loss)

title: New Partner At Forstmann
description: Michael A. Miles, the former chairman and chief executive of the Philip Morris Companies, has joined Forstmann Little & Company as a special limited partner, the company said yesterday.

title: Interactive Enthusiasts Seen Tuning Out Cable
description: If the television viewing public is willing to be led into the interactive age, many would apparently prefer to be led there by a telephone or satellite company rather than their cable providers.

title: Debts Are Cut for 6 Nations
description: The Paris Club of creditor nations said today that it had reworked $1 billion worth of sovereign debt of six countries -- five in Africa, one in Asia -- under the new terms advocated at the meeting last year of the leaders of the Group of Seven big industrial nations.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball Northern League

title: Bochco Moving to CBS With 3-Year Contract
description: Steven Bochco, one of the most successful creators and producers of television dramas, including "N.Y.P.D. Blue," "L.A. Law," and "Hill Street Blues," announced yesterday that he would end his association with ABC and begin a new long-term deal with CBS.

title: Personal Health; Living with the mysteries of Tourette syndrome.
description: JIM EISENREICH, now a star outfielder for the Philadelphia Phillies, was a 6-year-old Little Leaguer when he began having tics and twitches and suddenly snorting and sniffing. But not until he was 23, trying to play major league baseball with the Minnesota Twins, did he learn that the abnormal movements and sounds he could not control had a name and a physical cause -- Tourette syndrome. Even then, the Twins' management insisted that his problem was really stage fright and forbade him to take the medication prescribed to curb the symptoms caused by this inherited neurological disorder.

title: Maalox Account Is Moved to Grey
description: Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York has experienced a "Maalox moment" as the Ciba-Geigy Corporation, which recently acquired the Maalox line of antacids, shifted the brand's account to Grey Advertising Inc. in New York. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Abortion Pill Issue Creates a Clash for Some Republicans
description: The politics of abortion ran into the Contract With America today, and Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia and more than a dozen other Republicans seem caught in the collision.

title: From Ulysses Dove's Mind to Dancers' Feet
description: The "Dance in America" series of public television's "Great Performances" is once again focusing on the work of a noted black choreographer. A couple of weeks ago, Garth Fagan was given an elegant showcase. Tonight it's Ulysses Dove, whose gift for making dances was initially nurtured by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: Fugitive Returned to Spain
description: A former Civil Guard chief accused of embezzling millions of dollars from the Government was flown to Spain today after a 10-month manhunt that ended in Laos, the authorities said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: A Rise, a Fall and a Birthday in Hiding
description: Nicholas W. Leeson, who rose from a working-class background in a dreary London suburb to wealth and power in the macho, ego-laden world of financial trading, celebrated his 28th birthday last Saturday in hiding, presumably somewhere in Asia.

title: Just Deserts for Hacker
description: To the Editor:

title: Crimes of the Mighty Poison the Public Well
description: To the Editor:

title: New Directors Series To Present 22 Films
description: This year's New Directors/New Films series, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, opens on March 17 with "Living in Oblivion," a comedy directed by Tom DiCillo about low-budget film making in downtown Manhattan. The series, now in its 24th year, is to present 22 films from 15 countries. The films will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Base Closings Listed
description: The military announced its final plan to close 33 major installations. The program will cut 34,200 civilian jobs but still faces opposition in Congress, including a move by New York's two Senators that could delay the naming of members of a commission to make the final choices.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Omnicom Group Inc.(OMC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 28,009,000, or 81 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle.Revenue is commission and fee income.

title: Earnings at Morgan Stanley Fell Sharply in 4th Quarter
description: Reflecting the effects of the worst bond market in a generation, the Morgan Stanley Group reported yesterday that profits tumbled nearly 79 percent for the fourth quarter.

title: Shares of Quantum Health Off 23% After Profit Report
description: Shares of Quantum Health Resources Inc. plunged yesterday, a day after the company, which provides health services to patients with chronic diseases, reported disappointing fourth-quarter earnings.

title: HOUSE APPROVES SWEEPING CHANGES ON REGULATIONS
description: The House of Representatives today approved far-reaching changes in how Federal agencies enforce health, safety and environmental laws.

title: Giuliani's Panel on Police Gets Off to a Running Start
description: A new panel established by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to monitor police corruption had its first meeting yesterday, even as City Council members and some lobbying groups sharpened their complaints that the Mayor had improperly obstructed the role of the Council by creating the commission.

title: Mr. Giuliani's Police Ploy
description: The Giuliani administration has a well-developed knack for undermining confidence in New York City's Police Department. First Mayor Giuliani said he would ignore a new law, passed by the City Council, that established an independent agency to monitor police corruption. Soon after, the administration dismissed Walter S. Mack Jr., the department's top corruption official -- the first civilian ever to head the post -- and replaced him with an insider. Then Mr. Giuliani seized control of the Public Affairs Department, in a clear attempt to manipulate the flow of police information.

title: Toll Brothers Inc.(TOL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Republicans Modify Parts of Their Overhaul
description: In response to Democratic criticism, House Republicans today modified some of the most contentious provisions of their welfare bill, including one that would have permanently denied cash assistance to children born to unmarried women under the age of 18.

title: Mexican Family's Black Sheep Was Often Out of the Picture
description: When his younger brother was President of Mexico, Raul Salinas de Gortari was seldom seen, but his presence was often felt in questionable private business deals.

title: Islanders' Battered Defense Does the Job
description: Shortage of defensemen? What shortage of defensemen?

title: Food Notes
description: Adding Butter and Creme Fraiche

title: Olympic Steel Inc.(ZEUS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 875,000 from the fatal accident of an employee. Also included charge of $ 7.8 million from a reinstatement of deferred income taxes when the company changed to a C corporation from an S corporation on Jan. 1, 1994. Excluding charges, net income was $ 9.2 million, or $ 1.19 a share.c-Net income as if 1994 C corporation effective tax rate had been applied to 1993 S corporation income. On a historic basis, net income was $ 1,426,000, or 31 cents a share. Company changed to a C corporation from an S corporation on Jan. 1, 1994.

title: Red Storm's Victory Brightens N.I.T. Hopes
description: At last, something to smile about. A season of ups and downs finally reached a peak St. John's could be proud of last night when it came up with a victory in a game that probably salvaged its season.

title: U.S. and China in a Clash Over Human Rights
description: In a blunt diplomatic exchange, China today asked the State Department's top diplomat for Asian affairs to withdraw American support for a United Nations resolution criticizing China's human rights record.

title: THE 104th CONGRESS: NEWS ANALYSIS Budgetary Posturing; Substance Losing Ground to Politics
description: The impasse in the Senate over the balanced-budget amendment can be explained by this finding in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll: 79 percent of Americans said they favored a constitutional amendment that would require the Federal Government to balance its books by 2002; but only 32 percent said they were in favor if it would require cuts in Social Security.

title: 2 Big Travel Agencies In a Merger
description: US Travel and IVI Business Travel International, two of the biggest travel companies in the country, said yesterday that they had merged to form BTI Americas Inc.

title: Dole Hammers on Yeltsin As U.S. Frustration Grows
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, lashed out against Boris N. Yeltsin today, likening the Clinton Administration's embrace of the Russian leader to the Bush Administration's refusal to abandon his predecessor, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Ellis Island Footbridge Gives Access to History
description: To the Editor:

title: Nordstrom Inc.(NOBE,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Grammys: A Blend of Old and New
description: A newcomer, Sheryl Crow, and a pop trouper, Tony Bennett, won the top awards at the 37th annual Grammy Awards, which were presented last night at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles and telecast on CBS.

title: Buttrey Food reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a gain on the disposal of assets of $ 73,000 in the quarter and $ 3,984,000 in the year. The year also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 127,000, or 1 cent a share.c-Net loss and included a loss on the disposal of assets of $ 174,000 in the quarter and $ 1,088,000 in the year. The year also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 137,000, or 2 cents a share.(Loss)

title: Celebrating a Child's Own Decisions
description: JANOVIC/PLAZA likes to boast that it offers 5,000 shades of paint, but the last time I trolled the racks of chips it was for a single color: pink. I found peony and Pepto-Bismol, grandmotherly corals, the fuchsias of gaping orchids. I found pinks tinged with blue, as if their oxygen had been diverted, and blush pinks with drippings of melon stirred in. I plucked them all and brought them home.

title: Bowing to I.M.F., Yeltsin Takes New Steps to Fight Spending and Corruption
description: In a concession to the International Monetary Fund, President Boris N. Yeltsin has signed a series of decrees intended to increase fiscal discipline and reduce widespread corruption, Russian officials said today.

title: BUDGET MEASURE IS DELAYED AGAIN IN ANGRY SENATE
description: Republicans shut down the Senate chamber again today to avert a certain defeat of the proposed balanced-budget amendment, and both parties took the fight over the measure -- now more a political guerrilla war than a debate -- to the Capitol's corridors and television studios.

title: Officer Indicted For a Shooting Of a Colleague
description: The New York City police officer who opened fire on a black plainclothes transit officer during a moment of rush-hour chaos on a subway platform last summer has been indicted by a grand jury for first-degree assault, a person close to the indicted officer's family said yesterday.

title: A Charmer of the 1870's Faces Cataclysmic Tuttis
description: Has 100 years changed the way we live? No platitudes or pronouncements were needed for listeners at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon. The artifacts being held up by the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra under James Levine were Dvorak's Romance in F minor for Violin and Orchestra, then "Of Reminiscences and Reflections," a five-movement piece by Gunther Schuller.

title: Hills Are Alive With Late-Night Activity
description: In a farming community about an hour's drive from Louisville, Ky., the locals are burning the midnight oil. Actually, the illumination is more like stadium lights that brighten the hills of Paoli, Ind., until dawn. This is night skiing at its ultimate.

title: Risking Everything for Amendment
description: From the beginning, Republicans pursued a take-no-prisoners legislative strategy on the constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget. But the Senate, unlike the House, operates as much on personal relations and its own arcane folkways and traditions as on raw partisan power.

title: Britain's Premier Survives Challenge On European Policy
description: Narrowly surviving another challenge to his leadership, John Major, the Conservative Prime Minister, beat back an opposition motion in Parliament tonight to censure his Government's policy toward integration with the rest of Europe.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Science Times on Feb. 21 with an article about global warming, showing developed nations' 1990 levels of carbon dioxide emissions and projections for the year 2000, omitted three final zeros from the figures, thus understating them. The levels are in millions of tons. The figure for Australia's estimate of emissions for the year 2000, also understated, included an additional error. It should have read 370,491,000 tons.

title: Lone Panelist Opens Base-Closing Reviews
description: An independent base-closing commission got off to an awkward start today -- minus seven of its eight members -- in a four-month review of the nearly 120 installations the Pentagon recommends closing, shrinking or consolidating.

title: Rio Algom Ltd.(ROM,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 9,781,000, or 22 cents a share, from discontinued operations.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: DDB Needham Shop Out of F.T.D. Review
description: DDB Needham Chicago said yesterday that because of the amount of business from current clients, it had withdrawn from the review of the Florists' Transworld Delivery account, with billings estimated at more than $20 million. The withdrawal leaves four finalists: Bates U.S.A. in New York; Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis; Grey Advertising in New York, and J. Walter Thompson Detroit. A decision is expected in April.

title: Winnie Mandela's Fortunes Buffeted Anew by Graft Case
description: Police officers acting with the blessing of President Nelson Mandela today raided the home of his estranged wife, Winnie Mandela, searching for evidence to support charges she defrauded a Government program that builds houses for the poor.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Sitting Down With a Tax Expert: Your Computer
description: WHEN it comes time to deal with their personal tax returns this year, more than two million Americans will rely on tax-preparation software. Offering more help than ever to home users, the latest generation of these programs works much like a skilled tax professional, asking the right questions, doing the math and suggesting alternative solutions for completing Internal Revenue Service forms.

title: No Headline
description: "We really win if we win. But we may even win if we lose." -- SENATOR BOB DOLE, anticipating the vote on a balanced-budget amendment. [ A1:6. ]

title: Cutting Mass Transit, Carefully
description: The New York City Transit Authority has a rational plan to save $113 million this year, avoiding the need for a midsummer fare increase. Painful as some of the contemplated cuts are, still more cuts are coming, or higher fares, or both, probably before year's end. All concerned -- City Hall, Albany and the transit agency's parent, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority -- need to agree on a new overall plan for the next several years, rather than ripping the system apart mile by mile.

title: Justices Hear Campus Religion Case
description: Wrestling with a case at the intersection of religion and free speech, the Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a state university must provide financial support for a student-run religious magazine on the same basis as other student publications and activities.

title: Officer in 30th Precinct Is Acquitted of Corruption
description: In the first trial arising from the corruption scandal in the 30th Precinct, a Federal jury in Manhattan yesterday acquitted a police officer of charges that he distributed drugs, took payments to protect drug dealers and conducted illegal searches and seizures.

title: Beyond the Shaq, a Hardaway Attack
description: On a team with fewer offensive options, Anfernee Hardaway could well be averaging 30 points a game. "He's definitely got that kind of offensive ability," Pat Williams, the general manager of the Orlando Magic, said today. "But thank God he doesn't have that big of an ego."

title: Japanese Citizenship Sought
description: CHAD ROWAN of Hawaii, a sumo wrestling grand champion, plans to apply for Japanese citizenship, a sports newspaper in Japan reported yesterday.

title: Gustavo Correa, Professor of Spanish Poetry, 80
description: Gustavo Correa, a scholar of Spanish poetry and a professor emeritus at Yale University, died on Feb. 18 in Bogota, Colombia. He was 80.

title: Wendy's International Inc.(WEN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Thou Shalt Not Traffic in the Demon Gossip; In a World of Envy and Talk Show Values, a Pacifist Sect Takes a Higher, Harder Way
description: The rest of America may be feeding on modern gossip as an industrial-size staple of the gross national product, but not Christoph Arnold and his fellow Christian pacifists, who live quietly as the Hutterian Brethren here on the banks of the Wallkill River.

title: Russian Journalist Is Slain; Profits May Be the Motive
description: One of Russia's best-known television journalists, Vladislav Listyev, was killed tonight in a gangland-style murder in the entryway of his Moscow apartment building, the police said.

title: Younkers Inc.(YONK,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After an extraordinary charge in connection with the early repayment of debt of $ 1,088,000, or 12 cents a share.Sales included leased departments.

title: Executive Changes
description: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES, Chicago, promoted Gilbert P. Smith, its executive vice president and president of Helene Curtis U.S.A., to president of Helene Curtis North America. Eugene Zeffren, vice president for research and development, was promoted to senior vice president and president of Helene Curtis U.S.A. MANUFACTURED HOMES COMMUNITIES INC., Chicago, named Thomas P. Heneghan vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Coffee, Tea or Statistics On Plane Crashes
description: Tuning into a program titled "Is Flying Safe?" is not a risky adventure. You can be pretty sure the answer will not be an unnerving negative. Usually, as in tonight's edition of "48 Hours," such a report focuses on a possible danger or two, already if belatedly or insufficiently publicized. The hope is that prime-time attention may jolt a buggy-age bureaucracy into takeoff.

title: Doral Gets Nod For Its New Look
description: Golf professionals ordinarily like surprises as much as they like a buried lie in a bunker or a drive into a divot in the fairways. But when the field of 144 touring pros arrived here for the Doral-Ryder Open, the opening event on the Florida swing of the PGA Tour, they were greeted by some changes that even they -- meticulous and demanding fellows that they are -- could not fault.

title: Fall in Auto Sales Raises New Fears of Slowdown
description: Sales of cars and light trucks fell in February, in contrast to a robust period a year ago, according to company sales reports released today and estimates by analysts.

title: Urging Students to Read With a Little Cash
description: Channon Robinson, a 12-year-old at Moten Elementary School, said he liked Speaker Newt Gingrich "because he's coming to our school for no reason but to talk to us while he could be at work making some money."

title: And the Winners Are. . . .
description: Here are the winners at the 37th annual Grammy Awards ceremony last night in Los Angeles:

title: A Voice In Pursuit Of Its Niche
description: Marietta Simpson, a gifted mezzo-soprano, who gave a recital on Friday night at Weill Recital Hall, has the kind of voice that is given to very few: warm, velvety smooth, laden with an inborn dusky expressivity. Something in the quality of her tone immediately entrances the ear. There are, however, limitations: she is marvelous in the lower and middle registers, but she has some difficulty toward the top. Here the tone turns less alluring, though never harsh, and there are moments of unsteadiness. In addition, she does not seem to have much expressive range beyond a sort of rapturous melancholy.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: FIRE DEPT. MAY RUN AMBULANCE CORPS Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has revived a plan to merge New York City's Emergency Medical Service into the Fire Department as part of his effort to reduce the size of the city's public hospital system and to reduce the time it takes to respond to medical emergencies, officials said. A1. OFFICER INDICTED IN SUBWAY SHOOTING The New York City police officer who opened fire on a black plainclothes transit officer during a moment of rush-hour chaos on a subway platform last summer has been indicted by a grand jury for first-degree assault, a person close to the indicted officer's family said. A1.

title: Clinton Pledges to Reduce U.S. Nuclear Stockpiles by 200 Tons
description: In a new overture aimed at winning a permanent ban on the spread of nuclear weapons, President Clinton today ordered a major reduction in American stockpiles of materials used to make nuclear warheads.

title: Cascades Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss(Loss)Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Standard Motor Products Inc.(SMP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 1.8 million for restructuring.c-Included an after-tax charge of $ 1.1 million for accounting changes related to income taxes and postretirement benefits, and a pretax charge of $ 2.8 million for restructuring.

title: Holyfield Set for Ring Return
description: Evander Holyfield's return to the ring is imminent. Holyfield retired when he lost his heavyweight championship 15 months ago and it was then discovered that he had a heart problem. Holyfield has signed to fight Ray Mercer on May 20 in Atlantic City.

title: War and Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: Merisel Inc.(MSEL,NNM) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Bridge
description: A player who is on lead with two aces can reasonably expect to defeat a grand slam. But if he picks the wrong one, the cost can be enormous. An example is the diagramed deal, played in January at the Grand Club in Franklin Square, L.I. It was reported by Mel Colchamiro of Merrick, L.I., who sat North. His partner was Stan Green of Muttontown, L.I.

title: New Chamber Series Starts
description: The inaugural concert of Music of the Americas, a chamber-music series, is to take place tonight at 8 P.M. at the Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street. The concert is to feature the Mexican cellist Carlos Prieto and the American pianist Ursula Oppens playing two premieres, Samuel Zyman's Fantasy for Cello and Piano and Silvestre Rivueltas's Three Pieces for Cello and Piano. Future concerts in the series will focus on the works of noted Latin American composers.

title: Leaders Are Near Accord On Death Penalty Measure
description: Two weeks after they first announced agreement on a death penalty bill, legislative leaders and Gov. George E. Pataki said today that they had resolved most differences over crucial details of the bill and might begin passing it as soon as Monday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID GUNN JR. was a student at the University of Alabama in Birmingham, hoping to be a college English professor, when his father, Dr. David Gunn, was killed two years ago at an abortion clinic in Pensacola, Fla.

title: Peru and Ecuador Sign Truce In Effort to Halt Border War
description: Peru and Ecuador signed a new cease-fire today, seeking to end a monthlong Amazon border war that has claimed 73 lives and left at least 200 wounded.

title: Isis in Alliance With German Drug Maker
description: Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc. has agreed to collaborate with Boehringer Ingelheim International G.m.b.H. of Germany in the development of new drugs, the companies said yesterday. The deal has a potential value for Isis of more than $100 million.

title: Indians Offer Part of Profit From Casino
description: As they unveiled a plan to build a casino 90 miles from New York City, leaders of the Oneida Indian Nation said today that they would discuss giving New York State a share of their profits in exchange for Gov. George E. Pataki's approval.

title: GIBSON GREETINGS SHAREHOLDER SEEKS A POSSIBLE SALE
description: An investment firm that holds about 1 percent of the shares of Gibson Greetings Inc. is advising the company's board to consider selling the struggling company. "The company should make a good strategic fit with a number of larger consumer-oriented paper companies looking to expand their product offerings," David Katz, president and chief investment officer of Matrix Asset Advisors Inc. of New York, wrote in a letter sent to board members Tuesday night. The firm, which manages about $180 million in assets, also called for Gibson, based in Cincinnati, to make a "decisive" change in top management. Shares of Gibson rose 12.5 cents, to $9.50, in Nasdaq trading. The company's stock has fallen 71 percent since February 1992, when it reached a high of $32 a share.

title: Ashland-Waco Deal
description: Ashland Inc. said today that it had completed the acquisition of some assets of the Waco Oil and Gas Company for cash and about $40.5 million of stock. Ashland issued 1,250,623 shares of common stock valued at $40.5 million at a price of $32.375 each. The amount of cash was not disclosed. The company also said it had completed on Monday the previously announced acquisition of certain assets of the United Meridian Corporation of Houston. Terms were not disclosed, but an Ashland spokesman said the purchase was in cash.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Ex-Cook Held in Robbery Death
description: A former dishwasher-cook at the International House of Pancakes has been charged with fatally shooting the restaurant's manager, Robert Hess, in a futile robbery attempt early Monday.

title: Calendar: Lectures, Exhibitions
description: Shaker Prints Museum of American Folk Art, Columbus Avenue at 65th Street; (212) 977-7298.

title: Simpson Judge Removes Juror, Shifting the Balance for the Fourth Time
description: The racial, sexual and perhaps the philosophical composition of the O. J. Simpson jury changed again today, as Judge Lance A. Ito removed the 46-year-old black man the defense lawyers considered their favorite.

title: WCI Steel Inc.(WRN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $ 18,185,000, or 59 cents a share, from early retirement of debt and a gain from change in accounting for income taxes of $ 834,000, or 2 cents a share.(Loss)

title: XEROX LIFTS STAKE IN OVERSEAS UNIT TO 71 PERCENT
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had completed its $970 million acquisition of an additional 20 percent stake in Rank Xerox, its primary overseas unit. Xerox purchased the stake from Rank Organization P.L.C. of Britain. Xerox now owns 71 percent of Rank Xerox and is entitled to 80 percent of the unit's earnings, up from 67 percent. An agreement for Xerox to acquire the stake was announced in January. Rank Xerox, based in Marlow, England, makes Xerox products and systems and sells them in more than 80 countries in Europe, Asia and Africa. Rank Organization is a leisure and entertainment company based in London.

title: Blue-Chip Stocks Falter On Fear of Lower Profits
description: Blue-chip stocks fell yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average again slipped below the 4,000-point level, hurt by concerns that slower economic growth this year will translate into weaker corporate profits.

title: Essay; Singapore Sling
description: In Singapore last year, 27-year-old Nick Leeson was fined $140 for indecently exposing himself before a group of women in a discotheque. But when he was running up $27 billion in financial-derivative trades that bankrupted a venerable merchant bank, what did the see-no-evil regulators of Simex, Singapore's swinging stock exchange, do? They shyly looked the other way.

title: Indonesia Cites Army in Timor Killings
description: A Government-appointed human rights commission in Indonesia accused the military today of torturing and killing six villagers in East Timor in an incident that has renewed criticism of the annexation of the former Portuguese colony.

title: Three-Alarm Blaze Sets Off Evacuation of Palace Hotel
description: A fire filled the New York Palace Hotel with smoke yesterday morning and played havoc with the wiring of the mid-Manhattan high-rise, sending guests and hotel workers, clad in everything from minks to shorts and borrowed blankets, groping down dark hallways and stairwells and streaming into the streets.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Will Cut Nuclear Stocks

title: Accounts
description: * Dolphin Cruise Line and Majesty Cruise Line, Miami, to Henderson Advertising, Atlanta, to handle the account, previously at Wright & Co., Miami. The combined billings were estimated at $5 million. * People Soft Inc., Walnut Creek, Calif., to W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore, to handle the computer software company's account, previously at Winkler McManus, San Francisco. The billings were estimated at $2 million for the first year and $4 million for the second year.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Id al-Fitr holiday, alternate-side street cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today, tomorrow and Saturday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: In Pursuit of Memory, And a Double Agent
description: OUR GAME By John le Carre 302 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: Mr. Rubin's Sensible Bank Reform
description: The timing was atrocious -- coming the same week that reckless trades by a junior employee bankrupted the oldest investment bank in Britain. Yet the regulatory relaxation proposed as a banking reform by Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin makes good sense.

title: For Striking Mets, Nothing to See
description: Ask a regular Met to name a replacement Met and a long pause often follows. Some know that Doug Sisk, a former Met, is in camp. Others have heard about Stanley Jefferson. For the most part, though, they are quick to turn the channel when replacement baseball appears on their television screens.

title: Love to Hate Those Flower Shows
description: I HAVE this love-hate relationship with flower shows, particularly the Philadelphia Flower Show, which has been running since 1829 and will open on Sunday. I hope it pours until then, and stays gloomy and cold, because I'll get a bigger bang from the bulbs when I go down the elevator into the Philadelphia Civic Center to bury my nose in six acres of forced flowers.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture in some editions on Tuesday, with an article about Alvin Harper of the Dallas Cowboys, was published in error. It showed another Cowboy, Michael Irvin. A corrected picture, in other editions, showed a smiling Alvin Harper in a jersey bearing his number.

title: People
description: * Derek Bowden, joint managing director at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Europe, London, was promoted to chief executive, succeeding Jeremy Sinclair, who left after the ouster of Maurice Saatchi as chairman at the Saatchi & Saatchi Co. * Steven Landsberg was named creative director at Ogilvy & Mather Toronto, succeeding John Staffen, who left to join DDB Needham New York as an executive vice president and creative director. Mr. Landsberg was previously a senior vice president and creative director at Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York.

title: Body Found in Grave May Be Missing Child
description: Police officials said yesterday that they had found a skeleton in a shallow grave in the Bronx that they believe is the body of a missing 4-year-old Queens girl, Raychelle Ortiz.

title: Republicans Agree On Food Stamp Plan
description: House Republican leaders partly reversed themselves under pressure from governors in their party and agreed to let states that meet certain requirements use Federal food stamp money to feed poor people in any way that state officials wanted.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International Trader Nicholas W. Leeson and his wife, sought since the collapse of Barings, were detained by German border police at the Frankfurt airport. [ Page A1. ] Singapore defended the integrity of its markets in the aftermath of the huge losses on a Singapore exchange that toppled Barings. [ D1. ] The Osaka Securities Exchange offers advantages to an aggressive trader, like the one who brought down Barings. [ D6. ] Mexico's President was accused by his predecessor, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, of bungling the peso's devaluation. Mr. Salinas also withdrew his bid to head the World Trade Organization. [ D1. ]

title: Threat to School Board Doesn't Faze Candidates
description: Last week, in a display of resistance and faith, 23 Newark residents signed up to run for the Board of Education even as the state intensified its efforts to seize the district and abolish the board.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; State Control Over Trash Urged
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman told a Senate subcommittee yesterday that New Jersey could stop exporting garbage by the year 2000 if Congress granted states the authority to control waste disposal -- a power state and local governments lost last year, when the Supreme Court ruled they could not tell haulers where to send their trash.

title: GS Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time non-cash charges of $ 2 million for write-off of loan acquisition costs related to the refinancing of the company's credit facility.c-Included non-cash charges of $ 107 million recorded under the predecessor company's adoption of SFAS 106 for accounting for post retirement benefits other than pensions.

title: USLife Corp.(USH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results included capital losses of 5 cents a share, in the quarter, and 4 cents a share, in the year.Year-ago periods included capital gains of 13 cents a share in the quarter and capital gains of 24 cents a share in the year. The year also included gain of 7 cents a share on sale of unit home office property, and charge of 9 cents for federal income taxes.

title: Court Sets Aside Requirement For 'Megan's Law' Hearings
description: One of the two recent legal setbacks to New Jersey's "Megan's Law" was softened today when a state appeals court set aside a judge's order for a court hearing before community notification of a sex offender's presence.

title: Sports of The Times; Holding That Line Versus Crossing It
description: JIM MORRIS had a contingency plan that he thought he would never have to use. In December, the University of Miami's second-year baseball coach figured that by the time March rolled around, the strike would be settled, players would be in camp and his Hurricanes could play the Florida Marlins in peace.

title: Today's The Day: New Players In Pinstripes
description: Buck Showalter did not want to manage exhibition replacement games, but he will Thursday. Showalter does not want to accept a 10 percent salary cut, but he probably will soon.

title: Westvaco Corp.(W,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included pretax gain of $ 10.1 million, or 9 cents a share, from sale of property and sale of an operating lease.

title: Time to Wake Up and Sense the Magic
description: The Orlando Magic has become to the Knicks what the Chicago Bulls had been for years: their biggest obstacle in the path to a championship.

title: Expect Fewer Grants Instead of Smaller Ones, Endowment Heads Say
description: Jane Alexander and Sheldon Hackney, the heads of the two major Federal cultural agencies, told a Senate panel today that they were prepared to deal with less public money by reducing the number of grants they make instead of by cutting all the programs across the board.

title: ST. JOE PAPER SHARES UP ON MOVE TO SELL ASSETS
description: Shares of the St. Joe Paper Company rose 14 percent to a new high yesterday, a day after the company put some assets up for sale. Shares of St. Joe gained $8.25, to $67.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. After the close of trading on Tuesday, the company said it would sell its phone unit, its sugar divisions and part of its paper business in response to a request by its majority shareholder. One analyst said the sales could raise as much as $850 million for St. Joe, which is 69 percent owned by the Alfred I. du Pont Testamentary Trust. In addition to the businesses put up for sale, St. Joe, based in Jacksonville, Fla., has real estate and railroad holdings.

title: Defending Affirmative Action, Liberals Try to Place the Debate's Focus on Women
description: Trying to counter pressure from the right, a coalition of liberal groups said today that the White House's review of Federal affirmative action programs should not lead to any cutback in them.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Southwest Airlines Co., Dallas, is selling $100 million of notes due in 2005 through Salomon Brothers Inc. The issue is noncallable and priced at 99.461 to yield 8.08 percent.

title: Market Place; Customer Accounts Tied Up At Some Small Stock Firms
description: For many small brokerage firms specializing in low-priced stocks, it has been a bad week. They cannot take customer orders, and their customers cannot get at their money or securities. And for one of the firms, Stratton Oakmont, the news got worse yesterday with word that a Federal judge had ordered it to install a taping system to protect its customers.

title: London Journal; Oh-So-Courtly Justice: Honor Your Mum, or Else!
description: The details of the case before the Camberwell Youth Court were straightforward. A 15-year-old with a criminal file as thick as a small telephone book had just been found guilty of stealing a portable telephone and sentenced to pay restitution and court costs equivalent to about $550.

title: Hawkins's Harmony Lives On
description: In many ways, the best tribute to major artists is found in their own work. There was no exception to this rule when the Erick Hawkins Dance Company opened its first season since Hawkins's death in November at the age of 85.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Mob Juror Charged With Lying
description: A juror in a 1990 racketeering trial was charged yesterday with lying to conceal her brother's business ties to a defendant, then trying to get her fellow jurors to return an acquittal.

title: British Trader Whose Big Losses Ruined Bank Is Held in Germany
description: Barings P.L.C. trader Nicholas W. Leeson and his wife, sought since the Sunday collapse of the British investment bank, were detained by German border police at Frankfurt airport this morning after arriving on a Royal Brunei Airlines flight, a spokesman for the local police said today.

title: New York Can Do Better by Its Stray Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Trader Admits Crimes Over 20 Years
description: A horse trader and stable owner pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here today to a 20-year crime spree within the wealthy world of show horses but denied the most serious act with which he is charged: soliciting the long-unsolved killing of the candy heiress Helen Vorhees Brach.

title: I.M.F. Loan Is Expected for Ukraine
description: In a development that could have important implications for economic change in neighboring Russia, Ukraine is expected to borrow close to $1.5 billion from the International Monetary Fund later this month.

title: Losing Quarter At Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that member brokerage firms posted a combined after-tax loss in the fourth quarter, reversing a profit of a year earlier.

title: Bernard Cornfeld, 67, Dies; Led Flamboyant Mutual Fund
description: Bernard Cornfeld, a Brooklyn-reared salesman who became one of the most flamboyant and controversial figures ever to stride through the American mutual fund industry, died in London on Monday. He was 67.

title: Writer Expressed Remorse on Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gender-Neutral Tragedy
description: Last October an F-14A Tomcat warplane stalled as it approached the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln to land. The pilot had four seconds to eject, reacted too late, and was killed.

title: Varity Corp.(VAT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 27.6 million, or 63 cents a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 5 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 7.2 million, or 20 cents a share, in the year. The year also included an extraordinary charge of $ 1.7 million, or 5 cents a share, from early redemption of debt.d-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 146.1 million, or $ 3.98 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: Dollar Steadies as the Mark Slips vs. the Pound and Lira
description: The dollar was steady against most leading currencies yesterday as a respite from political turmoil in Europe diminished the German mark's appeal as a haven.

title: Long Bonds Push a Rally For 2d Day
description: The long end of the government securities market rallied yesterday for the second consecutive day, as new economic reports suggesting that growth was slowing and the threat of inflation was easing helped to keep the bullish sentiment intact.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday with an article about New York City's control program for stray animals, showing its results from 1990 to 1994, referred incorrectly to the ending of the involvement of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The organization asked to give up the role; it was not removed.

title: Vons Cos. (VON,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included restructuring charge of $ 14 million, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 33 million, or 45 cents a share, in the year.c-Included restructuring charge of $ 56.9 million, or 77 cents a share, and a charge of $ 1.4 million, or 3 cents a share, from debt refinancing.

title: House Votes to Request Clinton Data on Mexico

description: The Osaka Securities Exchange found itself in the middle of a billion-dollar crisis this week started by a brash young British trader many hundreds of miles away in Singapore.

description: N.B.A. Hill Leads Pistons Grant Hill scored 24 points and Allan Houston added 23, leading the Detroit Pistons to a 92-79 victory over the Indiana Pacers last night in Auburn Hills, Mich.

At the 17th annual ceremony last week in New York, Ogilvy Direct's offices in Los Angeles, New York, Singapore and Toronto won 8 of the 57 prizes in 22 categories. Rapp Collins Worldwide followed with 5 awards.

She is approaching the end of a brilliant career at St. Johnsville, a tiny school in Canajoharie, N.Y., a small town of 1,500 people 60 miles west of Albany.

Giuliani has revived a plan to merge New York City's Emergency Medical Service into the Fire Department as part of his effort to reduce the size of the city's public hospital system and to reduce the time it takes to respond to medical emergencies, officials said yesterday.

The placement and size of a credit can be the subject of intense warfare that's really all about ego, posturing, vulnerability and a hunger for recognition. The network is so hot about "Extreme," which makes its official debut tonight, that it offered a preview of the series in January right after the Super Bowl, television's most coveted spot for sampling new shows. Well, guys, don't cash in your chips just yet.

Cablecomms plans to offer as much as 270 million units, with each unit consisting of one ordinary share of Nynex Cablecomms P.L.C. and one common share of Nynex Cablecomms Inc., two intermediate holding companies, not a common share of the Nynex Corporation.

title: Panpipes in the Decor And Proud of It

He remembers the domed clay oven in a courtyard filled with animals, where his family ran the only bakery in town, and the way the rains transformed the village footpaths into rivulets that required stilts to cross.

description: Township officials will meet with the New Jersey Department of Transportation on March 15 to discuss a problem linked to the widening of a 21-mile stretch of Interstate 287 south from two lanes to three.

description: The Royal Philharmonic of London, with Vladimir Ashkenazy as music director until recently and Yuri Temirkanov as a longtime guest conductor, has developed a distinctive sideline in Russian music. Under Mr. Temirkanov on Friday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, the orchestra put both of its national specialties on display.

title: Electronic Ads On Phone Kiosks
description: Transportation Displays Inc. is introducing outdoor advertising displays called TDI Vision to present electronically transmitted ads on telephone kiosks. The displays, which were tested in Manhattan last summer, are being set up on Nynex kiosks; they resemble the screens in sports bars and restaurants that present scores and ad messages using a light-emitting display, or L.E.D., format.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; N.J. Considers Gamblers' Train
description: One month from today, Amtrak will cancel its "Gambler's Express" service between Philadelphia and Atlantic City. New Jersey Transit agreed on Tuesday to decide soon whether to pick up that service.

title: Developments in Washington
description: SENATE -- Still looking for just one more vote to win passage, Senate Republicans agreed to a showdown today on the balanced budget amendment. The vote is scheduled for 2 P.M., and the Republican majority leader, Bob Dole, pledged that if it failed, he would revive the issue at the height of the 1996 election campaign. He attacked several Democratic opponents for what he called a "stunning flipflop" on a measure they voted for a year ago, and other Republican senators criticized President Clinton's opposition, as well. On Tuesday, Mr. Dole suddenly postponed the vote on the amendment when it became clear that he had just 66 of the 67 votes needed. The decision to have the final vote today came after apparently unsuccessful attempts to reach a compromise that would keep Social Security trust funds off limits to budget cutters. "There is no reason a balanced budget amendment could not pass with nearly 80 votes in a matter of a few minutes -- if they're willing to protect Social Security," said Senator Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat. The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll found that 79 percent of Americans said they favored a constitutional amendment that would require the Federal Government to balance the budget 2002, but only 32 percent said they were in favor if it would require cuts in Social Security.

title: On the Angry Airwaves, the Response to the Budget Vote Is Underwhelming
description: Having come up one short of the 67 votes he needed to pass a balanced-budget amendment, Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, turned yesterday to Rush Limbaugh, the talk radio figure who has served as an electronic precinct captain for Republicans in Congress.

title: Environmental Law Is Wrecking the Environment
description: Ross Perot had a problem. In 1990, his development company wanted to turn 330 acres of prime real estate near Austin, Tex., into shops and homes. But the land was chockablock with ashe juniper trees, the sole source of nesting material for a little bird called the golden-cheeked warbler. The warbler was about to come under the protection of the Endangered Species Act, which would make it illegal to harm its habitat. So Mr. Perot's company did what just about anybody would do -- it chopped down the trees as fast as it could.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 2 about a questionnaire sent by Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, to employees of National Public Radio misstated the scope of his inquiry. The questionnaire sought information about ethnic backgrounds, sexes and previous employment at religious-affiliated broadcasting companies, but it did not ask about religious affiliation.

description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary loss of $ 189,000, or 4 cents a share, on redemption of debt.(Loss)

title: For an Investment Club, Homespun Success

title: Somalia: Not a Total Failure
description: Little fanfare attends the efforts this week of United States Marines helping to evacuate the last United Nations forces from Somalia. Two years ago and one beach away, 26,000 Americans troops waded ashore in a televised spectacular meant to symbolize a new humanitarian vocation for the United States military after the end of the cold war.

description: The Administration severely criticized the Government of Colombia today, calling it "the world's primary cocaine production center" and saying it was not doing enough to crack down on the drug trade. But the Administration stopped short of cutting off economic aid.
