2 Americans Shot to Death In Pakistan
description: Gunmen shot and killed two United States diplomats and wounded a third this morning as they were driven to work in Karachi, a sprawling port city that has long been ravaged by violence.

title: Dollar Hurts Stocks; Dow Falls 34.93
description: In the second consecutive day in which the weak dollar has hurt the stock market, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged as much as 50 points yesterday before recovering somewhat. Still, the Dow closed at 3,962.63, down 34.93 points.

title: INSIDE
description: A Firefighter Dies From Injuries at Blaze

title: Meyer (Fred) Inc.(FMY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a charge of $ 2,588,000, or 9 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for income taxes.Fred Meyer said labor strikes during the second half of 1994 cut fourth-quarter earnings by 75 cents a share and reduced full-year earnings by $ 2.10 a share.The company said the labor disputes were settled early in the fourth quarter, but the lingering effects cost Fred Meyer about $ 60 million in after-tax earnings for 1994. It also took $ 15,978,000 in write-downs to exit the California market.

title: AT TEA WITH: Gillian Armstrong; A Lucky Director's Daring Career
description: ASKED her age, Gillian Armstrong does not immediately answer. She pushes her smooth blond hair away from her face with blunt, sensible fingers and smiles. She takes her time. "Just say early 40's," she finally replies.

title: State Regulators Review New York City's Public Hospitals
description: Responding to reports of deaths and injuries in delivery rooms, the New York State Health Commissioner yesterday ordered an immediate review of obstetrical care at New York City's public hospitals.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the indictment of a New York City police officer in the shooting of a transit officer referred incorrectly at one point to the legal meaning of the jury's action. The indictment does not mean the grand jury concluded that he the officer committed first-degree assault, only that there was reasonable cause to believe he had done so.

title: Dress Barn Inc.(DBRN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Dollar General Corp.(DOLR,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to give retroactive effect to a 5-for-4 stock split distributed March 6, 1995. Before the adjustment, net income in the latest quarter was 59 cents a share on 55,637,000 weighted average shares outstanding, compared with net income of 41 cents a share on 54,314,000 shares in year-ago period.Share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to give retroactive effect to the 5-for-4 stock split distributed March 6. Before the adjustment, net income for the latest year was $ 1.33 a share on 55,205,000 weighted average shares outstanding, compared with net income of 90 cents a share on 53,825,000 shares in 1994.

title: George Cadbury, 88, Canadian Economist
description: George Woodall Cadbury, an economist in Canada who was an international leader in the Planned Parenthood movement, died on Feb. 25 in the Oakville Trafalgar Memorial Hospital in Oakville, Ontario, where he lived. He was 88.

title: June '94 Produced a Record for Antigay Attacks
description: Remembered by most gay and lesbian New Yorkers for the Gay Games and the 25th anniversary of the Stonewall uprising, June 1994 now turns out to have a darker distinction. More antigay attacks were reported in New York City that month than in any other in the 14 years such records have been kept.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Want to break into commercials? Get on a hit TV show like 'Seinfeld' or 'Northern Exposure' first.
description: IT'S certainly not news when a television star is signed by an advertiser to pitch a product. But in an unusual twist to celebrity endorsements, three popular series are contributing what seems a disproportionate number of cast members to the ranks of spokes-stars.

title: Picture It on the Menu: Arctic Hare Ragout
description: Canada's vast north, which stretches almost to the North Pole, is unlikely ever to support a three-star restaurant, but the region's foods, particularly those popular among the Eskimos -- caribou, seal, hare and game birds -- may soon be offered in restaurants in Europe and the United States.

title: Colts Sign Rams' Anderson
description: Wide receiver FLIPPER ANDERSON got quite a 30th birthday present from the Indianapolis Colts yesterday -- a five-year contract reportedly worth $8.5 million, including a $2 million signing bonus. Anderson caught 259 passes for 5,246 yards and 26 touchdowns in seven years with the Los Angeles Rams. (AP)

title: Big German Metals Union Settles Strike
description: G Metall, Germany's most powerful union, and employers in the southern state of Bavaria agreed today on a two-year wage settlement for metal workers that is expected to act as a benchmark for the metals industry.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Nordiques Beat Penguins Aleksei Gusarov scored his first goal of the season with 58 seconds to play as the Quebec Nordiques held on for a 5-4 victory over the Penguins last night in Pittsburgh. The Nordiques have a National Hockey League-best 35 points, 3 more than Pittsburgh. (AP)

title: Lin's Value Is Set at $3.3 Billion
description: The Lin Broadcasting Company was valued yesterday at $127.50 a share, or $3.3 billion, a price that analysts said represented a bargain for the AT&T Corporation, which is expected to buy the 48 percent of the Lin it does not already own.

title: Seaman Furniture Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
No Headline

The argument that the death penalty will deter and reduce crimes has been abandoned almost everywhere." MARIO M. CUOMO. [ B5:1. ]

The company adopted fresh-start accounting in conjunction with emergence from Chapter 11 protection, effective Oct. 30, 1993. On a pro-forma basis, the company reported net income of $ 1.65 a share.

title: Mexico Says Accused Man Had $6 Million in the U.S.
description: Mexican officials said today that nearly $7 million had been found in American bank accounts in the name of a former government prosecutor who has been charged with a cover-up in his investigation into the murder of his brother, who was a governing-party leader.

title: Charming Shoppes Inc.(CHRS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After an accounting benefit of $ 3,991,000, or 4 cents a share, for the adoption of SFAS 109.Sales are sales only.Total revenues in the latest fourth quarter were $ 347,684,000, compared with $ 359,352,000 in year-ago period. Total revenues in the latest year were $ 1,282,051,000, against $ 1,263,474,000 in 1994.

title: Port Jervis Nurses Win Pact With Hospital
description: A six-month nurses' strike at the only hospital in Port Jervis, N.Y., ended late Monday after negotiators reached a settlement that gave nurses their first contract since they organized more than a year ago.

title: Call Off Campaign: Kittles Has Arrived
description: It was only a few months ago that the Villanova athletic department mounted an aggressive marketing campaign, complete with posters and brochures, touting its star forward Kerry Kittles as a potential all-American.

title: Changes in Food Stamps
description: In a 15-hour session, the House Agriculture Committee endorsed sweeping changes in the food stamp program, including strict work requirements. Page A16.

title: A Visionary Cuba, When Believers Still Believed
description: The island of Cuba has never looked as fantastically exotic as it does in "I Am Cuba," a nearly 2 1/2-hour swatch of cinematic agitprop that aspires to be the "Potemkin" of the Cuban Communist Revolution. Completed in 1964, during the headiest days of the romance between the Soviet Union and Cuba, this Russian-Cuban co-production is a feverish pas de deux of Eastern European soulfulness and Latin sensuality fused into an unwieldy but visually stunning burst of propaganda. Supervised by the great Russian director Mikhail Kalatozov, who is best known for "The Cranes Are Flying," it suggests Eisenstein filtered through "La Dolce Vita" with an Afro-Cuban pulse.

title: Gottschalks Inc.(GOT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: Hunting Meets Future, and It's Too Easy for Some
description: The bones in the basement are testimony to the skill of Jerry Simmons. He has a box full, mostly spinal columns and grinning skulls, from deer, elk and other big game. Embedded in each piece is a single black arrowhead.

title: Esterline Technologies Corp.(ESL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: AEP Industries(AEPI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
As 2 Directors Leave, Gloom At State Arts Agency Deepens
description: The executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts has resigned and her top deputy is retiring early, deepening a sense of uncertainty at the agency, which supports some 1,200 arts groups statewide.

title: AM Intl.(AM,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: The latest six months' results are not comparable to the year-ago period, which covers four months beginning Sept. 30, 1993, due to restructuring and implementation of fresh start reporting, which occurred following the company's emergence from bankruptcy on Oct. 13, 1993.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Question of Fit: Scaling Down a Voice Lyuba Kazarnovskaya, soprano Walter Reade Theater

title: Opposition in Bronx
description: New York City prosecutors expressed mixed feelings about the death penalty, with the Bronx District Attorney saying he would not seek it under any circumstances.

title: Haley Will Play Next Season
description: The All-Pro defensive end CHARLES HALEY, who said after the Dallas Cowboys' loss in the National Conference championship game that he was retiring, will play another season. Haley, 31, who is due to make $1.95 million this season, said yesterday that he changed his mind -- for now. "I'd rather not play if we're going to lose, and if they sit on their hands as far as getting other players, I still might retire again," he said. (AP)

title: Army Suspends 5, Including 2 Officers, in Training Deaths
description: Two Army officers and three sergeants were suspended today pending the completion of investigations into the deaths of four soldiers training to become part of the Army's Ranger corps, military officials said.

title: Canadian Utilities reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Preferred-share dividends were $ 45 million in the latest year, compared with $ 51.9 million in 1993.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Abbey Healthcare Group Inc.(ABBY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 10,355,000 in restructuring and merger related costs, and after income of $ 3,415,000, or 27 cents a share, from discontinued operations, which included a gain of $ 3,071,000 on disposal.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 365,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 1,466,000, or 18 cents a share, in the year.

title: Morningstar Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 1.3 million, or 9 cents a share, which included a gain of $ 400,000 from the sale of Velda Farms.c-Net lossd-Included $ 7.1 million in pretax restructuring and other charges in the quarter and year. The periods also included a loss of $ 900,000, or 6 cents a share, in the quarter and income of $ 1.2 million, or 8 cents a share, in the year, both from discontinued operations. The year also included extraordinary charge of $ 200,000, or 1 cent a share.(Loss)

title: Expansion Site Recommendation Made
description: Baseball's expansion committee held another meeting today. As with its previous meetings, the committee made no public announcement about its deliberations. But it did recommend to the executive council tonight the two sites for the next round of expansion.

title: At the Nation's Table: North Carolina
description: What Could Be Finer?

title: Theory on Nuclear Dump Peril Is Disputed
description: Senator J. Bennett Johnston yesterday belittled a debate over whether a proposed dump for high-level atomic wastes in the Nevada desert might erupt in a nuclear explosion, and publicly released an internal document from the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico that strongly attacked the explosion thesis.

title: Article 535395 -- No Title
description: A Federal jury awarded $81.3 million in damages to shareholders of Koger Properties Inc. yesterday, finding that the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche had misled investors about the deteriorating financial condition of Koger, causing its stock to be inflated.

title: Report Cards for the Schools
description: For years, New York City schoolchildren have been given report cards evaluating their performance. Now report cards for each of the city's schools are being issued as well. The latest -- assessing 121 of the city's 167 high schools -- were distributed this week. The cards offer parents, the public and school administrators a useful tool to help hold schools accountable.

title: Reward Offer in Bomb Threats
description: A $500 reward is being offered for information on a bomb threat that prompted officials to evacuate Edison's high schools seven times on Monday. The school superintendent, Melindo Persi, said someone called the police at 7 A.M. and gave a list of times bombs could go off at Edison High School and John P. Stevens High School. The schools were evacuated before each of those times. Bomb-sniffing dogs found no explosives in the buildings. But as a precaution, officials said yesterday, all after-school activities were canceled indefinitely.

title: Executive Changes
description: GATEWAY 2000 INC., North Sioux City, S.D., the marketer of personal computers, appointed David J. McKittrick senior vice president and chief financial officer. GENERAL MOTORS CORP., Detroit, named G. Mustafa Mohatarem chief economist.

title: Market Place; The Labyrinth of 2 Insider Cases
description: If you had some hot inside information, would you tell a friend? And would that friend tell somebody else?

title: Intuit Inc.(INTU,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included net acquisition-related charges of $ 12.1 million for the quarter and $ 67 million for the 6 months. The quarter also reflected a provision of $ 1.3 million, or 4 cents a share, for problem software.c-Net lossd-Included net acquisition-related charges of $ 182.6 million in the quarter and 6 months.The latest periods' results included sales from the company's Chipsoft Inc. subsidiary acquired in December 1993 and Parsons Technology Inc. subsidiary acquired on Sept. 27, 1994.(Loss)

title: U.S. to Help Girls in Poor Lands Stay in School
description: The Clinton Administration will announce here on Wednesday the creation of a program to help keep girls in school in Africa, Asia and Latin America, despite enormous economic and cultural barriers. The first year of the 10-year program will cost about $11.7 million, said the United States Agency for International Development, which will administer it.

title: A Partial Cure for Drug Bills For a $370,000-a-Year Ailment
description: Many patients with Gaucher disease, a rare inherited disorder, suffer not only physically but financially as well because the only drug effective against the condition can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars a year. But now a panel of experts says it may be possible for many patients to reduce costs without compromising effectiveness by using smaller doses.

title: Host Marriott Corp.(HMT,N) reports earnings for 16wks to Dec 30
description: b-Host Marriott refers to the losses as losses before accounting changes. The amounts included losses of $ 3 million, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 6 million, or 4 cents a share, in the year, both on retirement of debt. The company had a loss of $ 12 million, or 8 cents a share, before the items, in the quarter, and before the items, it had a loss of $ 19 million, or 13 cents a share, in the year.(Loss)The year-ago periods are pro-forma results that are presented as if the Oct. 8, 1993 distribution of Marriott International common stock to the company's shareholders and related transactions occurred at the beginning of the respective periods.Revenue is total revenues.

title: Woman Is Sentenced in Husband's Death
description: A woman who killed her husband during her losing campaign for the New Paltz Town Board in 1993 was sentenced today to 15 years to life in prison, the minimum sentence for intentional murder.

title: Kohl's Corp.(KSS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included extraordinary loss of $ 1,769,000 in the quarter and year.Kohl's latest fourth quarter results included a LIFO credit of $ 3,165,000, compared with a credit of $ 1,928,000 in year-ago period. LIFO reflects the last-in, first-out method of inventory accounting.The latest year's results included a LIFO credit of $ 353,000, compared with a charge of $ 383,000 in 1994.

title: Disciplinary Schools Planned For Students Carrying Weapons
description: Seeking to stop increasing violence in New York City schools, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines said yesterday he would remove students carrying guns from their regular schools for a year. The older ones would be sent to four disciplinary academies, which would open next fall. Students as young as kindergartners would be segregated in disciplinary programs.

title: Sony Names Division Leader
description: Peter Gelb, the president of Sony Classical U.S.A. since July 1993, has been put in charge of the classical-record label's international operations, the company said yesterday. He succeeds Gunther Breest, who resigned abruptly in December after a six-year tenure during which he transformed the former CBS Masterworks label into a company that rivaled its European competitors in terms of its artist roster and the diversity of its repertory offerings.

title: Canadian Imperial Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges with the ticker symbol of CM.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: At the Nation's Table: Westport, Mass.
description: What Goes Around

title: For an Honest Death Penalty
description: It is a staple of American politics that there is very strong support for the death penalty; in opinion polls, roughly 70 percent consistently favor it. Yet the popular will on this issue has been thwarted.

title: Why War? Sifting Through the Past for Answers
description: ON THE ORIGINS OF WAR AND THE PRESERVATION OF PEACE By Donald Kagan Illustrated. 606 pages. Doubleday. $30.

title: Berkley (W.R.) Corp.(BKLY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included investment losses of $ 399,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 86,000, or 1 cent a share, in the year. Year-ago periods included investment gains of $ 4,037,000, or 23 cents a share, and $ 14,775,000, or 82 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Accounts
description: * Keycorp, Cleveland, to Wyse Advertising, Cleveland, to handle advertising, promotion and collateral programs for the bank holding company, previously handled by J. Walter Thompson Detroit. Wyse joins Bronner Slosberg Humphrey, Boston, on Keycorp's agency roster. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Spot Work for Prime-Time Stars
description: Successful television shows often land cast members work in advertising, endorsing products or serving as voiceover announcers in broadcast commercials. Here is a look at the casts of three popular television shows and advertising work they are doing. Advertising, page D18.

title: Pioneer Financial Services Inc.(PFS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results included investment losses of $ 219,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 252,000, or 4 cents a share, in the year.Year-ago periods included investment losses of $ 886,000, or 13 cents a share, and $ 865,000, or 13 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectiely.

title: Charles S. Chetham; Former Museum Head, 65
description: Charles Scott Chetham, a former director of the Smith College Museum of Art in Northampton, Mass., died on Saturday at his home in Provincetown, Mass. He was 65.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Police Commissioner WILLIAM J. BRATTON dismissed Police Officer CAROL SHAYA-CASTRO yesterday for posing nude in the August 1994 issue of Playboy magazine. The Commissioner said she had violated the City Charter and the department's rules and was thus unfit to be a police officer.

title: St. Joe Paper Co.(SJP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an accounting benefit of $ 20,518,000, or 68 cents a share, for the implementation of FAS No. 109.

title: Rejoining the Welfare Debate, Clinton Attacks G.O.P. Plans
description: Wedging his way back into a debate he helped start but that has lately overtaken him, President Clinton today denounced Republican proposals for overhauling welfare as too harsh on children and too soft on work requirements, and pledged support for broad experimentation by states.

title: Fay's Inc.(FAY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a charge of $ 4,806,000, or 24 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.The latest year's results included charge of 10 cents a share for expenses related to the closing of nine Paper Cutter stores.

title: Money for Vietnam War Project
description: The state authority that distributes casino revenue wrote a check yesterday for $2.75 million to be spent on an education center next to the Vietnam Veterans War Memorial. The center will try to tell the stories of the 1,525 New Jersey residents killed or lost in Vietnam.

title: UConn's Rizzotti Injures Elbow
description: JENNIFER RIZZOTTI, the Connecticut junior point guard, hyperextended her right elbow Monday night during the Big East Conference tournament title game against Seton Hall. The injury was diagnosed yesterday and her status is day-to-day. Connecticut earned the Big East's automatic berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, which begins next week, with its 85-49 victory over Seton Hall. (AP)

title: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc.(ICN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a noncash charge of $ 221 million resulting from the merger of four ICN companies. The charge represents the write-off of purchased research and development costs.c-Net income(Loss)The 1993 periods above represented the operations of SPI Pharmaceuticals Inc., the surviving entity of the November 1994 merger, and therefore differs from the results reported a year ago.

title: First Mission for Donated Copter
description: The executive helicopter that Governor Whitman turned over to the state police for use as an air ambulance flew its first mission on Monday, transferring a critically ill patient, Thomas Boyle, 77, from Bayonne Hospital to the Deborah Heart and Lung Center in Browns Mills. The trip took 20 minutes. "The drive would have taken two hours," said the chief flight nurse, John Bisciglia. Mr. Boyle remained in critical condition yesterday in the intensive care unit.

title: Of a Father Whose Son Is 'Cheerful'
description: When Jeff Mitchell (Russell Crowe) has a hot date in "The Sum of Us," he also has a problem: his father. "Don't let me interrupt," insists Harry Mitchell (Jack Thompson), when his son and the date begin necking. Moments later, Dad is back with a porn magazine, offering it to the lovebirds "if you need something to get started." Then he's back again with a question: "Sorry, I forgot to ask. How do you take your tea in the morning?" At one point Harry can be seen with his arm around Jeff's date, making raunchy double-entendres and having a whale of a time.

title: HEINZ (H.J.) CO. (HNZ,N)
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 7.5 percent in the third quarter, as recently acquired businesses helped bolster sales.

title: Airport Guard Roughly Treats Ex-Governor
description: A guard at Raleigh-Durham International Airport was dismissed today after witnesses said he throttled former Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, an airport spokesman said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 DOLLAR'S PLUNGE DEEPENS As the dollar plunged around the world, the Administration watched in alarm but did not act. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is reported to be reluctant to fight the markets, preferring to let the sell-off die before acting. A1 KEEPING GIRLS IN SCHOOL The Clinton Administration plans to announce the creation of a decade-long program today aimed at keeping girls in school in Africa, Asia and Latin America despite economic and cultural barriers. A12

title: Season Taking Toll on Coaches
description: Marshall Coach BILLY DONOVAN was being treated for flu-like symptoms yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Huntington, W. Va. He was admitted Monday, a hospital spokeswoman said. His secretary, CHRISTAL PERRY, said that Donovan, the youngest head coach in Division I basketball at age 29, hoped to be released later this week.

title: Australians Won't Move To Raise the Sunken Hull
description: Australian yachtsmen today abandoned all plans to raise the sunken hull of their $3 million America's Cup yacht, One Australia. Their decision is based on more than the cost of raising the 75-foot yacht, a price that is likely to be high. They also believe there is nothing left worth saving.

title: Rock's Story as Told by the Rockers
description: When it comes to synergistic marketing, Time Warner, the company that sends me my monthly cable bill, is right up there with the Disney behemoth. The latest evidence is "The History of Rock 'n' Roll." A version consisting of 10 hourlong tapes, being distributed by Time-Life Video and Television, will reach stores in about two weeks. Meanwhile, there's the television series, which can be seen in two-hour segments on various stations around the country that made syndication deals with Warner Brothers.

title: Kodak Move in Japan
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it had started selling private-label film in Japan for the first time. Kodak agreed to produce the film under the brand name Coop for the Japanese Consumer Cooperatives Union, a chain of 2,500 stores.

title: 'Saturday Night' Lives, for Now, but Then What?
description: "Saturday Night Live," the television institution as well as a potent moneymaker for NBC in its 20 years on the air, needs a creative overhaul that may include everything except the show's live format and its location in New York City, a top network executive said yesterday.

title: Bid Increased for Hillhaven
description: The Horizon Healthcare Corporation raised its bid today for the Hillhaven Corporation to $31 a share in stock from $28 and said it would not increase the offer again.

title: Nobody Is in Favor Of Illegal Searches
description: To the Editor:

title: Choreographer to Speak
description: Gloria Contreras, a Mexican choreographer who worked with the New York City Ballet and led her own troupe in New York City in the 1960's, is to discuss dance in Mexico at 2 P.M. on Friday at the Library for Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. Ms. Contreras directs the Taller Coreografico of the National Autonomous University of Mexico.

title: Now Manhattan Must Wait To Learn Post-Season Fate
description: Despite 25 victories and a nationally ranked defense, Manhattan remains uncertain as to whether it will be selected for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Russia, Women at Work and Elegance
description: Inspiration is where you find it, and Laura Biagiotti found hers in Russia. After she opened a boutique in Moscow, she was invited to put on a fashion show in the Kremlin. So, last month an audience of 4,000 saw a two-hour show of opera, ballet and, of course, clothes.

title: Mets Want to Sign Franco
description: The Mets, aware of reports that the Baltimore Orioles had nearly signed the free-agent relief pitcher John Franco, remain interested in the left-hander, but also remain in limbo because the pursuit of all unsigned players came to a halt on Feb. 9, when the 28 clubs instituted a signing freeze.

title: Sundstrand Corp.(SNS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 53.6 million, or $ 1.51 a share, on sale of SDC business in the quarter, and the year was after income of $ 55 million, or $ 1.55 a share, from discontinued operations, which was from gain on sale of SDC business, including loss of $ 700,000, or 2 cents a share, from operations of SDC business before discontinuance. The periods also included extraordinary charge of $ 5 million, or 14 cents a share, from loss on early retirement of debt.

title: Food Notes
description: Indian Chicken Wings

title: Brother Wars in Mexico
description: There is more than a whiff of soap opera in the melodramatic story of political assassinations, alleged cover-ups and twisted family ties now unfolding in Mexico. But far more than soap opera is involved. At stake is the future of the world's longest-entrenched ruling party, Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI.

title: In a Tiny Company's Fight, Big Communications Stakes
description: The contest might look quixotic. A small manufacturer that has lost money in every one of its 23 years is tilting at rich and mighty Motorola Inc. and, by extension, almost every other maker of wireless communications equipment.

title: Orchard Supply Hardware Stores Corp.(OSHC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 3,955,000, or 57 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 9.3 million, or $ 1.57 a share, in the year, on write-offs from the extinguishment of debt.(Loss)Share earnings for the latest fourth quarter and year-ago period were calculated after preferred stock dividends to reflect the income available to common stock for all periods.

title: Parental Smoking and Infant Deaths
description: NURSING mothers who smoke and caregivers who expose babies to cigarette smoke may double or triple the infants' risk of dying of sudden infant death syndrome, a new study has shown.

title: In New York City, a Mixed Response to Law From Prosecutors
description: The five district attorneys in New York City, where the vast majority of the state's murders are committed, expressed mixed feelings about capital punishment yesterday, with one -- District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx -- saying he would not seek the death penalty under any circumstances.

title: Knicks Put Smith On Injured List
description: Charles Smith, still bothered by pain in his sprained left knee, was placed on the injured list last night before the Knicks-Boston Celtics game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Moscow's Mayor, Denouncing Yeltsin Dismissals, Vows to Quit
description: The pugnacious yet immensely popular Mayor of Moscow abruptly threatened to resign today unless President Boris N. Yeltsin reinstates two senior law enforcement officials he dismissed after the mob-style execution of the television personality Vladislav Listyev.

title: Cluster Care Doesn't Always Make Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: CML Group Inc.(CML,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included extraordinary charge of $ 1,125,000, or 2 cents a share, on early extinguishment of debt.

title: Enterra Corp.(EN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Enterra said that the latest quarter is the first to include the full benefits of the Total Energy Services acquisition.

title: For Chefs in Turkey, an Effort to Revitalize a Forgotten Cuisine
description: FROM dumplings the size of a thumbnail to multilayered delicacies made with dough as thin as a leaf, from eggplant 40 ways to poached fish en papillote with cream sauce, Turkey is full of culinary surprises.

title: Book Notes
description: Louganis Tops the List

title: PetsMart Inc.(PETM,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Included $ 14.1 million, or 36 cents a share, net of tax benefit, in merger and nonrecurring charges in connection with the acquisition of Weisheimer Cos. in March 1994, and a gain of $ 1.7 million, or 6 cents a share, from recognition of the Petzazz net operating loss carryforward.c-Net lossd-Included a benefit of $ 233,000, or 1 cent a share, from an adjustment in accounting, and a gain of $ 1,013,000, or 4 cents a share, from recognition of the Petzazz net operating loss carryforward.(Loss)

title: Margery Solomon; Bridge Player, 86, Represented U.S.
description: Margery Mastbaum Solomon, one of America's leading bridge players, died on Saturday at her home in Elkins Park, Pa. She was 86.

title: Ira C. Herbert, 67, Coca-Cola Executive
description: Ira C. Herbert, a retired executive vice president of the Coca-Cola Company, died at his home in Atlanta on Saturday. He was 67.

title: Agendas Clash in Bid to Alter Law on Product Liability
description: Lobbying over the high-stakes legal overhaul measure now in the House has become so contentious that George McGovern, a liberal icon of the 1960's, says the debate is even more heated than that over the Vietnam War.

title: Extendicare reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 478,000 on the sale of nursing centers in the quarter and year.c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations which included a gain of $ 24,323,000 on the disposal of Beutel Goodman of $ 24,743,000, or 44 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 27,301,000, or 49 cents a share, in the year.Periods also included a gain of $ 648,000 and $ 1,686,000 in the quarter and year, respectively, on the sale of nursing centers, and a loss of $ 64,771,000 on the dilution of the company's investment in Crown Life in both the quarter and year.The per-share amounts represent earnings per class -A- shares.Results are in Canadian dollars.(Loss)

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: Complicated Lives Built Around a Core of Serenity 'Wrapped Up, Tied Up and Tangled' Performance Space 122 Lovey, the matriarch of the family of women portrayed in Peggy Pettitt's "Wrapped Up, Tied Up and Tangled," has knees that are "as soft as an armchair."

title: Bombardier Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges with the ticker symbol BBD.B.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Developments in Washington
description: LEGAL REFORM -- Voting largely along party lines, the House passed legislation intended to curtail the number of lawsuits in Federal Courts. The Attorneys Accountability Act, approved 232 to 193, seeks to encourage parties to settle lawsuits before trial by exposing both parties to a risk of paying their opponent's legal costs. The measure, the first of three the House will vote on this week, was swept along by a tide of anecdotes purporting to show that the legal system is swamped with frivolous product liability and personal damage suits. FOOD STAMPS -- The House Agriculture Committee began voting on legislation to cut $16.5 billion from projected spending in the food stamp program over the next five years, despite protests from Democrats who said the bill was immoral and mean-spirited. Under the bill, states would have the option to get Federal food stamp money in a lump sum and then set their own eligibility standards and benefit levels.

title: Personal Health; What women can do to escape heart disease.
description: BY now most women surely are aware that heart disease is an equal opportunity killer, especially in those past the age of 50. Slightly more than half the deaths from heart disease in the United States now occur among women, and this share is likely to increase as the population ages.

title: Delinquent Mortgages
description: The number of homeowners late in paying their mortgages rose in the fourth quarter as consumers felt the pinch from higher payments on adjustable-rate mortgages, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today.

title: Financier's Mother Dies
description: Jean Davis, a philanthropist and the mother of Marvin Davis, the billionaire financier and former owner of 20th Century Fox, died on Feb. 21 at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 94 and had lived most of her life in Manhattan.

title: Irving P. Abel; Longines Executive, 85
description: Irving P. Abel, a former president of the Longines-Wittnauer Watch Company, died in his sleep on Sunday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 85.

title: Public Relations Enters Barings Case
description: With new details having emerged about the charges that Nicholas W. Leeson is likely to face if he is extradited to Singapore, a public relations man for the former Barings P.L.C. trader said today that "powerful people" could be the losers when Mr. Leeson told all he knew about the downfall of the venerable British investment firm.

title: Sheik Didn't Suggest War Against the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor, and Luck, Help Control Oil Depot Fire
description: A gasoline fire erupted with a thunderous roar at an Amoco fuel-storage depot here today before firefighters smothered it with foam, possibly averting a catastrophe -- with a little help from Carteret's Mayor.

title: Wieden and McCann Share Nike Japan
description: A new alliance between Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., and McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York has been awarded the Japanese account of Nike Inc., a Wieden & Kennedy client in the United States since 1982. The account, for which the billings were not disclosed, was previously handled by Dentsu Inc. in Tokyo.

title: Police Foot Patrols Don't Offer False Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Gangway for Rimsky-Korsakov: His Operas Have Found Voices
description: Of the many amazements produced by the Bach, Handel and Scarlatti tercentenary year of 1985, few surpassed the near-simultaneous presentation of three Handel operas under one roof at the Pepsico Summerfare in Purchase, N.Y. Such a convergence would be extraordinary even for a composer more central to the operatic repertory and is scarcely conceivable for a truly peripheral figure like Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov.

title: Differing Accounts of a Firefighter's Care
description: Questions have deepened about the emergency treatment given to Lieut. Raymond F. Schiebel, the firefighter who collapsed at a blaze in Brooklyn on Sunday and died last night, with sharply differing accounts offered by officials of the volunteer ambulance corps that treated him and an Emergency Medical Service paramedic.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: PATAKI SIGNS DEATH PENALTY BILL

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN HOMEPATIENT INC., Franklin, Tenn., a health care service company, agreed to acquire Conpharma Home Healthcare Inc., Buffalo, from its Canadian parent company, Continental Pharma Cryosan Inc., for about $30 million in cash.

title: EXIDE AGREES TO ACQUIRE BATTERY UNIT OF FIAT
description: The Exide Corporation, a battery maker based in Reading, Pa., has agreed to acquire all the capital stock of the battery unit of the Italian auto maker Fiat S.p.A. for about $550 million. The executive vice president and chief financial officer of Exide, Alan E. Gauthier, said Exide planned to pay for the acquisition with $200 million raised in December through the issue of 5.1 million new shares. The remaining $350 million will be financed with bank debt. The two companies said last October that they had signed a letter of intent to discuss the acquisition of the unit, called Compagnie Europeene d'Accumulateurs S.A., which at the time was valued at about $535 million.

title: Treasuries Continuing Drop in Price
description: Prices of long-term Treasury securities continued their slide for a fifth day yesterday as the dollar plunged again in the currency markets.

title: Awards in Dueling Casino Suits
description: John Tombarello is a high roller. In eight years, he reportedly lost more than $500,000 at the Sands Hotel Casino, before ending his relationship with the casino in a huff after it switched his hotel suite. To lure him back, the Sands offered a $93,000 Mercedes, said Mr. Tombarello's lawyer, Lloyd D. Levenson. (He had turned down a Cadillac worth $44,000 and a pair of Rolex watches worth $50,000.)

title: New Croat-Bosnian Link Worries U.N.
description: Three weeks before its threatened expulsion of United Nations peacekeepers is to begin, Croatia has forged a new military alliance with Bosnia, establishing what on paper is a common front between former adversaries to counter Serbian rebels in both their countries.

title: NeoStar Retail Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a net charge of $ 8,916,000, or 61 cents a share, for business combination costs resulting from the December 1994 merger of Babbage Inc. and Software Etc. Stores Inc., into the new company, NeoStar Retail Group.c-Net income(Loss)

title: Comptroller Predicts Bigger Budget Shortfall
description: New York City's Comptroller said yesterday that the city's budget gap could be $500 million higher than the $2.7 billion shortfall projected by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, largely because of overly optimistic estimates of tax revenues and rising costs of overtime, pensions and benefits for municipal workers.

title: Microsoft and U.S. Seek to Upset Judge's Decision
description: Teaming up with the Justice Department, its former adversary, the Microsoft Corporation filed an unusually personal brief today asking a Federal appeals court to overturn a judge's decision that dismissed the company's attempt to settle antitrust charges out of court.

title: Lindros Finally Makes An Impact for Islanders
description: For one night, at least, Brett Lindros found a way to take the weight of his name -- if not the weight of the franchise -- off his broad back.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK TO ACQUIRE HIBERNIA BOND UNIT
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it would acquire the municipal bond business of Hibernia National Bank. The terms were not disclosed. Hibernia National Bank is a unit of the Hibernia Corporation of New Orleans. Under the deal, the Bank of New York will take over the administration of more than $2.7 billion in outstanding securities. The agreement would mark the Bank of New York's sixth acquisition of a corporate trust department in the last 14 months. The purchases have increased the size of the Bank of New York's corporate trust department by about 12 percent in the last year, it said. The department administers more than $300 billion in securities.

title: BELLSOUTH TO STEP UP PLAN FOR CUTBACKS
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it would accelerate a cost-cutting plan, eliminating 15,000 jobs by early 1997, in a move to raise profits amid mounting competition in its local telephone markets. BellSouth, the nation's largest regional phone company, had planned to cut 10,200 jobs, about one of eight people in its work force, by the end of 1996. "Our staff reduction of 10,200 jobs will be reached by the end of 1995, one year ahead of schedule," the executive director of investor relations for BellSouth, Nancy Humphries, said at an investment conference. Then BellSouth, which is based in Atlanta, will continue to cut jobs at the rate of about 5,000 a year, she said.

title: Interface Inc.(IFSIA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: The share earnings for the latest periods were after preferred dividends of $ 437,000 in the quarter and $ 1,750,000 in the year. Year-ago periods' share earnings were after preferred dividends of $ 437,000 in the quarter and $ 913,000 in the year.

title: Fritz Cos.(FRTZ,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday, about the concerns of some large institutional shareholders of W. R. Grace & Company over the departure of the company's chief executive, referred incorrectly to an executive who spoke with them. He was Peter B. Martin, head of investor relations, not Thomas A. Holmes, Grace's interim president and chief executive.

title: Wellcome Is Accepting Glaxo Offer
description: Wellcome P.L.C. said today that it had given up its six-week hunt for another bidder and would accept the $15 billion takeover offer made in January by Glaxo P.L.C., creating the world's largest pharmaceutical company.

title:
Real Estate;
With Bertelsmann moving on to Broadway, a law firm takes its space at 666 Fifth Avenue
description: IN a complex transaction that sealed Bertelsmann's move to 1540 Broadway, Sumitomo Realty and Development (N.Y.) Inc., the owner of 666 Fifth, at 51st Street, agreed to take over the remaining five years on a lease Bertelsmann still held there on 66,000 square feet.

title: Lincoln Electric Co.(LIEL,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains of $ 3.2 million in the quarter and $ 2.7 million in the year from the reversal of restructuring charges.c-Net loss, which included restructuring charges of $ 40.9 million, or $ 3.77 a share, in the quarter and year. The year also included a gain of $ 2.5 million, or 23 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.(Loss)

title: Dollar's Fall Is Still Unabated; U.S. Officials Take No Action
description: Trying to ride out an enormous selloff of the dollar on markets around the world, the Clinton Administration watched with growing alarm today but without taking action as the currency fell to post-World-War-II lows against the Japanese yen and the German mark.

title: Frederic Billings Littlefield, 92, Founder of Maine Summer Camp
description: Frederic Billings Littlefield, founder of Camp Robin Hood in Brooksville, Me., where generations of boys made their summer homes, died on March 1 at his home in Medford, Mass. He was 92.

title: Six Communities Compete For a New Military Center
description: Wanted: 140,000 square feet of secure office space. Good airline connections to Latin America. Affordable family housing. Strategic site for nabbing drug lords and running top-secret military missions.

title: Brazil Stocks In a Steep Fall
description: Stock prices in Brazil plunged to a 10-month low today, after the Brazilian currency, the real, fell 3.6 percent against the dollar, raising concern that inflation would rise.

title: U.S. Is Urged To Investigate Cereal Prices
description: Two members of Congress have asked Attorney General Janet Reno to investigate the four largest cereal companies in the country -- Kellogg, General Mills, Post and Quaker Oats -- for antitrust violations.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball National Ledague

title: Bank of Montreal (BMO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Rangel's Mother, 90, Dies
description: Blanche Rangel, a retired garment worker and mother of United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, died on Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. A Harlem resident, she was 90.

title: Meggett's Parting Shots Irk Reeves
description: The David Meggett story is over except for one thing: Dan Reeves. Even though the Giants' coach released a statement after Meggett left for New England expressing how disappointed he was to lose him, until now Reeves has not had a chance to respond to some of the criticisms leveled against him by the former Giants running back and his representatives.

title: International Specialty Products Inc.(ISP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 1.2 million, or 1 cent a share, to refinance bank debt.c-Net lossd-Included pretax charge of $ 13.8 million primarily related to the company's cost-reduction program in the quarter and year. The year also included a tax provision of $ 2.9 million, or 3 cents a share.(Loss)

title: Arthur Schulte, 88, Investment Banker
description: Arthur David Schulte, a retired New York investment banker and philanthropist, died last Wednesday at the Hospice Center in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 88 and had homes in Manalapan, Fla., Greenwich, Conn., and Manhattan.

title: Analogic Corp.(ALOG,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Foreign Affairs; Mexican Malfunction
description: As my flight into Mexico City was landing, I began to feverishly fill out the customs form they passed out on the plane. Line three, though, stumped me. It consisted of nine different boxes, out of which you were supposed to find and circle your occupation. Columnist wasn't listed. There was, however, "farmer," "driver of a vehicle," "livestock raiser" and then one that just leapt out at me. It said: "bond holder."

title: Life Re Corp.(LRE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included an investment loss of $ 1,292,000 in the quarter and an investment gain of $ 89,000 in the year. Year-ago quarter included an investment loss of $ 1,655,000 and the year included an investment gain of $ 20,957,000.

title: The Lure and Addiction Of Life On Line
description: MARK P. had been sober for two years when he went on line. He began talking to other people through his office computer. He even found an on-line Alcoholics Anonymous meeting. At first it was exhilarating. Then it became a problem. He wrote in an electronic message:

title: Sports of The Times; Better Late Than Never For Ashburn
description: RICHIE ASHBURN invented Marvelous Marv Throneberry, but that is not the reason he was selected to the Baseball Hall of Fame yesterday. Richie Ashburn also threw Cal Abrams out at home to help the Phillies win the 1950 pennant, which is duly remembered by aging Brooklyn Dodgers fans, but that isn't why Ashburn was selected by the Veterans Committee, either.

title: HOUSE APPROVES MEASURE TO LIMIT FEDERAL LAWSUITS
description: Voting largely along party lines, the House of Representatives today passed legislation intended to curtail sharply the increasing number of lawsuits brought in Federal courts.

title: Green Wants to Level The Replacement Field
description: Mets Manager Dallas Green, angered by the lopsided nature of exhibition games between teams using young, talented minor leaguers and others using retreads and never-have-beens -- like his -- called on club owners today to redefine replacement baseball to restore some semblance of fair play until the strike by major leaguers is over.

title: Unemployment the Key Issue in French Election
description: Suddenly, the race to succeed President Francois Mitterrand this spring is wide open -- a tight contest between a Socialist and two rival conservatives that is all about jobs, jobs, jobs.

title: Rouse Co.(ROUS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 1,394,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 4,447,000, or 9 cents a share, in the year, both from the early extinguishment of debt.c-Net lossd-Included extraordinary charges of $ 1,255,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 8,051,000, or 17 cents a share, in the year, both from early extinguishment of debt.(Loss)The latest periods' results were after preferred dividends of $ 3,270,000 in the quarter and $ 13,081,000 in the year. Year-ago periods were after preferred dividends of $ 3,270,000 and $ 11,381,000 in the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Bradlees Inc.(BLE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a charge of $ 485,000, or 4 cents a share, from change in accounting for postemployment benefits.c-Included extraordinary charge of $ 5.2 million, or 46 cents a share, from refinancing of debt, and after a charge of $ 1,475,000, or 13 cents a share, from change in accounting for discounting certain self-insurance reserves to a ''risk-free'' rate.

title: A Cake Mix Derby
description: WHILE baking may be the province of the dedicated cook, nearly everyone needs to come up with a cake now and then. Since store-bought cakes are often quite expensive or unbearably undistinguished, cake mixes are often the logical alternative. This year, Americans are expected to spend more than $400 million on cake mixes.

title: U.S. Nuclear Pledge Needs Treaty Oversight
description: To the Editor:

title: Athena Shares Plunge On Rejection of Drug
description: Shares in Athena Neuroscience Inc. fell sharply today after the company said that it had received a letter from the Food and Drug Administration stating that its drug Zanaflex, a potential treatment for spasticity resulting from spinal cord injury, was not approvable.

title: Attacks on Youth Agency Called Unfair
description: A year after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that the Youth Services Department was plagued by rampant financial mismanagement and political manipulation, the City Investigation Department has determined that many of the allegations were unjustified or exaggerated.

title: Bank of Nova Scotia reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges with the ticker symbol of BNS.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Deb Shops (DEBS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income(Loss)

title: Courier Quickly Gets Off to a Cozy Start
description: Jim Courier, twice the titleholder of the Newsweek Champions Cup as well as a part-time desert resident, took advantage of the balmy conditions today to improve his 1995 match record to 20-2 with a 6-3, 7-5 dismissal of Markus Zoecke.

title: NeoStar Retail Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a net charge of $ 8,916,000, or 61 cents a share, for business combination costs resulting from the December 1994 merger of Babbage Inc. and Software Etc. Stores Inc., into the new company, NeoStar Retail Group.c-Net income(Loss)

title: Documentary Magazine To Make Debut in April
description: Robert Coles, a child psychiatrist, Harvard professor, social historian and author of more than 50 books, is a man who, at 65, is still searching for new ways to express the wonders of life.

title: Pay No InterestWell, Not at First
description: NO money down, no interest for one full year!" "Buy now, pay later -- interest free!" "No payment, no interest, no kidding!"

title: Tokyo Journal; Stoically, Japan Looks Back on the Flames of War
description: Surrounded by an inferno, overwhelmed by the smoke and the roar of collapsing buildings, Tatsuo Hamano, 17, decided that his only hope lay in running not away from the fire but into it.

title: Sports of The Times; Leon's Day In the Sun, At Last
description: SOON after Leon Day awoke Tuesday morning in St. Agnes Hospital in Baltimore, where he is being treated for a heart ailment, he was talking to his wife, Geraldine.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures in The Living Section yesterday with a review of Gianni Versace's fall fashion show in Milan, and in a cross reference on the front of the section, carried incorrect credits. The photographs were by Corina Lecca for The New York Times, not by The Associated Press.

title: Redskins Sign Stephens
description: The Washington Redskins moved to shore up their struggling defense by signing Seattle Seahawks middle linebacker ROD STEPHENS to a three-year free-agent contract.

title: Song Concert Postponed
description: The New York Festival of Song has postponed its concert tonight at Weill Recital Hall because Bernarda Fink, a mezzo-soprano, is ill. The performance is to be rescheduled later in the season. Subscribers and single-ticket buyers who purchased their tickets through Carnegie Charge will automatically receive credit on their accounts. Those who bought tickets at the box office may return them for refund, either in person or by mail to Carnegie Hall Box Office, 154 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019, Attention: NYFOS Refund. All requests must be made by May 19. Subscribers who bought tickets from the New York Festival of Song office may call for refunds: (212) 662-9909.

title: Records as Long As 7-Year-Old Arm; Thieves Are Too Young for Jail
description: The burglars who stole milk money from the Sisters of Charity defy standard police description.

title: Correction
description: The Pulse chart in The Metro Section on Monday, about New York City museums, misstated the availability of budget figures from the Whitney Museum of American Art. Though the numbers were not immediately available for the chart, the museum does disclose them: for the fiscal year 1991 (which began July 1, 1990) the budget was $ 13.5 million; for 1992, $ 13.1 million; for 1993, $ 12.9 million; for 1994, $ 13 million.

title: Journal; The Jew World Order
description: In a fiery speech delivered in Chicago on Feb. 26, Louis Farrakhan attacked "international bankers" for promoting this century's wars so that their "central banks" could collect interest off loans to the combatants. The bankers he singled out for ignominy were Jewish -- the Rothschilds in Europe, and, in America, their alleged agent Paul Warburg.

title: Novo Nordisk A/S(NVO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in American depository shares (ADS). Effective April 18, 1994, the ratio of Novo Nordisk's B shares to ADS's was changed to 1:4 - one B share representing four ADS's.The results in United States dollars were translated at the Dec. 31, 1994 exchange rate of U.S. $ 1.00 equaled DKK 6.083.

title: Frame by Small Frame, Perseverance Pays for Bowler
description: The royal blue bowling ball spun straight for the gutter, reached the edge of the yellow wood, hung for a moment half on the lip, half off, and then, as if having checked a map, changed course on a dime, wheeled left and crashed headlong into the 10 white pins, scattering them like a flock of geese.

title: Berkley (W.R.) Corp.(BKLY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included investment losses of $ 399,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 86,000, or 1 cent a share, in the year. Year-ago periods included investment gains of $ 4,037,000, or 23 cents a share, and $ 14,775,000, or 82 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively.

title: U.S. to Send F.B.I. Agents to Pakistan
description: Using its jurisdiction over terrorist attacks on Americans overseas, the Federal Bureau of Investigation prepared today to send a team of agents to Pakistan to investigate the shooting attack in Karachi on Tuesday that killed two United States consulate employees and wounded a third.

title: No Headline
description: "I remember one time I had a D, and he was like, 'You got to bring that up, man.' Then it was a C, and he said, 'You got to bring that up.' He was always pushing me to be my best." -- JOE HODGES, on Reuben Mills, his counselor in a youth program. [ B12:5. ]

title: Corrections
description: A listing on Sunday in the calendar of events of the Long Island Weekly, about a benefit auction at Dowling College in Oakdale, L.I., was incomplete. The event will be held on Saturday at 7:30 P.M. in the college's Fortunoff Hall.

title: New Question on Medics in Firefighter Death
description: The chairman of the medical council that regulates ambulance care in New York City said that the volunteer ambulance worker who treated a stricken firefighter last Sunday had apparently violated local regulations concerning advanced life-support care.

title: A Design Shop Worthy of Its Contents
description: CASSINA, the Italian company that is the licensed manufacturer for furniture designed by modern masters (including Frank Lloyd Wright, Le Corbusier, Gerrit Rietveld and Charles Rennie Mackintosh), has finally gone retail in America. Two Italian architects, Dario Caimi and Franco Asnaghi, have designed the company's first shop, at 155 East 56th Street (above). It is a stunning, stark white, two-story space with a curved wall cutting across it. The glass wall facing the street is stopping traffic -- literally. Last month, for example, a man left his car idling while he went in to examine Wright's Taliesen dining-room table and Coonley chairs.

title: Mistaking a Moment for a Mandate
description: These are heady days in the House. They are no less heady for Republican theorists and consultants, who are working feverishly to fabricate a mandate for all the legislative activity by attempting to elevate the 1994 election and give it meaning. That rush to judgment in the House, they argue, is not mere politics but a contract steeped in all the legitimacy of a popular conservative upheaval.

title: Developments in Washington
description: TERM LIMITS: Trying to avert an embarrassing defeat on a major campaign pledge, House Republicans postponed a vote on a Constitutional amendment to limit the terms of members of Congress. The vote was scheduled for Tuesday, but the Republican leadership put it off until the end of the month.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Bill Would Ease Death Votes
description: A State Assemblyman is drawing up legislation to allow executions in murder cases in which most, but not all, jurors vote for the death penalty.

title: Defense for Malcolm X's Daughter Seeks to Question Informer
description: Expressing outrage at what they portrayed as Federal investigators' sloppy supervision of a longtime Government informer who says Quibilah Bahiyah Shabazz tried to hire him to kill Louis Farrakhan, lawyers for Ms. Shabazz demanded today that the informer appear in court to testify at her pretrial hearing.

title: A home builder drops its nuts-and-bolts image for a 'trust us' campaign.
description: THE Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest house builder, is trying to build something other than dwellings with an unusual soft-sell campaign.

title: Ford Revises View of U.S. Auto Sales
description: The chairman of the Ford Motor Company, Alexander J. Trotman, said today that vehicle sales in the United States this year might fall short of the company's projection of 15.8 million units.

title: Account Changes At Pillsbury
description: A month after the Pillsbury Company acquired Pet Inc., the company has reassigned an account and added an agency to its roster.

title: Nets Falter But Finally Win One In Overtime
description: When their leading scorer and floor leader have the ball stripped from their hands in the final seconds of regulation, two things usually happen: the Nets lose and they grow extremely unhappy.

title: USAir Plan Will Cut 5% Of Capacity
description: USAir said yesterday that it would cut 5 percent of its capacity, joining other airlines that in recent years have overturned a long-held industry belief that bigger is better.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; College Gets Foreclosure Notice
description: Upsala College received notice yesterday that the Essex County Improvement Authority, seeking to recover a $4.2 million loan, had begun foreclosure proceedings on the five college buildings that secure it.

title: TV's Better Half
description: To The Home Section:

title: FOREST LABORATORIES SHARES FALL ON GENERIC'S ARRIVAL
description: Shares of Forest Laboratories Inc. fell 7.9 percent yesterday after it said the American Home Products Corporation would sell a generic version of Inderal SA that will compete with Forest's. Forest, a maker of generic and branded drugs based in New York, had been the only supplier of generic of propranolol hydrochloride, used to treat hypertension. American Home Products also sells the brand-name version of the drug, which was developed in 1968. Forest's shares closed down $4 yesterday, at $46.875.

title: Dollar's Four-Day Plunge Halts; Greenspan Hints at Higher Rates
description: The four-day plunge of the dollar in international currency markets halted today after the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, hinted that he might raise American interest rates, which would tend to encourage people to buy dollars.

title: Thunder Gulch Is Favored
description: Ten colts, including a three-horse entry trained by Nick Zito, were entered today in the $500,000 Florida Derby with a chance to go on to the Kentucky Derby. But the early line still favored Thunder Gulch, the traveler from the West Coast barn of D. Wayne Lukas, who won the Fountain of Youth Stakes three weeks ago.

title: MOORCO SAYS DANIEL INDUSTRIES REJECTS TAKEOVER OFFER
description: Moorco International Inc. said yesterday that Daniel Industries Inc. had rejected a takeover offer of $196 million. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, Daniel stock closed $2.125 higher, at $14.75. Moorco shares dropped 37.5 cents to $14.25. Under the proposal, Moorco, a supplier of measurement and high-pressure control products for the energy industry, would have paid $11.90 in cash and exchanged three-tenths of one share for each Daniel share. Moorco and Daniel, a maker of fluid-measurement products, are both based in Houston. Daniel said it wanted to pursue a restructuring plan to cut costs and focus on more profitable product lines.

title: Mayor Booed on West Side
description: Discontent with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's budget policies and the prospect of diminished city services dominated a "town hall" meeting in Manhattan last night at which the Mayor struggled to explain his fiscal strategy, but was incessantly booed.

title: Rebuttal on Ex-Barings Trader's Role
description: Lawyers for Nicholas W. Leeson said today that Mr. Leeson, the former trader for Barings P.L.C., had not been trying to flee from justice when he abruptly left Singapore last month, and that he was not solely responsible for the collapse of the British investment firm.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: UNION TIED TO JAVITS CENTER IS SEIZED Asserting that the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is riddled with corruption, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters seized control of the union local that dispenses many jobs at the center, saying it was a patronage mill for mobsters and convicted felons. A1. NEW YORK CITY WASHINGTON, BROKE, GETS GIULIANI'S ADVICE In his hometown, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is wrestling with a budget gap that's still growing despite deep cuts. But in flat-broke Washington, lawmakers have turned to Mr. Giuliani for budgetary advice. B3.

title: A Young Bassist, Skipping His Way Around the Scales
description: Christian McBride started his late set on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard with a classic bass player's gambit: a brisk walking line, which introduced "Cherokee." The walk, however, was more like hopscotch, lightly skipping around typical walking-bass scales. The arrangement of "Cherokee" was equally novel, shifting unpredictably between fast be-bop and a waltz.

title: Economic Scene; Managing the airwaves for productivity and profits.
description: THE policy honchos who fought long and hard to auction the airwaves rather than give them away are preening these days, and for good reason. Bids for licenses to transmit voice, data and video over the air are now more than $5 billion -- money most welcome in an era when ketchup again seems destined to be reclassified as a vegetable.

title: Now, the Tough Issue: Palestinian Refugees
description: For the first time, Arab and Israeli officials have met to discuss one of the region's most emotion-laden issues: the fate of hundreds of thousands of Palestinian refugees living outside Israel and its occupied territories.

title: Senate Democrats Show Their Plan to Balance Budget
description: Senate Democrats today introduced their own balanced-budget proposal, a statute they said would achieve the goals of the defeated balanced-budget amendment but more quickly and without counting Social Security trust funds against the deficit.

title: Orchard Supply Hardware Stores Corp.(OSHC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 3,955,000, or 57 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 9.3 million, or $ 1.57 a share, in the year, on write-offs from the extinguishment of debt.(Loss)Share earnings for the latest fourth quarter and year-ago period were calculated after preferred stock dividends to reflect the income available to common stock for all periods.

title: Kitt's Victory Overturned And New Race Is Scheduled
description: The International Ski Federation yesterday overturned the decision of a jury in Aspen, Colo., and wiped out the results of last weekend's storm-plagued Aspen downhill, won by A J KITT. It ordered the race to be rerun Saturday, but in Norway.

title: Baryshnikov And Feld Rejoin Forces
description: Eliot Feld choreographed a solo for Mikhail Baryshnikov in 1977, the same year that Mr. Feld established the New Ballet School, which continues to provide thousands of children with tuition-free ballet training.

title: F.D.A. Head Calls Smoking a Pediatric Disease
description: Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said today that smoking was fundamentally a pediatric disease because most addiction to tobacco begins among teen-agers, and outlined steps to combat the problem.

title: Review/Fashion; Opulence Is Back: Fendi Lets the Fur Flow
description: Luxury lives. At least for some. Both the Fendi and Genny collections shown today are intended for women who aren't afraid to wear their wealth on their backs. Maybe it isn't the 1960's or 70's but the 80's that are coming back.

title: Elbit Ltd.(ELBTF,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 9.4 million write-off and other expenses related to the company's acquisition of Fibronics International on Dec. 30, 1994, in the quarter and year.c-Included gains of $ 12.3 million from changes of holdings in units, primarily Elscint Ltd.

title: A Milestone for Larmer in Rangers' Night of Stars
description: After Rangers beat the Devils in a 6-4 extravaganza last night, Mark Messier looked across the locker room and smiled when he saw a knot of reporters around Steve Larmer, asking Larmer about his milestone.

title: Russian Opposition Leader Opens Old Wounds on Visit to India
description: On his first visit to the Indian subcontinent, the Russian nationalist leader, Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, was strongly criticized by Pakistan and Bangladesh today for remarks in which he said that he opposed the "artifical division of any country" and that India should be restored to its pre-independence unity, which would include Pakistan and Bangladesh.

title: The Long . . . And Short of It; The Height Of Luxury
description: TO duck, or not to duck: that is the question. Whether 'tis nobler to suffer low doorways and short beds -- or perhaps, by design, to replace them with 8-foot doors, 20-foot ceilings and beds 8 feet long. Is this the stuff basketball players (and other vertical achievers) dream of?

title: Man Dies After Struggle With Police in Subway
description: A Brooklyn man died in police custody yesterday after an altercation with at least seven officers in which pepper spray was used, the police said.

title: AFTER APPRAISAL, LIN BROADCASTING SHARES FALL
description: Shares of the Lin Broadcasting Corporation fell yesterday after an independent appraisal valued the company at $127.50 a share -- 18 percent below an appraisal given by Lin's investment bank. Lin's shares closed down $7.25, at $121. Three million shares were traded. Wasserstein Perella & Company, an investment bank, gave an independent appraisal on Tuesday that determined the AT&T Corporation would have to pay $127.50 a share, or $3.25 billion, for Lin if the long distance telephone company decided to buy the 48 percent of Lin that it did not already own. The appraisal was announced after the close of trading.

title: Fay's Inc.(FAY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a charge of $ 4,806,000, or 24 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.The latest year's results included charge of 10 cents a share for expenses related to the closing of nine Paper Cutter stores.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Officer Sees License, and More
description: It may turn out to be more expensive than the typical speeding ticket. Errol Lee of Levittown, Pa., was pulled over on the New Jersey Turnpike on Tuesday night near Exit 7 in Burlington County for doing 75 miles an hour in a 55-m.p.h zone.

title: Democrats Plan to Have 2 State Chairmen
description: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver will endorse Judith H. Hope of East Hampton and John T. Sullivan of Oswego to be co-leaders of the state Democratic Committee, Democratic officials said today.

title: Clinton Issues Order to Build Union Muscle
description: President Clinton sided with organized labor today and issued an order barring the Federal Government from doing business with companies that hire permanent replacement workers during strikes.

title: Postcards From the Lap
description: PEOPLE who take business trips with laptop computers can stop thinking of the machines as office equipment and start using them as a way to keep in touch with friends and family while on the road.

title: Dutoit and the Philadelphia Bring Another 'Jeanne d'Arc'
description: It is probably still safe to describe Honegger's 1935 dramatic oratorio "Jeanne d'Arc au Bucher" ("Joan of Arc at the Stake") as a rarity, even though the Philadelphia Orchestra's performance on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall follows a New York Philharmonic account by only 11 months. Before that the work's last major performance in New York was at a 1984 Boston Symphony concert, and finding a good recording still takes some effort.

title: Months After the Tar, A Feather in His Cap
description: RICHARD L. MURPHY -- the former Youth Services Commissioner who was tarred by the Giuliani administration a year ago, but then cleared this week of the worst charges -- sounds remarkably philosophical about the whole thing. "I realize the power of government when it wants to abuse it," Mr. Murphy said over the phone. "I think this has been an abuse of power. And even though I'm sort of a minor player in the whole sea of things, one felt a lot of pain. A reputation was on the line."

title: World News Briefs; Clinton to Visit Haiti For Shift of G.I.'s to U.N.
description: The White House said today that President Clinton would visit Haiti on March 31. Mr. Clinton will meet with President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, whom the United States helped to restore to power, and is expected to preside over ceremonies handing over the United States peacekeeping mission to the United Nations.

title: The Arms Bazaar Expands Eastward
description: The Clinton Administration wants new markets for American-made arms, and is looking for them in all the wrong places. Instead of trying to limit arms trafficking around the globe, it is now ready to make sales to former Soviet bloc countries. That is the message of the Administration's disappointing new policy on arms sales.

title: Unraveling Copyright Rules for Cyberspace
description: Government officials from 11 industrial nations have concluded their first official meeting on copyright issues in cyberspace, with plans to keep looking for agreements on protecting intellectual property in an electronic world that knows no physical borders.

title: More Progeny of 'Cheers'
description: The departed "Cheers" is still a major player in the sitcom game. "Frasier" is a direct spinoff. Now, taking indirect routes, there's NBC's "Hope and Gloria," created by Bill and Cheri Steinkellner, former Emmy Award winners for "Cheers," and CBS has "The George Wendt Show," whose star is probably better known as Norm Peterson, former accountant and champion devourer of beer nuts for 11 years at the Cheers bar in Boston.

title: 13 Stadium Renovation Plans Later, Yankees Are Still Dissatisfied
description: Several weeks after city officials presented their latest plan to renovate Yankee Stadium, a top team official has suggested that it may be impossible to rebuild the historic stadium in a way that would satisfy the team's principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d.

title: Dance Magazine Award
description: Susan Marshall, Carla Maxwell and the Nicholas Brothers have been named the recipients of the Dance Magazine Award for 1995. Presented for significant contributions to dance since 1954, the awards will honor Ms. Marshall for her modern-dance choreography, Ms. Maxwell for her dancing, teaching and directorship of the Jose Limon Dance Company and Fayard and Harold Nicholas for their tap-dancing in a number of film classics. The awards are to be presented on April 17 in a private ceremony at the Asia Society in Manhattan.

title: Warm Temperatures Push Heating Oil to 11-Month Low
description: Heating oil prices tumbled to an 11-month low yesterday, as unusually warm weather continued to cut short the season of peak demand. Prices of crude oil also fell.

title: Dusted and Muscled Up: A New William Morris
description: Talent agencies in Hollywood develop their own personalities. The most powerful -- Creative Artists Agency -- seems chilly, remote, almost scary in its intensity. Its main competitor, International Creative Management, resembles a none-too-happy family, with everyone in it locked in separate rooms and barely speaking to one another. A third agency, United Talent, is in such a state of crisis that it recently hired a therapist to work out the hostile, aggressive and passive-aggressive tendencies of its agents.

title: Wave of Killing in Sicily Raises Fear of Mafia Terror Campaign
description: Alarmed by nine gangland-style slayings in Sicily in the last 10 days, Italian prosecutors have warned of a new "terrorist campaign" by the Mafia aimed in part at silencing informers who have been vital to the Government's offensive against organized crime.

title: Wheelchair Offers No Respite for Gang Member
description: It was only when Lamar Lewis emerged from the hospital, paralyzed from a gang shooting in Watts, that he realized just how harsh life on the streets can be.

title: U.N. Parley Puts Focus On Africa
description: There was little disagreement today among rich and poor countries over the special and urgent needs of Africa south of the Sahara, as delegates at the World Summit on Social Development debated, sometimes bitterly, a plan for fighting worldwide poverty.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Chicago is selling $132.1 million of tax-exempt general obligation bonds through First Chicago Capital Markets Inc. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 6.35 percent for an issue due in 2016. For short-maturity serial bonds, yields range from 5.00 percent in 1998 to 6.25 percent in 2013. The bonds are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Services and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. * Cone Mills Corp., Greensboro, N.C., is selling $100 million of notes due in 2005 priced at 99.831 percent to yield 8.125 percent through J. P. Morgan Securities. The notes are noncallable and are rated Baa2 by Moody's and BBB by S.& P.

title: Republicans Bite Elections Watchdog
description: House Republicans promised in their Contract With America to "restore accountability to Congress." They have chosen an odd way to go about it. They are moving to cripple the Federal Election Commission, the agency charged with enforcing the campaign finance laws that provide at least some check on obsessive political fund-raising.

title: Accounts
