description: A list of credits last Wednesday with a review of the 10-part television show "The History of Rock 'n' Roll" omitted the name of the producer, writer and director of "Plugging In," an episode discussed in the review. She is Susan Steinberg.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: International Briefs; Tokyo Trade Surplus Up 5.3% in February
description: Japan's trade surplus rose 5.3 percent in February from a year earlier, officials said yesterday, with export volume resuming somewhat as Japanese learned to cope with the effects of Jan. 17 earthquake that halted operations at the port of Kobe.

title: MAPLE LEAF FOODS SEEKS OTHER SUITORS
description: Maple Leaf Foods Inc. is inviting other investors to challenge Wallace McCain's takeover bid of $1.3 billion (Canadian), or $868 million (United States), a financial adviser to the company said yesterday. Last week, Mr. McCain, co-founder and former president of McCain Foods Ltd., and the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board offered $13.75 to $15 a share for the Toronto-based food processor. But "there are other people looking at the company in terms of being in a position to make other offers," said David Ward, managing director of mergers and acquisitions at Nesbitt Burns Inc., which is advising Maple Leaf's independent directors.

title: In Defense of Algae
description: To The Living Section:

title: SUNY Trustees Plan Cuts Under Pataki's Budget Plan
description: Trustees of the State University of New York said today for the first time that they would close or merge eight campuses or hospitals and raise tuition $1,600 a year, to $4,250, if Gov. George E. Pataki's budget cuts were approved.

title: Baker (J.) Inc.(JBAK,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
The Iran Exception; U.S. Will Deal With Other Old Foes But Still Sees Teheran as an Outlaw
description: If American business has received a single clear message from the Clinton Administration during the last year, here it is: Join the age of "economic engagement," by helping the United States win over the souls of authoritarian regimes through greater access to American capital and investment.

title: A Likely Next Company For a Board Room Coup
description: General Motors. I.B.M. Westinghouse. Eastman Kodak. Is Kmart next?

title: Bowe Calls the Garden
description: ROCK NEWMAN, RIDDICK BOWE's manager, will meet today with DAVE CHECKETTS, the president of Madison Square Garden, to discuss staging a heavyweight fight between Bowe and MIKE TYSON. "Rock called here, and we're exploring boxing, so we should talk," said JOHN CIRILLO, a Garden spokesman.

title: Chief of Nuclear Panel Quits To Build Gas-Run Generators
description: The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said this morning that he would quit his job on July 1, a year before his term ends, to go into business in Asia building electric power plants that burn natural gas.

title: OfficeMax Inc.(OMX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 21
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma. The company went public Nov. 1, 1994.

title: Paychex Inc.(PAYX,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Devils Trade For Defense
description: The Devils traded center Aleksandr Semak and right wing Ben Hankinson to the Tampa Bay Lightning today for defenseman Shawn Chambers and right wing Danton Cole.

title: Waiver Sought in Carjack Case
description: Attempted murder, assault, carjacking, weapons possession and robbery. With charges like these against a 17-year-old Montclair youth, officials want to try him as an adult in the shooting of a woman in her West Caldwell driveway.

title: Kirby Corp.(KEX,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Coventry Corp.(CVTY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 2,896,000, or 9 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 3,355,000, or 12 cents a share, in the year.

title: Simms Close to a Deal
description: PHIL SIMMS, the former Giants quarterback who was cut from the team last year, is believed to be close to cutting a comeback deal with the Cleveland Browns. The dollars being discussed would make the 39-year-old Simms the highest-paid backup quarterback in the National Football League.

title: Broadway StoresInc.(BWY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net lossc-Included $ 20 million pretax charge in the quarter and $ 45 million pretax charge in the year, both for nonrecurring costs.(Loss)

title: Weak Retail Sales Cheer Markets, Sending Stocks Up
description: It was a surprisingly good day on Wall Street yesterday, although the dollar remained under pressure.

title: 3COM CORP. (COMS,NNM)
description: The 3Com Corporation said yesterday that its income from operations for the fiscal third quarter rose 82 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, exceeding Wall Street's expectations, on strong sales of its computer-network equipment.

title: TV Bonanza for U.S. Team
description: In a follow-up to the television success of last year's World Cup, four television networks will broadcast 84 games to be played by the United States national soccer teams through 1997. ABC will show 10 games, ESPN 28, ESPN2 24, and the Prime Network 22. Univision will broadcast at least 40 Spanish-language games.

title: Sanders to Stand Trial
description: Cincinnati Reds outfielder DEION SANDERS will have to stand trial on misdemeanor charges stemming from a confrontation with a police officer at Riverfront Stadium. Yesterday, Judge DAVID DAVIS of Hamilton County Municipal Court set a trial date of May 15. (AP)

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Arrest in Motel Room Strangling
description: A man accused of strangling his girlfriend in a North Bergen motel room on Sunday was arrested yesterday in Miami.

title: INSIDE
description: Syria Agrees to Meet Israel

title: Texans Fight Concealed Weapons Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Didn't Hear That Plea for Cash
description: First the sound, then the fury.

title: Firefighters Hurt in Collapse
description: Five Newark firefighters are lucky that they did not have to spend last night in the hospital after being injured in a fire that investigators said was arson.

title: Elizabeth Futas, 50; Led Library School
description: Elizabeth Dorothy Futas, the director of the University of Rhode Island's Graduate School of Library and Information Studies, died on Feb. 6 in Philadelphia. She was 50 and lived in Wakefield, R.I.

title: Aron Pressman, 97, Professor of Russian
description: Aron Pressman, a former head of the Russian department at New York University, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Sunderland, Mass. A former resident of Manhattan, he was 97 and had lived in Amherst, Mass., since moving from Manhattan in the 1960's.

title: 'John Doe' Is Fighting 'Megan'
description: Lots of people have questions about Megan's Law, the measure permitting prosecutors to warn neighborhoods when sex offenders move in. And the State Supreme Court pledged yesterday to try to come up with answers as soon as possible. Saying it would hear appeals on an emergency basis, the court scheduled arguments for May 2 in the case of a Burlington County man, identified only as John Doe, who filed suit because he does not want to register with the police.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Sabres Beat the Panthers Yuri Khmylev had an assist and scored the game-winning goal 54 seconds into overtime to lift Buffalo to a 2-1 victory over Florida last night in Miami. Although Buffalo goaltender Dominik Hasek inadvertently kicked the Panthers' lone goal into his own net, he was spectacular when it counted, turning aside 32 shots. (AP)

title: Gulf War General Is Named as Senior Marine
description: President Clinton today nominated a veteran of the Persian Gulf war and son of a Marine Corps general to be the next Commandant of the Marines.

title: Eric Richards Rippel; Executive, 60
description: Eric Richards Rippel, a New Jersey executive, died on Thursday in a car accident in Alexandria Township, N.J. He was 60 and lived in Alexandria Township.

title: Excerpt From Reno's Letter on Cisneros
description: Following is an excerpt from the letter by Attorney General Janet Reno asking the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to appoint an independent counsel to investigate Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros.

title: The Albany Budget Games Begin
description: In a bipartisan display of fantasy and procrastination, New York State legislators are already looking to save favored programs from devastating budget cuts while carrying out Gov. George Pataki's proposed tax reductions without the money to pay for them.

title: Rabbi L. J. Bernstein, 67, Orthodox Jewish Leader
description: Rabbi Louis J. Bernstein, president of the 1,000-member Rabbinical Council of America and a major spokesman for modern Orthodox Jewry for three decades, died on Sunday at his home in Bayside, Queens. He was 67.

title: American Express Pact
description: American Express Travel Services Group said yesterday that Allied Signal Inc. had chosen it to provide business travel services, the corporate card and the corporate purchasing card. The five-year agreement, expected to be signed soon, will consolidate $350 million in annual travel and purchases through American Express.

title: Volcker Adds Chief's Post at Wolfensohn
description: James D. Wolfensohn Inc. is reorganizing because its founder and chief executive, Mr. Wolfensohn, has been nominated to become president of the World Bank, the private investment-banking firm said yesterday.

title: Marshall Industries(MI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a charge of $ 163,000, or 1 cent a share, related to tax rate increase, and an after-tax restructuring charge of $ 525,000, or 3 cents a share.Share earnings and shares outstanding for 1994 year were adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 28, 1994.

title: Murderer Says Victim Was Witch
description: In an eerie monologue before his sentencing yesterday, the man convicted of fatally stabbing a former Rockette four years ago as she walked her dogs near Central Park told a court in Manhattan that his victim may have been a witch and had been "making noises" at him that disrupted his life.

title: Sports of The Times; Don't Use Jordan As a Pawn
description: IT was an embarrassment of riches for Jerry Reinsdorf, who owns both the Chicago Bulls and the Chicago White Sox. Not only did Reinsdorf suddenly have Michael Jordan considering a return to the Bulls, which would make them formidable opponents in the playoffs, but he could also deliver a hit in the baseball labor negotiations.

title: MEDIQ'S MANAGEMENT MAKES A BUYOUT OFFER
description: Mediq Inc., a health services company based in Pennsauken, N.J., said yesterday that it had received a $437 million buyout offer from management executives. The management team would pay $6.87 for each Mediq share. That price includes $4 in cash and $2.87 in stock in affiliated companies and a note from Mental Health Management Inc., a psychiatric care services company that is a former unit of Mediq.

title: Oracle in Talks to Offer Video News Service
description: The Oracle Corporation, a leading maker of software for managing large computer data bases, is in discussions with several telephone, computer and news organizations to create a nationwide digital video service that would let users of personal computers customize their own video newscasts or conduct on-line research from video news archives.

title: J. R. Pennock, 89, Political Professor, Theorist and Author
description: J. Roland Pennock, a political scientist who made his mark in legal and political theory, died on Feb. 19 at Bryn Mawr Hospital in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 89 and lived in Haverstraw, Pa.

title: Study Sees a Sugar-Adrenaline Link in Children
description: ALTHOUGH parents commonly complain that their children become wild and inattentive after eating a lot of sweets, most researchers have steadfastly insisted that the effects of sugar on children are negligible, if they exist at all. But now a new study by pediatric researchers at Yale University School of Medicine suggests that the parents' observations may be correct.

title: PLAN TO CONTRACT OUT OPERATION OF SERVICE CENTERS
description: To lower its costs, United Parcel Service of America Inc. said yesterday it would contract the function of its customer-service centers around the United States to an outside company. The Atlanta-based shipping company "will do everything possible" to relocate the 5,800 employees at the centers, which number more than 65, a company spokesman said. Transferring customer-service operations to a still-unnamed company will occur in the next two years, providing time to find slots for the displaced workers. The centers, which provide information about services, rates and delivery schedules, are likely to be consolidated to no more than 12 sites. U.P.S. has about 300,000 employees worldwide.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Top Rung Is Always a Bit Shaky; This Time, No. 1 U.C.L.A. Hopes to Survive the First Round
description: The same people who disowned the U.C.L.A. Bruins one tournament ago -- Bill Walton to name one -- are massaging them now. The view from the top is breathtaking, but this U.C.L.A. team knows the traction at No. 1 is not firm.

title: Detective Holds His Own Against Lawyer
description: F. Lee Bailey, the legal legend reborn in the O. J. Simpson case, hammered away further today at Detective Mark Fuhrman, the officer whom the defense deems the Achilles' heel of the prosecution. But despite suggestions that he was a bigot and a liar, Mr. Fuhrman again held his own, returning Mr. Bailey's slams with gentle, soft-spoken lobs.

title: Nuclear Trail -- A special report.; A Vast Smuggling Network Feeds Iran's Arms Program
description: The tiny Hartenholm civilian airport here, with its fleet of a dozen aging Cessnas, small wooden building for the local parachute club, snack bar, nine warehouses and red and white checkered control tower, appears to be the idyllic home for weekend and business fliers.

title: Eagle-Picher Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
The Victorious Appeal Of a Dish Low in Meat
description: IT is a victory of sorts when a meat-and-potatoes man praises a meal with only four ounces of lamb and even has seconds on the spinach with oranges.

title: Berlitz Intl.(BTZ,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss(Loss)Full-year 1993 is not comparable since company merged with Fukutake Publishing during period. For the post-merger period from Feb. 1, 1993, to Dec. 31, 1993, company reported a loss of $ 3.5 million, or 35 cents a share, on revenues of $ 252.1 million and 10,031,000 outstanding shares.Corrected from Thursday, March 9, editions.

title: In Gesture to Rebels, Mexico Will Pull Back Its Troops
description: Hoping to entice peasant rebels in the southern state of Chiapas to join new peace talks, the Mexican Government said today that it would move army troops out of villages within the territory formerly controlled by the insurgents.

title: DEAL COMPLETED FOR QUAKER'S PET FOOD BUSINESSES
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said yesterday that it had completed its $725 million acquisition of the United States and Canadian pet food businesses of the Quaker Oats Company. Heinz said the purchase would double the revenue and profit of its Heinz Pet Products division, which last year had sales of more than $600 million. Quaker's pet foods division, which include products like Kibbles'n Bits, Cycle and Ken-L Ration dog foods, has annual North American sales of about $540 million, Heinz said.

title: Fallout Risks Near Atom Tests Were Known, Documents Show
description: The United States military knew there were serious health risks of radioactive fallout from nuclear bomb testing in 1951 and, though a safer site was available, chose to explode weapons near populated areas in Nevada to get better data on where the fallout would go, according to documents uncovered by the President's Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments.

title: N.F.L.: Sapp Did Not Test Positive for Cocaine
description: The National Football League labeled as "inaccurate" a report in The New York Times yesterday that Warren Sapp had tested positive for cocaine. Sapp, the former Miami defensive lineman, is a potential No. 1 pick in next month's N.F.L. draft, and the player's attorney, Drew Rosenhaus, said he was "wrongly accused."

title: Reneging on AmeriCorps
description: The House will decide as early as today whether to take back two-thirds of the money it previously voted to spend this year on AmeriCorps, President Clinton's national service program. The slashing attack on a worthy program can only be interpreted as an effort to humiliate the President.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Pat Robertson Gives Focus to Our Disaffection; Attack on Freemasons
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE SUPPORTS TAX CUT
description: The House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill today to reduce taxes by almost $200 billion over the next five years, a cornerstone of the Republicans' Contract With America.

title: The G.O.P.'s Contract Makes Government More Responsible
description: To the Editor:

title: American Israeli Paper Mills Ltd.(AIP,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Remorseful Killer Draws Stiff Term
description: Expressing regret for killing the couple that had moved into his boyhood home, a Larchmont man broke down in tears before drawing the maximum sentence of 16 2/3 to 50 years in prison.

title: Taylor Is Starting Back On Road to the Stadium
description: Brien Taylor leads a lonely existence in the chaotic world of baseball. It is the existence of a 23-year-old prospect trying to make a comeback from a serious shoulder injury before ever unleashing one pitch in a major league game. Alone, he is trying to regain what he lost.

title: Next Messier Confronts the Current One
description: When Eric Lindros was a teen-ager in junior hockey, he used to keep a Mark Messier hockey card on his locker shelf as if it were some sort of religious totem. Now that Lindros is 22 years old and a third-year veteran, he no longer displays a Messier picture in the dressing room. He simply plays like a young Messier on the ice.

title: Eagle Hardware & Garden Inc.(EAGL,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $ 14,331,000, or 63 cents a share, which included a write-off of Canadian deferred tax benefit of $ 1,616,000, and a loss on the sale of the company's Canadian unit of $ 12,715,000, in the quarter and year.c-Net income(Loss)

title: Bumper to Bumper to Bumper
description: Diminished services and increased fares. That was the prospect held out by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg and former Gov. Jim Florio if the Federal Government goes ahead with proposed cuts in mass transit aid.

title: Effort to Preserve a Political Dynasty in East Harlem Fails by a Wide Margin
description: William Del Toro's attempt to win his brother's State Assembly seat in East Harlem ended in a crushing upset last night at the hands of Francisco Diaz Jr., the manager of Community Board 11 and a neighborhood political organizer.

title: No Headline
description: "In my old age, it occurred to me that we could make a difference to our country, and do it with an institution that had staying power and that I was familiar with. After all, Harvard has been around more than 300 years. JOHN L. LOEB, after he and his wife gave Harvard $70.5 million. [ B11:5. ]

title: Seat-Back Translations At the Met Next Fall
description: The Metropolitan Opera is to introduce its new seat-back translation system -- called Met Titles instead of the more common supertitles -- at an Oct. 2 performance of Verdi's "Otello," which will open the 1995-96 season.

title: Swim Medals Spiced by a Family Reunion
description: Cristina Teuscher was ecstatic when she learned that the 1995 Pan American Games would be held in Argentina. Her parents were born in Buenos Aires. Her grandparents still live there. This would be a great opportunity to compete in front of her relatives. Then she thought again. She was a swimmer, and Argentina appeared to be a country without any pools.

title: Big B Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a pretax write-off of about $ 1 million, or 4 cents a share after tax, for unusable equipment.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Patterns column on the Fashion page yesterday about a plan by a group of French fashion editors to single out a late-starting show for a walkout misspelled the name of the fashion editor of Le Figaro. She is Janie Samet. Because of an editing error the report also misstated the home country of Le Figaro. It is a French daily, not Italian.

title: Having a World Title Is Fine, But Jones Still Yearns for More
description: The diamond and ruby ring proclaims him the world supermiddleweight champion. But for Roy Jones Jr., there is a time-honored and mythical title he is after: best fighter, pound for pound.

title: Big Investor Relations Task: Selling Mexico to Wall St.
description: Mexico, the prodigal son of the financial markets, has a lot to do if it is to repair its credibility with Wall Street and international investors, who poured billions of dollars into Mexico and were badly scalded by the recent 48 percent devaluation of the Mexican peso.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: YALE RETURNS $20 MILLION TO PATRON

title: CHRONICLE
description: Birds of different feathers flocked together Monday night to hear readings from essays that celebrate the nation's open spaces and frequently bemoan their shrinkage.

title: Food Notes
description: Times Square Tastes

title: Foot Behind Head, Woody Harrelson Goes Positively Yogic
description: WE were entering the fourth chakra, the chakra of love.

title: Alumnus Expands Love Affair With Harvard by Offering a Monumental Gift
description: As a transfer student to Harvard in 1921, John L. Loeb did not stand out in any special way. But as an alumnus, he has been truly spectacular.

title: Iwo Jima Journal; A Pacific Isle That Can't Quite Rest in Peace.
description: They traded war stories, visited battle sites and stood uneasily next to men they had tried their hardest to kill.

title: Real Estate; Development, including luxury apartments, is stirring in a business park near Orlando, Fla.
description: DEVELOPMENT in the largest business park in the metropolitan region here, which had virtually ground to a halt in recent years, is off to a fast start this year with two new projects.

title: Taking to Airwaves for (or Against) Budget
description: Applying the tactics of campaign warfare to New York's budget battle, both Republicans and Democrats began flooding the airwaves today with advertisements designed to build pressure for and against Gov. George E. Pataki's spending cuts.

title: Indian Premier Faces Criticism for State Losses
description: Hindu right-wing governments took office today in the industrially developed Western states of Maharashtra and Gujarat, redrawing India's political map and underlining the growing isolation of Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao's Congress Party.

title: A Space First: Russians Launch American
description: Streaking through the icy atmosphere in a spacecraft that until recently he would have had to risk his life just to see, Norman E. Thagard today became the first American to enter space aboard a Russian rocket.

title: Pat Robertson Gives Focus to Our Disaffection
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Seeks Results of Babies' AIDS Tests
description: In the continuing battle over whether newborns should be tested for the AIDS virus and their mothers told the results, a New York City advocacy group for children filed suit yesterday to force New York State to do so.

title: Tragedy Casts Harsh Light on Volunteer Ambulance Units
description: They are a familiar blur as they rush through the city's incident-prone streets, sirens screaming, responding to calls from the stricken. On board are crews of "weekend warriors" -- accountants, electricians, truck drivers, plumbers -- animated by do-goodism and accompanied by city ambulance workers who say they want to rescue lives in the off-hours as well.

title: PAINE WEBBER IS SAID TO BE CONSIDERING JOB CUTS
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. may eliminate as many as 500 jobs, or 3 percent of its total work force, in an effort to cut its compensation costs, traders at the brokerage firm said yesterday. Paine Webber did not decide on the cuts during a board meeting yesterday, a person familiar with the firm said. Paine Webber is considering the dismissals as it tries to cut compensation costs by $20 million, according to an article in The Wall Street Journal. A spokeswoman for Paine Webber declined to comment on the report. The possible cuts come after Paine Webber acquired Kidder, Peabody & Company from the General Electric Company last year, increasing Paine Webber's work force by 14 percent, to about 16,600 people.

title: Hills Stores Co.(HDS,N) reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 28
description: b-Included a gain of $ 9.6 million related to a reversal of liabilities established in ''fresh-start'' accounting, partially offset by $ 2.2 million in additional amortization of deferred financing costs and $ 2.2 million paid to holders of senior notes connected to the company's self-tender. The net after-tax effect of these nonrecurring items was to increase fully diluted earnings by 19 cents a share.c-Included various nonrecurring gains which increased fully diluted earnings by 23 cents a share.The pro forma combined statement of operations presents the pro forma combined results of opeations of the successor and predecessor companies for the 52 weeks ended Jan. 29, 1994 and have been adjusted to reflect: the implementation of fresh start reporting as of Jan. 31, 1993; elimination of the effects of nonrecurring transactions resulting from the reorganization included in the results of the predecessor company; and payment to creditors pursuant to the plan of reorganization as of Jan. 31, 1993.The fiscal 1994 results are pro forma, reflecting the fact that the company emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy and adopted ''fresh-start'' accounting as of Oct. 2, 1993.

title: Clinton Shouldn't Meddle in Irish Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Why a Fez Is a Sensation at Israel's Book Fair
description: Even though he was only taking books out of boxes and putting them on shelves, Nghimi Filali caused a small sensation in his fez and long robe.

title: The G.O.P.'s Contract Makes Government More Responsible; A 20 Percent Mandate
description: To the Editor:

title: Horizon Outlet to Acquire McArthur/Glen Realty
description: Horizon Outlet Centers Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the McArthur/Glen Realty Corporation in a stock swap valued at $302 million. The merger will create the nation's largest owner of factory outlet centers.

title: The Knicks Meet the Enemy; It May Be Themselves
description: A sideline disagreement between Coach Pat Riley and Anthony Mason, which led to Mason briefly leaving the bench during the game, overshadowed New York's 94-74 victory over the Denver Nuggets last night.

title: Man Gets Maximum Term For Killings in Larchmont
description: Expressing regret for killing the couple that had moved into his boyhood home, a Larchmont man broke down in tears today before drawing the maximum sentence of 16 2/3 to 50 years in prison.

title: Puritan-Bennett Corp.(PBEN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $ 2,654,000 in the quarter and year, and charges of $ 490,000 in the quarter and $ 5,049,000 in the year for costs associated with unsolicited offers to acquire its stock.c-Net loss, which included restructuring charges of $ 34,155,000 in the quarter and $ 43,169,000 in the year. The periods were also after charges of $ 135,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 2,890,000, or 24 cents a share, in the year, from adjustments in accounting.(Loss)

title: Yesterday in Washington
description: THE TAX CUT: The House Ways and Means Committee approved the Republicans' tax-cut bill, a cornerstone of their Contract With America, which would lower taxes by almost $200 billion over the next five years. But the action was tempered by the first signs of trouble in the Republicans' promise to compensate for the tax cuts by cutting spending. Party leaders had to concede that they were hard pressed to win support for even a first modest round of reductions. Republicans have insisted that they would pay for the tax cuts with equivalent reductions in spending so the deficit would not be worsened; they have not specified how they would do so. LOBBYING FOR THE ARTS: The country singer Garth Brooks was among 350 musicians, actors, artists and cultural leaders who lobbied in the Capitol to divert Congress from its determination to cut Federal subsidies to the arts. Arts Advocacy Day was sponsored by the nonprofit American Council for the Arts and financed by corporate donations. The council has conducted similar annual expeditions over the last 14 years, usually with some assurance that a Democratic-run Congress would protect both its interests and its financing. That changed when the last election swept fiscal and social conservatives into power.

title: Business Travel; As U.S. hotel companies rush to get ready to enter Cuba, Days Inns appears to be a step ahead.
description: AMERICAN hotel companies have made no secret of their intention to expand into Cuba if and when Washington lifts its economic embargo, but the company that appears positioned to move the quickest boasts neither luxury resorts nor a reputation as a hotel for business travelers. It is Days Inns of America Inc., a chain of 1,600 economy hotels.

title: F.A.A. Orders Checks of Rudder on 737's
description: Following reports that two particular rudder power control units had malfunctioned, the Federal Aviation Administration yesterday ordered all airlines that use Boeing 737's to inspect the devices.

title: More Rainfall in California Raises Fears of New Floods
description: A new storm moved into Northern California today, causing fears of more flooding as already swollen lakes and rivers rose to dangerous levels in some areas.

title: Celebrities Take Art's Case to Congress
description: Most days, Garth Brooks is a chart-topping country singer and international celebrity. Today he was a political lobbyist, pounding shoe leather along the Capitol's tiled hallways, trying to argue a suddenly pinchpenny Congress out of its determination to cut Federal subsidies to the arts.

title: Islanders Start Fast, Then Lose in a Hurry
description: The Islanders can only wonder how much worse this season can get.

title: An Irish Judge Fuels Debate Over Abortion
description: The already emotional debate over Ireland's constitutional ban on abortion accelerated today as the man imprisoned in a landmark 1992 case had his sentence reduced.

title: PENSKE BUYING LEASEWAY FOR $200 MILLION
description: The Leaseway Transportation Corporation agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Penske Truck Leasing Company of Reading, Pa., for about $200 million, or $20 a share, in cash. The acquisition, which was approved by the Leaseway board, will create the nation's second-largest supplier of transportation and logistical support to manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers, Ron Hutchison, Leaseway's vice president and treasurer, said. Shares of Leaseway, which is based in Cleveland, soared $6.78 to $19.72 in Nasdaq trading yesterday. Penske's chairman is Roger Penske, the former race car driver who is also chairman of the Detroit Diesel Corporation.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CALIFORNIA ANGELS -- Named Bill Wood consultant and scout.

title: Variations of First Love In Late-1950's Ireland
description: In "Circle of Friends," Minnie Driver gives a lovely performance as unlovely Benny Hogan, a wallflower from a small Irish town. In this sweetly winsome story of first romance, Benny sets her sights on handsome Jack Foley and shows enough spirit to win his heart. One nice thing about "Circle of Friends," both on the screen and in Maeve Binchy's entertaining novel, is that where Jack is concerned, it has no trouble making Benny's near-impossible wishes come true.

title: Nuclear Arms Cleanup Plan Is Impossible, Senators Say
description: The ranking members of the Senate Energy Committee said today that an agreement between the Federal Government and the State of Washington to clean up a nuclear weapons plant was impossible to carry out and that Congress should rewrite the laws concerning such projects.

title: C.I.A. Report Misleads on Bosnia War Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Twelve years after winning the Nobel Peace Prize for his struggles for workers' rights, President LECH WALESA of Poland finally got to Norway yesterday to start a three-day visit, The Associated Press reported. His wife, DANUTA, picked up the award for him at ceremonies in Oslo in 1983. He didn't make the trip because he feared that the Communist regime then in control of Poland would bar him from returning. NADINE BROZAN

title: Robert Freeman, 82, Ex-C.I.A. Official
description: Robert Belmont Freeman, a retired official of the Central Intelligence Agency, died on March 5 at his home in Scientists Cliffs, Md. He was 82 and also had a residence in Arlington, Va.

title: Canadian's Debut in 'Figaro'
description: The New York City Opera's current production of "The Marriage of Figaro" is unremarkable but more than adequate; it lets the opera speak for itself. Carl Toms's sets and costumes tend toward plainness, allowing room for the singers to move and the audience to imagine. The only serious complaint one could make is that the colors are more drab than bright; Hans Sondheimer's generally dim lighting may be to blame.

title: N.L.R.B. Cites Baseball's Owners Again
description: For the third time in three months, the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board said he has found reason to issue a complaint against baseball's club owners, charging them with violating labor laws. For at least the second time, the owners, nevertheless, claimed victory.

title: An Expanded Business Day
description: In today's issue of Business Day, reporters take a hard look behind the scenes at the discount giant, Kmart, where a tumbling stock price and a split on the board threaten the future of the discount retailing chain's chief executive, Joseph E. Antonini.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17 CONOCO DROPS IRAN DEAL Conoco will not proceed with its agreement to develop two offshore oilfields for Iran after the White House announced that President Clinton would issue a directive barring all such transactions. A1 CARLOS SALINAS'S SIDE Carlos Salinas, the Mexican ex-President said to have been forced into exile by his successor, has popped up in New York, eager to dismiss that version of events. A1

title: Pressure Cooking Without the Terror
description: NO matter that Julia Child, Chuck Williams and other cooking luminaries love their pressure cookers. No matter that sales of the machine are rising and that curious cooks are finding new uses for an old concept. Lorna Sass, the pressure cooker's missionary, zealot and indefatigable promoter, still gets depressed.

title: Accounts
description: * Lotto World Inc., Naples, Fla., to Emmerling Post, New York, to introduce nationally Lotto World magazine. The billings were estimated at $2 million the first year and $4 million the second year. * Federal National Mortgage Corp., better known as Fannie Mae, Washington, to Sidall, Matus & Coughter, Richmond, to handle its business-to-business advertising, previously handled by McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C. The billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: Procter & Gamble Chooses Its New Chief
description: Ending months of speculation about Procter & Gamble's corporate succession, the company's board yesterday named John E. Pepper, 56, a gentlemanly consensus-builder who is a 32-year veteran of the company, to be chairman and chief executive beginning July 1. He will succeed Edwin L. Artzt, Procter's autocratic leader for the last five years, whose departure had been expected.

title: Christopher Persuades Syria and Israel to Resume Direct Talks
description: Syria agreed today to meet face to face with Israel once again in a drive to find a formula for peace, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said in Damascus.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNITED STATES SHOE CORP., Cincinnati, will eliminate about 40 positions and consolidate its footwear division, Selby & Co., to save about $4 million a year.

title: Market Place; Heady days for drug makers, especially so at SmithKline.
description: THE big drug companies are pleasing investors again, after singing the blues for nearly three years. Sales and profits are stronger at most companies, but the improved results are especially sweet for SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the British-American company based in London that is emerging from difficult times.

title: Pamida Holdings Corp.(PAM,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Net loss, and the year included an extraordinary charge of $ 4,943,000, or 99 cents a share, on loss from the early extinguishment of debt.(Loss)

title: Solomon Seidman, Bridge Official, 85
description: Solomon Seidman, a prominent official in tournament bridge, died on March 5 at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 85.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday with statistics about New York City services from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's annual Management Report overstated the number of slashing incidents in the city's jails. In 1993 there were 0.27 slashings per 100 inmates, not 27 slashings; in 1994 there were 0.52, not 52.

title: Ross Stores Inc.(ROST,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included income of about $ 6.2 million, or 25 cents a share, from insurance proceeds for a business interruption claim resulting from the roof collapse at the company's distribution center in Carlisle, Pa., in March 1994.

title: AT WORK WITH: Alexander C. Sanger; In His Grandmother's Footsteps
description: WHEN her son Grant had six children, Margaret Sanger should not have been surprised. In the annals of passive aggression, it is a classic.

title: Boeing Is Victor In S.A.S. Deal With a Value Of $1.16 Billion
description: In a big victory for the Boeing Company and a serious setback for the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the Scandinavian Airlines System said today that it would purchase 35 new Boeing 737 jetliners, valued at $1.16 billion, and take options on another 35 planes.

title: Man in the News: Norman Earl Thagard; The Space Comrade From Florida
description: Norman E. Thagard was trained to kill Communists. In the Marine Corps, he labored in one of the hottest theaters of the cold war, flying 163 combat missions in Vietnam, winning awards for bravery and succeeding in coming home alive to his family.

title: Hillary Clinton Asks U.N. to Do More for Women
description: Today, for the second time in a week, Hillary Rodham Clinton came to speak to a United Nations gathering, this time about the condition of women's lives within this organization as much as in the world at large.

title: International Briefs; Saatchi Profit Rises
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 69 percent in 1994, despite what the company called "very mixed trading." Pretax profits totaled $:32.4 million ($51.3 million), exceeding analysts' expectations. The company, which owns Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide and Bates Worldwide, said sales from continuing operations dropped 4 percent, to $:775.4 million.

title: G.O.P. Chief Resigns Post Under Pressure
description: The longtime chairman of the Westchester County Republican Party is resigning under pressure from Gov. George E. Pataki and his Republican allies in the county.

title: Mitchell Energy & Development Corp.(MND.A,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included $ 52.6 million in pretax gains on major energy asset sales, partly offset by $ 36.9 million in pretax restructuring costs and asset write-downs. The net after-tax effect of the items was a gain of $ 8.6 million.c-Net lossd-Included extraordinary charge of $ 5,426,000, or 1o cents a share, in the quarter and 11 cents a share, in the year, on loss from early retirement of debt. The year also included a $ 6.6 million deferred tax charge related to the August 1993 increase in the federal corporate income tax rate.(Loss)The year-ago periods were restated to reflect an accounting change to successful effects from the full-cost method.

title:
DIALOGUE: The Environment vs. Property Rights;
It's My Land, Isn't It?
description: Liberals have dismissed the Contract With America's property rights reforms as an anti-environmental crusade sponsored by large corporations seeking to despoil the land. But as Democrats prepare to try to derail the Republican proposals, they would do well to remember that property rights laws affect real people -- the sort that reduced them to a Congressional minority in November and may toss them out of the White House in 1996.

title: Samuel J. Meer, 75; Taught Psychologists
description: Samuel J. Meer, a psychologist who helped train school psychologists to recognize learning disabilities, died on March 7 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 75 and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Britain Pulling 400 Troops Out of Ulster, Citing Cease-Fire
description: In a move that could speed up peace talks in Northern Ireland, Britain announced today that it is withdrawing a regiment of 400 men, the largest reduction of British troops in the province in a decade.

title: KELLOGG TO SPEND $325 MILLION ON 1995 STOCK BUYBACKS
description: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that it expected to spend $325.4 million on stock buybacks this year. Last year the cereal maker, based in Battle Creek, Mich., spent $327.3 million to buy back about 6.2 million of its common shares, according to the company's latest annual report issued yesterday. Kellogg shares rose $1.125 yesterday, to $58, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: OIL CONCERN ENDS A DEAL WITH IRAN AS PRESIDENT ACTS
description: A big American oil company said today that it would not proceed with its agreement to develop two large offshore oilfields for Iran after the White House announced that President Clinton would issue a directive barring all such transactions.

title: Salinas, in New York, Denies Being Asked to Quit Mexico
description: Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the former President of Mexico who was said to have been forced into virtual exile over the weekend by his successor, popped up on Manhattan's East Side yesterday, eager to dismiss that version of events.

title: Home, Sweet Home
description: To The Living Section:

title: Personal Health; Ignoring an easy way to cut risks of crib death.
description: IN a letter published recently in The New York Times, a distressed grandmother complained that she had been banished from baby-sitting for her 6-week-old grandson after the parents caught her putting the baby to sleep on his stomach.

title: Broad Group Visits President On Affirmative Action's Future
description: Hoping for help in defusing a political bomb, President Clinton summoned a bipartisan, interracial group of civil rights leaders and academics to the White House on Monday night, part of the Administration's review of Federal affirmative action programs in the face of Republican demands to scale them back.

title: Gulls on Approach to Kennedy
description: THE laughing gulls are on their way to their spring and summer roosts at the edge of Kennedy International Airport, and the 18 men who keep the birds away from the runways and the jets are worried.

title: Foreign Affairs; New Mexico
description: Ricarda Martinez, a 60-year-old Mexican peasant living in a tumbledown shack on the edge of Mexico City, says she's never heard of Wall Street and doesn't know anything about dollar-linked peso bonds, George Soros or Merrill Lynch's emerging markets fund. Peeling cactus from her garden, she insists that none of those strange-sounding names could possibly explain what she does know, which is that she can't afford to buy meat anymore, and that "Mexico is now different -- now we are poor."

title: Peter Brook Charts Twists and Turns Of the Human Mind
description: Running a mere 100 minutes and played without an intermission, Peter Brook's hypnotizing new theatrical work, "The Man Who," would seem to be as spare and tightly constructed as his 10-hour "Mahabharata" was winding and discursive. Yet "The Man Who" is no less an epic. It's as vast and mysterious as the human imagination, and as commonplace as the image of a man trying to shave himself, but failing.

title: A Recuperating Irvan Takes Some Fast Laps
description: ERNIE IRVAN got into his race car yesterday for the first time since a near-fatal crash Aug. 20 at Michigan Speedway. He breezed around Darlington (S.C.) Raceway, setting an unofficial course record of 30.26 seconds in his Busch Grand National Thunderbird. Wearing a patch on his left eye, he ran a four-lap set on the 1.366-mile oval that produced a turn of 162.510 miles per hour. That bettered the mark of 161.342 m.p.h. set in September. (AP)

title: Angelica Corp.(AGL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Company-Backed Juice Study Sets Off a Dispute on Ethics
description: A RELATIVELY minor study published this month in a pediatrics journal has touched off a major marketing campaign and a dispute over the role of corporations in sponsoring scientific studies.

title: Oshkosh B'Gosh Inc.(GOSHA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a $ 7.1 million, or 49 cents a share, restructuring charge, in the quarter and year.(Loss)

title: Some States Trying to Stop Gay Marriages Before They Start
description: A battle over the very definition of marriage, which began two years ago in Hawaii, is spreading through Western states as lawmakers hasten to foreclose any possible legalization of homosexual matrimony.

title: A Study Calls Household Materials Especially Toxic
description: Chemicals found in everyday products like carpeting and particleboard may pose greater long-term environmental hazards than industrial chemical wastes, a study conducted for the influential environmental group Inform has concluded.

title: Tito Puente Takes His Place On His Music's Time Line
description: "The Latin Tinge: Jazz Music and the Influence of Latin Rhythms," a concert featuring the music of Tito Puente presented by Jazz at Lincoln Center, was a fine idea. Mr. Puente, a percussionist, band leader, composer and arranger, recorded an extraordinary series of performances during the 1950's and 60's. A legacy of synthesists like Dizzy Gillespie, Machito, Mario Bauza and others, the music drew from jazz's big bands and from Afro-Cuba's disciplined percussion sections, and it was visionary.

title: Life Re Corp.(LRE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included an investment loss of $ 1,292,000 in the quarter and an investment gain of $ 89,000 in the year. Year-ago quarter included an investment loss of $ 1,655,000 and the year included an investment gain of $ 20,957,000.

title: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.(GAP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Included charge of $ 2 million, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and a charge of $ 27 million, or 71 cents a share, in the year, for Canadian employee buy-out costs. The year also included $ 160 million, or $ 4.19 a share, for nonrecurring write-off of goodwill and certain long-lived assets, a provision for store closings and a net reduction in deferred tax assets. The year also included charge of $ 4,950,000, or 13 cents a share, from change in accounting for postretirement benefits.c-Net loss, which included a charge of $ 17,153,000, or 45 cents a share, from Canadian employee buy-out costs.d-Net income, and included charge of $ 17,153,000, or 45 cents a share, from Canadian employee buy-out costs.(Loss)

title: Coach of 'the Mount' Is the Man of the Hour
description: The outdoor basketball hoops on the Mount St. Mary's College campus here have been uprooted. Poles with plywood backboards and rusty rims lie on their sides, strewn about and awaiting replacements.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp.(PVH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $ 7 million related to the consolidation and realignment of certain managerial and administrative functions associated with the company's retail and wholesale apparel divisions, as well as the closing and conversion of existing private label retail stores. Both periods also included a gain of $ 4.1 million for a tax adjustment representing a reversal of deferred tax reserves relating, in part, to the 1987 acquisition of G.H. Bass.c-Included extraordinary charge of $ 11,394,000, or 42 cents a share, on loss from debt refinancing, in the quarter and year.

title: February Retail Sales Had Surprising Slide
description: The Government reported today that retail sales fell five-tenths of 1 percent in February, a surprising decline that was the first in almost a year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Striking baseball players still striking it rich on Madison Avenue.
description: THE strike against Major League Baseball is keeping familiar players from spring training. And there doesn't seem to be much likelihood that they will be in uniform come Opening Day.

title: Investigator Seeks Control of Javits Center Hiring
description: A special investigator is seeking court permission to take control of hiring for the lucrative carpenters' jobs at the Jacobs K. Javits Convention Center and accusing the president of the carpenters' union of allowing organized crime to persist at the center.

title: Judges Urge Easing of Nynex Regulations
description: Endorsing a drastic loosening of telephone regulations in New York, two administrative law judges recommended yesterday that the state's Public Service Commission free the Nynex Corporation to earn unregulated profits in return for a reduction in local phone rates.

title: Franciszek Gajowniczek Dead; Priest Died for Him at Auschwitz
description: Franciszek Gajowniczek, the Polish army sergeant whose life was spared when a Franciscan monk took his death sentence at Auschwitz 53 years ago, died on Monday in the Polish city of Brzeg. He was 94.

title: A Dickens Revival in Comparable Times
description: The word is Dickensian. Laden with overtones of social inequities, it has resurfaced with a vengeance in the last decade or so as homeless people drifted onto the nation's streets and census reports confirmed that the rich were indeed getting richer and the poor poorer. The time for a Charles Dickens revival is obviously ripe, and television, long committed to the obvious, is clearly eager to play its part.

title: Tempest in the Kitchen
description: SOME of the most highly praised and expensive restaurants in New York City, including Lespinasse in the St. Regis Hotel, Les Celebrites in the the Essex House Nikko Hotel and Le Regence in the Hotel Plaza-Athenee, lost money last year.

title: Cowens Coming Back?
description: DAVE COWENS, a Hall of Fame center, may make another comeback from retirement and join the San Antonio roster for the playoffs, Spurs Coach BOB HILL says. Cowens, 46, is a Spurs assistant coach. (AP)

title: Judicial Conference Rejects More Secrecy in Civil Court
description: Expressing concern about court secrecy, the judges who make policy for the Federal courts voted today to reject a proposal that would have made the sealing of court records nearly automatic in civil cases as long as the two sides agreed.

title: President of Toyota Ill
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said yesterday that its president, Tatsuro Toyoda, 65, had been hospitalized with high blood pressure and would be away from work until the summer. Toyota said it would be run in the meantime by its chairman, Shoichiro Toyoda, and five executive vice presidents. The company's president, Tatsuro Toyoda, was taken by ambulance to a hospital on Feb. 24, and Toyota had said very little about his prognosis until yesterday. In addition to being president of Toyota, Mr. Toyoda is chairman of the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association.

title: Bella Fishko; Gallery Founder, 81
description: Bella Fishko, an art dealer and founder of the Forum Gallery, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 81.

title: Nets' Defense Is Sound Against a Shaq Attack
description: Two seasons ago, in a forest of National Basketball Association trees, the 7-foot-2 reserve center Dwayne Schintzius was guarding the 7-1 man-child, Shaquille O'Neal. Schintzius played his way onto all the cable sports shows that evening -- with a little help from Shaq.

title: Fixing Charges Leads To Arrest of 3 Players
description: The police arrested three prominent soccer players in Britain today on suspicion of fixing games, plunging the sport into the worst scandal to afflict it in this country in decades.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JACK MILES has tackled an even loftier topic in his new book, "God: A Biography," which will be published next month by Knopf.

title: 4 Arrested After Wild Chase Across Hudson
description: What began as an early-morning traffic check in Harlem turned into a high-speed, bullet-punctuated chase across the George Washington Bridge and into New Jersey yesterday. By the time it was over, four men were in custody and dozens of police officers had felt a career's worth of adrenaline in part of one night's shift.

title: In Wake of Death, Rowland Vows to Help Children in Troubled Families
description: Gov. John G. Rowland said today that Connecticut would be more aggressive in taking children from troubled families. He spoke after the death of a 9-month-old who the police say was sexually assaulted by her mother's boyfriend.

title: G.M. Honored In Reggie Awards
description: A promotion marketing campaign for the Saturn Corporation unit of General Motors, took top honors yesterday at the Promotion Marketing Association of America's 12th annual Reggie Awards ceremony in Chicago.

title: Resorts Intl.(RT,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gains of $ 4,008,000, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 190,008,000, or $ 5.81 a share, in the year, from repayment of debt under reorganization plan. The year also included a $ 72.5 million loss on the sale of the company's Paradise Island operations and a $ 20.5 million write-down of its nonoperating real estate holdings in Atlantic City, N.J.c-Net loss(Loss)Resorts International said that results included its Paradise Island operations, which were disposed of in May 1994, for the entire year 1993 and for the first four months of 1994.

title: Rams Still Waiting For N.F.L. Approval
description: The National Football League owners discussed the Los Angeles Rams' proposed moved to St. Louis for more five hours today without reaching a decision. Their annual meeting will resume on Wednesday, and the owners indicated that a vote might not be taken until Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: A brief announcement in some copies of Business Day yesterday about the omission of the foreign stocks table misidentified the table's source. It is Bloomberg Financial Markets, not Tribune Media Services.

title: Yale Returns $20 Million to an Unhappy Patron
description: Four years after giving $20 million to Yale University to expand its Western civilization curriculum, Lee M. Bass, a billionaire alumnus, has requested that the money be returned because Yale never instituted the courses.

title: A Better Plan for X-Rated Shops
description: Showing refreshing flexibility, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has reached a reasonable agreement with the New York City Council on strict zoning rules to limit the spread of X-rated video stores and topless bars in midtown Manhattan and residential neighborhoods like Chelsea and Forest Hills, Queens.

title: A Subway Rider, 50, Disarms And Subdues Two Attackers
description: A Brooklyn man fought off two teen-agers inside a subway car early yesterday, disarming one of the youths, then slashing both with their own weapon, a box cutter, the police said.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP. (FDX,N)
description: The Federal Express Corporation said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter profit more than doubled, exceeding analyst expectations, on improved international business.

title: The Right Way to Help Pakistan
description: Violence is running out of control in Pakistan's port city of Karachi. More than 1,000 Pakistani lives have been lost in a year of disorder. Last week two American consular employees were killed and a third wounded when their van was ambushed on the city's main thoroughfare.

title: Floods' Effect on Food Prices
description: THIS week's flooding in California will affect the price of produce that consumers buy in coming weeks, but the increases may be only short term and may not go into effect in all stores immediately.

title: Eating Well; Crackle, Pop, Compare
description: A MAN picked up a box of cereal in a supermarket recently, put it down and picked up another, then another and another, returning each of them to the shelf. Before turning away, he shook his head and said to no one in particular, "So expensive!"

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Conoco Drops Iran Pact As U.S. Moves to Block Deal

title: 'Workforce' vs. Welfare
description: ORGANIZATION

title:
DIALOGUE: The Environment vs. Property Rights;
Want a Toxic Dump Next Door?
description: As a homeowner and real estate developer, I believe in landowners' rights and in preserving property values.

title: Flood May Carry Away Immigrants' Farm Jobs
description: Driven from their trailers by the same flood waters that lay brown and still over the Salinas Valley's fertile strawberry and lettuce fields, immigrant farm workers, desperate for jobs, faced the prospect today of having to join a new migration.

title: Lemaire's Lethargic Troops Get A Victory
description: Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire left Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight not sure what to do with his team after another low-energy performance. Luckily for the Devils, tonight's game was against the Ottawa Senators, the worst team in the National Hockey League, and the Devils were able to salvage a 4-2 victory while on cruise control.

title: Time Warner and Turner Talks Said to Hit Snags
description: Talks over the proposed sale of Time Warner Inc.'s 19.4 percent stake in Turner Broadcasting to Turner ran into snags yesterday, people close to the discussions said.

title: Moe Ginsburg Narrows Review
description: Moe Ginsburg, Men's Better Clothing Inc., in New York, said yesterday that it had narrowed the review on the creative portion of its account to 4 agencies from 31. The account, with billings estimated at $1 million, had been at Lipman, Richmond, Greene in New York for the last seven years until that agency was dismissed early last month. Martin Weissberg, president of the Media and Marketing Group in Boca Raton, Fla., which handles the media portion of the account and is advising the review, identified the finalists, all based in New York, as Beaver Reitzfeld Inc., Calderhead & Phin, Castle Underwood and Follis Advertising Inc. A decision is expected by April 1, he added.

title: Bates Worldwide To Cut 150 Positions
description: Less than a month after the loss of its important Mars Inc. account, with billings estimated at $400 million, Bates Worldwide is laying off 3 percent, or about 150, of its 5,000 employees worldwide.

title: Wine Talk
description: WITH uncharacteristic hubris, a prominent Bordeaux chateau owner predicted in the late 1980's that henceforth there would be no more bad vintages of Bordeaux wine. Ego is a persistent Bordeaux problem; hubris is not. Bordeaux was part of England for 300 years, and the Bordelais pride themselves as much for their sang-froid as for their Savile Row suits.

title: Missing a Rare Ingredient? Here's How to Find a Substitute
description: ALTHOUGH some supermarkets manage to keep up with the most voracious appetites for new or unusual products, many people who want to make an Indian curry or fragrant Thai soup face the daunting task of tracking down ingredients.

title: Burglaries Show Big Decline in New York City
description: Police Officer Roger Smith remembers when he began to lift fingerprints in downtown Brooklyn and surrounding neighborhoods in 1986: He would typically face an urgent bunch of 20 or more fresh burglary cases after his weekend off. "I'd run around like a chicken without a head," he recalled.

title: At Towing Trial, a Hook Shot
description: The defense got its chance yesterday to go after a witness against two Councilmen on trial for bribery, portraying him as a man who betrayed their trust and exaggerated his political connections while skimming funds from his partners in a towing company seeking a city contract.

title: ING CREATES NEW MANAGEMENT STRUCTURE FOR BARINGS
description: The ING Group, which acquired the failed British investment bank Barings P.L.C. earlier this month, said yesterday that it had created a new management structure for Barings. It gives only a limited role to Peter Baring, who had been the investment bank's chairman, and Peter Norris, who had headed the securities division and had ultimate authority over the Singapore futures-trading operation. Enormous losses in Singapore caused the collapse of Barings. Mr. Baring will be one of six members of a committee that will advise ING executives who will make up the board of Baring Holding Company Ltd., as the parent company will now be known. ING said Mr. Baring's new role reflected his desire, announced before the firm's collapse, to retire later this year. Mr. Norris will serve as an adviser to the management committee.

title: A Studio Breathes, Idea by Idea by Idea
description: ADAM WEITSMAN, 26, may be noblesse in the antiques world. But in the world of interior design, he is a novice.

title: To Thy House Be True
description: SIR EDWARD COKE, a jurist in 17th-century England, is credited with saying, "For a man's house is his castle." An exhibition at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington is debating the point.

title: YOUNKERS REJECTS NEW TAKEOVER BID FROM CARSON PIRIE
description: The board of Younkers Inc. rejected a sweetened takeover bid from Carson Pirie Scott & Company yesterday, calling it "grossly inadequate." Carson, based in Milwaukee, had hoped to end the five-month struggle between the two retailers last week by raising its hostile bid for Younkers to $170 million, or $19 a share, from $152 million, or $17 a share. But Younkers, a department store company based in Des Moines, said its strong fourth-quarter results showed that it was worth more than Carson has offered. Shares of Younkers fell 29.6875 cents, to $17.9531, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Columbia Gas Picks Chairman
description: Columbia Gas System Inc., which has been operating under Chapter 11 protection since July 1991, named Oliver G. Richard 3d, 42, chairman, chief executive and president today, effective April 28.

title: About Churches, Souls And Show-Biz Methods
description: The title of tonight's ABC report, "In the Name of God," is flexible enough to allow for at least two interpretations. Is Peter Jennings out to show what growing numbers of evangelical churches are doing in God's name; or is he asking, what in God's name are they doing?

title: INSIDE
description: The School Door as Turnstile

title: Paychex Inc.(PAYX,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
The Pipes, The Pipes
description: They practice in basements, backyards and parks. As the bagpipes resonate, the din of sirens and scanners fades from their minds, and they feel a fleeting sense of calm.

title: Coleman's Magic Show Spellbinding
description: They tried to play Hack-a-Shaq tonight, but Shaquille O'Neal grew tired of this game of push, foul and whack. He began to dominate, and the Nets were forced to depend on something more substantial, something with teeth and resolve.

title: Bridge
description: Each year, the International Bridge Press Association organizes the Bols Tip competition, sponsored by the Dutch liqueur manufacturer. Eight invited experts submit articles based on a useful piece of advice, and the journalists vote on their comparative merit.

title: John Kearney, 82, Longtime Counsel To Brooklyn Diocese
description: John H. Kearney, who was counsel to the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn for more than 50 years, died on Saturday at New York Medical Center. He was 82.

title: SEAGRAM CO. (VO,N)
description: The Seagram Company said yesterday that its earnings in the fiscal fourth quarter rose 30 percent, as a result of higher profit at Du Pont, of which it owns 24 percent, and gains at its wine and spirits group.

title: A Bank Goes to Great Lengths to Move Shares Up
description: In an unusual attempt to push up its stock price, California Federal Bank plans to issue a security that would give its shareholders 25 percent of any cash award it might receive in its pending lawsuit against the Federal Government.

title: Resorts Intl.(RT,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gains of $ 4,008,000, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 190,008,000, or $ 5.81 a share, in the year, from repayment of debt under reorganization plan. The year also included a $ 72.5 million loss on the sale of the company's Paradise Island operations and a $ 20.5 million write-down of its nonoperating real estate holdings in Atlantic City, N.J.c-Net loss(Loss)Resorts International said that results included its Paradise Island operations, which were disposed of in May 1994, for the entire year 1993 and for the first four months of 1994.

title: Top Orange County Official Raises Specter of Tax Increase
description: Orange County's chief executive violated an unofficial taboo today by becoming the first senior official to say what many people had long believed: the county has no hope of climbing out of bankruptcy and paying off its creditors without a prompt tax increase.

title: 3 Officers Accused of Making 'Collars for Dollars' Go on Trial
description: A rogue band of police officers in a Brooklyn precinct relentlessly stole cash, drugs and guns from suspects, made false arrests to gain overtime and counted on a "blue wall of silence" to protect them, a Federal prosecutor charged yesterday as three of the accused officers went on trial.

title: Berlitz Intl.(BTZ,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss(Loss)Full-year 1993 is not comparable since company merged with Fukutake Publishing during period. For the post-merger period from Feb. 1, 1993, to Dec. 31, 1993, company reported a loss of $ 3.5 million, or 35 cents a share, on revenues of $ 252.1 million and 10,031,000 outstanding shares.Corrected from Thursday, March 9, editions.

title: Profit Up 6.6% At French Bank
description: Societe Generale, France's third-largest commercial bank, had a 6.6 percent increase in net profit last year to 3.85 billion French francs ($770 million) from 3.61 billion francs in 1993.

title: Austerity and Rates of 92% Fail to Perk Up the Peso
description: A tough new economic plan and interest rates of more than 90 percent were not enough to rekindle much confidence in Mexico today as the peso tumbled an additional 5 percent and investors expressed worry that the country's problems would continue to worsen.

title: Ross Stores Inc.(ROST,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included income of about $ 6.2 million, or 25 cents a share, from insurance proceeds for a business interruption claim resulting from the roof collapse at the company's distribution center in Carlisle, Pa., in March 1994.

title: Thermo Instrument Systems Inc.(THI,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is a public unit of Thermo Electron Corp.

title: Into the Middle, Where There's Gravity
description: Bang on a Can's march from the fringes into the mainstream concert world must be inspiring for young avant-garde musicians, but its transformation from a ramshackle, freespirited festival into a concert series at Lincoln Center has meant losses as well as gains. The series, which opened on Monday evening at the Walter Reade Theater, is no longer a forum for new music ensembles of all stripes, as it was during its early years. Now the organization has a house band, the Bang on a Can All-Stars, who play its concerts and make recordings. Only the annual marathon (this year's is on May 21 at Alice Tully Hall) is the kind of omnibus offering that won Bang on a Can attention when it started nine years ago.

title: OfficeMax Inc.(OMX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 21
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma. The company went public Nov. 1, 1994.

title: Ballet Drawn From Danza
description: Ballets de San Juan, Puerto Rico's oldest ballet troupe, romped into town for a rare New York appearance on Saturday night and established itself as a company of special charm and warmth. Part of that warmth had to do with where the group performed. The Pregones Theater at the new Hostos College complex in the South Bronx, an accessible and comfortable new performing space, was packed with cheering dancers, balletomanes and families.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; 4 Arrested in Sales of Heroin
description: A gang that sold heroin round the clock here, 50 feet from an elementary school, was dismantled yesterday, Federal authorities said. In announcing the arrests of four suspects, United States Attorney Faith S. Hochberg said, "This drug gang operated more efficiently than any fast-food store." Four other people remain at large, she said.

title: Kirby Corp.(KEX,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Senate to Begin Hearings on Operation of Javits Center
description: At a conference on the city's economy last month, Jonathan M. Tisch, president and chief executive officer of Loews Hotels, appealed to public officials and private executives to focus on cleaning up the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Trump Collateral Is Allowed
description: Donald J. Trump, facing a March 31 deadline for a $60 million payment to regain control of a hotel that bears his name, got permission from the Casino Control Commission yesterday to use his management-services agreement at another Trump business as collateral for a loan.

title: Pamida Holdings Corp.(PAM,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Net loss, and the year included an extraordinary charge of $ 4,943,000, or 99 cents a share, on loss from the early extinguishment of debt.(Loss)

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp.(PVH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $ 7 million related to the consolidation and realignment of certain managerial and administrative functions associated with the company's retail and wholesale apparel divisions, as well as the closing and conversion of existing private label retail stores. Both periods also included a gain of $ 4.1 million for a tax adjustment representing a reversal of deferred tax reserves relating, in part, to the 1987 acquisition of G.H. Bass.c-Included extraordinary charge of $ 11,394,000, or 42 cents a share, on loss from debt refinancing, in the quarter and year.

title: Taking the Pentium For a Test Drive
description: COMPUTERS powered by the fast chips known as 486's provide excellent performance for almost all software used by families. Those using the next generation, the more expensive Pentium chips, promise even better performance.

title: Baker (J.) Inc.(JBAK,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
E.M.S. Erred In a Dispute, Report Finds
description: Emergency Medical Service personnel made a long series of blunders in treating a pregnant Queens woman last year, from failing to take her vital signs to failing to note that she was bleeding, and wasted crucial minutes as her baby bled to death, according to a city investigators' report issued yesterday.

title: Sports Authority Inc.(TSA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 22
description: Share earnings are reported pro forma, reflecting the fact that Sports Authority went public in November 1994.

title: Journal; Dropping the N-Bomb
description: Perhaps not since Ted Danson donned blackface to honor Whoopi Goldberg at the Friars Club has a white man flogged the word "nigger" as publicly as F. Lee Bailey did this week. Mr. Bailey, whose acting skills make Mr. Danson look like an amateur, all but exulted in bellowing out the word for a national TV audience, as if he were looking forward to capping what seems to be a waning legal career by playing the role of Bull Connor in a prequel to "Mississippi Burning."

title: Bonnie Raitt in a Self-Revealing Mood
description: In a change of pace from its normal run of cautionary dramas for young audiences, the "ABC After school Special" series turns this afternoon to a talk-show format. Whoopi Goldberg is the interviewer on "Bonnie Raitt Has Something to Talk About."

title: Management Shifts At Martin Agency
description: The Martin Agency in Richmond said yesterday that it would make several changes in top management, one effect of which would be to give more autonomy to a new unit that specializes in interactive marketing.

title: A Snip Here, A Topiary There
description: WHEN most people look at an unruly shrub, they see only a mass of green. Asher Eden, a gardener who specializes in topiaries, envisions a landscape of shapes -- circles, rectangles, triangles.

title: N.F.L. Owners Reject Rams' Bid to Move To St. Louis
description: In a fragmented scene that was the order of the day and possibly a hint of the future, the National Football League owners today overwhelmingly rejected the Los Angeles Rams' bid to move to St. Louis. Paul Tagliabue, the N.F.L. commissioner, announced the vote as 21 against, 3 for and 6 abstaining.

title: Cornell Dorms Based on Race Are the Focus Of an Inquiry
description: Acting on a complaint from a Manhattan-based civil rights organization, the State Department of Education is investigating whether race-based dormitories for black, Hispanic and American Indian students at Cornell University violate state laws.

title: Delusions and Frustrations of the Sexual Whirl
description: No matter what the papers say about a new age of celibacy, life as a sexual square dance continues in America, at least on its stages and screens. It seems telling that "La Ronde" by Arthur Schniztler, which was the mother of the romantic daisy-chain drama, has been adapted into both a film and a musical in the last several years. And for those who find real life a barren field for gossip, there are always partner-switching soap operas on television.

title: At New York Public Hospitals, Quality of Care Keeps Improving
description: To the Editor:

title: Education Transfers, and Stops; Public Schools Are Struggling With High Student Turnover
description: It is March, and Marie Pompeo-Melone, the nurse at Public School 8, is still registering new students -- 25 in the first eight days of the month alone.

title: An Expanded Business Day
description: Worried about the growth of disability benefits, many states are rewriting laww to make it tougher to claim them. Today Business Day examines the results: good news for insurers, who are finally making a profit on the business, but concerns about the arbitrary treament of workers.

title: Essay; The Greatest Auction Ever
description: They all laughed at the economist Milton Friedman when he suggested a generation ago that the Federal Government auction off broadcast licenses, instead of giving them away to political favorites.

title: It's Raining Cats and Shoes
description: MOST illustrators put their designs on paper; some also put them on umbrellas. Victoria Roberts's umbrellas (left) are printed with leaping cats. Philippe Weisbecker's (above) are printed with shoes -- high-heel and low-heel, pointy-toe and turned-up-toe -- with a boot for a handle. Both are made by Stormy Weather Umbrellas and are $49.95 to $64 (depending on the handle) at the Whitney Museum's Store Next Door, 943 Madison Avenue (75th Street.)

title: Fire at the Four Seasons: Everyone Who's In Is Out
description: For the movers and shakers who arrived to have lunch as usual yesterday at the elegant Four Seasons, yesterday was decidedly unusual.

title: Garden Is Interested in Bowe-Tyson Bout
description: Rock Newman may propose it and proclaim it. He may scream about the historical logic behind two Brooklyn homeboys fighting at boxing's former mecca.

title: AMR Overhauls Top Tier, Naming Likely Crandall Heir
description: The parent company of American Airlines announced an overhaul of management yesterday that includes sharp job cuts and the naming of an heir apparent to Robert L. Crandall, the chairman and chief executive.

title: Even for Top-Seeded Teams, There's Still Much to Prove
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association begins its first 64-team women's tournament Thursday night with the four top-seeded teams on a mission.

title: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.(GAP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Included charge of $ 2 million, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and a charge of $ 27 million, or 71 cents a share, in the year, for Canadian employee buy-out costs. The year also included $ 160 million, or $ 4.19 a share, for nonrecurring write-off of goodwill and certain long-lived assets, a provision for store closings and a net reduction in deferred tax assets. The year also included charge of $ 4,950,000, or 13 cents a share, from change in accounting for postretirement benefits.c-Net loss, which included a charge of $ 17,153,000, or 45 cents a share, from Canadian employee buy-out costs.d-Net income, and included charge of $ 17,153,000, or 45 cents a share, from Canadian employee buy-out costs.(Loss)

title: Dollar Falls Sharply Despite U.S. Growth
description: The dollar fell sharply yesterday to near-record lows against the Japanese yen and the German mark, despite signs of robust growth in the American economy that could lead to higher interest rates. Still, the stock and bond markets largely shrugged off the fall in the dollar.

title: McCormick & Co.  (MCCRK,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Farm Aid to Chicago? Miami? Study Hits an Inviting Target
description: Marco Island, Fla., hardly seems an obvious destination for checks under the Agriculture Department's farm programs. It is, after all, one of South Florida's most exclusive vacation paradises, renowned for its golf courses, beaches and expansive homes.

title: Corrections
