description: An article on March 8 about House passage of legislation to reduce the number of lawsuits brought in Federal courts misidentified the section of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing sanctions on lawyers for frivolous lawsuits. The section is Rule 11, not Chapter 11.

title: For UConn, Memories of '94 Reverse
description: Life does not take place 40 minutes at a time. It is just measured that way this month. Two time zones from home, the Connecticut Huskies have transformed the factors that did not develop this time last year into the tasks that must be done this month.

title: Sponsorship Moves By BMW and Coke
description: Two marketers are getting a head start on promoting their sponsorships of the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta.

title: I.R.A. Backer Leaves Shadows for the Crystal Chandeliers
description: Gerry Adams's fever had hit 102, and a savage cough wracked his body. And so shortly after dawn, he sat slumped in the back seat of a modest sedan on his way through a faint but gathering light to the Albany County airport.

title: Separation Anxiety for Home of Bullets and Capitals
description: Since 1973, this Washington suburb has been known nationally as a dateline on the sports pages, the town that Charles Barkley and Wayne Gretzky pass through when their teams play Washington.

title: COMPANY NEWS BROOKLYN UNION GAS CO., the natural gas utility company, said its Pennunion Energy Services gas-marketing venture with Pennzoil Co., Houston, would begin full-scale operations on April 1.
description: SBS ENGINEERING INC., Albuquerque, N.M., will shut down or sell its flight-simulation division because of possible cuts in military spending and delays in overseas contract awards.

title: Ringling Brothers finds just coming to town isn't enough any more.
description: ALL the hoopla, ballyhoo and bunkum surrounding the 125th anniversary year of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus has obscured two marketing facts: The company will spend more on advertising this year -- $25 million -- than ever. And "the Greatest Show on Earth" is introducing the first national advertising campaign in its history.

title: LEHMAN BROTHERS FACES LAWSUIT FROM CHINESE COMPANY
description: A Chinese company sued Lehman Brothers Inc. yesterday after Lehman asserted that the company had failed to repay millions of dollars in trading losses. The China International United Petroleum and Chemicals Company, which is responding to a lawsuit filed earlier by Lehman, is seeking $58 million in damages. Unipec maintains that Lehman made risky foreign exchange trades that cost the company $14 million, or more than 13 times its annual income. Unipec maintains that the trades were unauthorized. Lehman, which said the trades were authorized by the president of Unipec, called the lawsuit "simply a smokescreen to renege upon their obligations." In a similar breach-of-contract case, Lehman was countersued last week by the Minmetals International Nonferrous Metals Trading Company for $128 million.

title: 2 Former Officials Of United Way Sued
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco of New York filed suit yesterday to try to recover more than $480,000 that he says two former executives at United Way of America took from the charity to finance a luxurious life style, trips and gifts.

title: Sahara Voting Drive Tests U.N. Resources
description: To the Editor: Your March 5 news article on Morocco's involvement in Western Sahara paints an inaccurate picture of the United Nations mission for the referendum in Western Sahara.

title: Edward V. Roberts, 56, Champion of the Disabled
description: Edward V. Roberts, a quadriplegic who helped redefine how Americans view the physically handicapped, died on Tuesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 56.

title: Berlin Journal; The Wall Is Back as a Movie (and Still a Divider)
description: More than five years after the Berlin wall was breached by ecstatic East Germans, the first major feature film about the wall is helping Berliners confront its emotional legacy.

title: Learning From Two Masters
description: Old-style patronage may be only a memory in the art world, but as the fall fashion shows began here this week, two of the more interesting collections emerged from young talents backed by two of the most influential designers in the business, Rei Kawakubo and Issey Miyake.

title: Coventry Corp.(CVTY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 2,896,000, or 9 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 3,355,000, or 12 cents a share, in the year.

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL: EAST;
Childress: A Field General With Heart and a Clutch Shot
description: Wake Forest guard Randolph Childress is accustomed to commanding everything on a basketball court, from his teammates to his outward emotions to the games themselves.

title: Leroy B. Kellam, 76, Ex-Judge in Queens
description: Leroy B. Kellam, a former State Supreme Court justice in Queens who was a founder of a bar association for minority lawyers, died on March 7 in the North Carolina Baptist Hospital in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 76 and had lived in Pinnacle, N.C., since his retirement in 1988.

title: For Many in Work Force, 'Glass Ceiling' Still Exists
description: Despite three decades of affirmative action, "glass ceilings" and "concrete walls" still block women and minority groups from the top management ranks of American industry, a Federal commission said today in the Government's first comprehensive study of barriers to promotion.

title: Tough Guys in America's Landscape
description: SUNBURN By Laurence Shames 279 pages. Hyperion. $21.95. THE STANDOFF By Chuck Hogan 306 pages. Doubleday. $23.50.

title: Dumping Proposal Stirs Up Residents of Fishers Island
description: Hands shot up throughout the hall when John H. Thatcher Jr. asked at a recent meeting on Fishers Island who was ready to take on the Army, the Navy and the State of Connecticut to stop an underwater dumping project a mile and a half from shore.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Report Says 'Glass Ceiling' Is Prevalent in U.S. Industry A Federal commission has found that white men hold about 95 percent of all senior management positions, and although white women have poured into lower management, they often do not advance.

title: The House That Replacements Rebuilt?
description: Replacement baseball will stain Yankee Stadium and Yankee tradition, Don Mattingly said today. What it won't do, the latest in the tradition of venerable Yankee stars added, is make any impact on striking players.

title: Peering Into New York's Glass House
description: A state legislative hearing called today by the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, promises to shed light on corruption at New York City's Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. A key witness on the schedule is the embattled former president of the Javits Center, Fabian Palomino.

title: John Ellis, 82, a Republican Who Aided Disabled Children
description: John Ellis, a prominent liberal Republican who worked on behalf of mentally ill children, died on March 6 at his home in Aiken, S.C. He was 82 and kept a home in Manhattan until 1975.

title: Sports of The Times; Another Rebellion At Fort Riley
description: ANYONE who sits behind the Knicks' bench at Madison Square Garden will tell you that the most fascinating exchanges are the ones between Pat Riley and Anthony Mason. If that's what they can be called.

title: White House Memo; Lies, Regrets and Presidential Loyalty, of a Sort
description: The Attorney General concludes, in notably pungent terms, that the Housing Secretary lied to the F.B.I. about how much money he paid his former mistress, and that he did so at the time he was applying for the honor of serving the President. The President says he regrets that mistakes were made, and vows to stand by his man -- for now.

title: Stanhome Inc.(STH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Stanhome said that the latest periods' results included a $ 3.5 million expense for contractual retirement obligations. Prior year's results included $ 17 million restructuring charge.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Economy Shows Some Signs of Strength, but Dollar Falls Sharply; Both Stocks and Bonds Shed Early Nervousness
description: The dollar tumbled to near-record lows in overseas trading yesterday, despite signs of robust growth in the American economy that could lead to higher interest rates. The stock and bond markets largely shrugged off the fall in the dollar and the stronger-than-expected economic data.

title: Broadway StoresInc.(BWY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net lossc-Included $ 20 million pretax charge in the quarter and $ 45 million pretax charge in the year, both for nonrecurring costs.(Loss)

title: Court Orders Votes Counted In Alabama
description: In a decision that may reverse the results of the election of its Chief Justice, the Alabama Supreme Court has ruled that some 1,700 contested absentee ballots that are likely to favor the Democratic incumbent over the Republican challenger should be counted.

title: Poor Land Is Exerting Big Weight In Africa
description: When the Liberian faction leader Charles Taylor needs a plane to move around the region, diplomats say, he picks up his satellite telephone and calls Blaise Compaore, the President of Burkina Faso, a hardscrabble nation of nine million people. Typically, a plane bearing the country's yellow, green and red colors arrives in short order.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Two Sought in Fatal Robbery
description: The authorities searched yesterday for at least two men who posed as deliverymen in a botched robbery attempt on Tuesday that left the wife of a jewelry store owner dead and another suspect wounded.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Local Bouts Are Back
description: The former champions TRACY HARRIS PATTERSON and AARON DAVIS headline the first boxing show in Manhattan in two years March 29 at the 69th Regiment Armory on Lexington Avenue and 26th Street that the promoter, MICHAEL BLUTRICH, hopes will lead to a series of monthly shows. Boxing had disappeared from New York when Madison Square Garden ended its regular shows at the Paramount in 1993 until Blutrich got New York State to rent him the armory. The armory will seat about 3,000 with tickets priced from $75 to $20.

title: Cutting Nursing Home Profits, Not Care
description: THERE is quite a crowd-pleaser in Gov. George E. Pataki's rather daunting list of proposed Medicaid cuts. Halve the profits that nursing homes earn from Medicaid, says the Governor.

title: History Standards for All Tastes; Iraqi Kurds Mark Grim Anniversary
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Playtime At the Dentist
description: IF anyone doubts that times have changed, just listen to this: there are some children these days who have burst into tears when told their visit to the dentist was being postponed, and some parents who have punished naughty children by canceling their haircut appointments.

title: Conrail Names Chief Executive
description: Conrail Inc. named its president, David M. LeVan, as its chief executive, completing a management succession plan begun in September.

title: Colgate, to the Big Dance
description: College coaches cried out in anguish last spring when a bright, athletic high schooler named Adonal Foyle (6 feet 10 inches tall, 260 pounds) said no to the basketball factories and instead chose Colgate, a smallish school with no basketball reputation, in Hamilton, N.Y.

title: Mitchell Energy & Development Corp.(MND.A,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included $ 52.6 million in pretax gains on major energy asset sales, partly offset by $ 36.9 million in pretax restructuring costs and asset write-downs. The net after-tax effect of the items was a gain of $ 8.6 million.c-Net lossd-Included extraordinary charge of $ 5,426,000, or 1o cents a share, in the quarter and 11 cents a share, in the year, on loss from early retirement of debt. The year also included a $ 6.6 million deferred tax charge related to the August 1993 increase in the federal corporate income tax rate.(Loss)The year-ago periods were restated to reflect an accounting change to successful effects from the full-cost method.

title: Puritan-Bennett Corp.(PBEN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $ 2,654,000 in the quarter and year, and charges of $ 490,000 in the quarter and $ 5,049,000 in the year for costs associated with unsolicited offers to acquire its stock.c-Net loss, which included restructuring charges of $ 34,155,000 in the quarter and $ 43,169,000 in the year. The periods were also after charges of $ 135,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 2,890,000, or 24 cents a share, in the year, from adjustments in accounting.(Loss)

title: AT HOME WITH: Evangeline Bruce; The Improbable Author
description: EVANGELINE BRUCE has been called many things in her 70-odd years -- beauty, fashion plate, consummate diplomat's wife, American society's last empress -- but no label rankles more than what she calls the "H" word.

title: Mixed Economic Signals Leave Long Bond Unchanged
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as the dollar remained weak and reports of strong growth in the economy countered a Federal Reserve report that suggested that inflation was unlikely to accelerate.

title: LaFontaine's Odyssey Of Recovery Set to End
description: Two weeks ago, Pat LaFontaine of the Sabres had just finished an extensive rehabilitation session on Long Island with Steve Wirth, the Islanders' team therapist.

title: Amid the Follies, Jefferson Dallied
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON, that man of reason, had kinkier taste in architecture than one might have thought. When the new Merchant-Ivory film, "Jefferson in Paris," opens later this month, viewers will be introduced to one of Jefferson's favorite architectural sites, an example of 18th-century fantasy building at its most extravagant.

title: SHARES OF UNION CARBIDE GAIN ON EARNINGS ESTIMATE
description: Shares of the Union Carbide Corporation rose yesterday after the company said it expected to report first-quarter earnings that would exceed Wall Street estimates. A survey of 17 brokers conducted by First Call Inc. yielded a range of estimates from 80 cents a share to $1.10 a share, with a mean estimate of 98 cents a share. Union Carbide, based in Danbury, Conn., plans to report first-quarter earnings in late April. Last year, the company reported first-quarter net income of $61 million, or 37 cents a share. Shares of Union Carbide rose $1.125, to $29.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; 4 Held in Hate-Group Attack
description: Four members of a white supremacist group remained in custody yesterday after being charged with beating a 14-year-old Woodbridge girl who was trying to quit the group, prosecutors said.

title: Economy Shows Some Signs of Strength, but Dollar Falls Sharply
description: Even as consumer spending appears to be tailing off, American industry pushed solidly ahead in February and prices obtained by producers showed signs of acceleration, according to Government figures released today.

title: Showtime's Former Chief Leaves Viacom
description: Winston H. (Tony) Cox, who recently was replaced as chairman and chief executive of Showtime Networks Inc., has now resigned from Showtime's parent company, Viacom Inc.

title: G.O.P. IN SENATE BOWS TO MINORITY ON STRIKER ISSUE
description: In the face of determined opposition by the Senate's Democratic minority, Republicans today abandoned their effort to overturn a directive by President Clinton on the use of replacement workers in strikes.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: AN ERROR, A DEATH, A JAIL SENTENCE Dr. Gerald Einaugler, a Brooklyn internist, was in trouble. But this was not ordinary doctor trouble; he faced criminal prosecution, not a civil suit. And so the American Medical Association, the Medical Society of the State of New York and two other doctors' groups have taken up an impassioned defense. A1. NEW YORK CITY THE PIPES, THE PIPES As the bagpipes resonate, the din of sirens and scanners fades from their minds, and they feel a fleeting sense of calm. Members of the Police Department's Emerald Society Pipe and Drum Band, a centerpiece of the St. Patrick's Day Parade, take their music seriously. Some say their band audition was the most stressful event of their police career. B3.

title: PROGRAMS BASED ON SEX AND RACE ARE CHALLENGED
description: The simmering debate over affirmative action boiled over on several fronts today. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said he would seek to end preference programs for women and minorities, while a Federal court and a Congressional committee also raised questions about the programs' validity.

title: Court Stalls F.C.C. Program For Women and Minorities
description: A Federal appeals court here today derailed the Government's most ambitious affirmative action program, temporarily blocking a plan to reserve a valuable swath of the nation's airwaves for small businesses, minorities and women.

title: Compromise Plan On New York City And Public Stations
description: New York City would divest itself of its public radio and television stations under a compromise plan that could win initial approval as early as next week, parties to the discussions said yesterday.

title: In Los Angeles, A Time for Planting
description: ON a desolate corner of Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard in the South-Central neighborhood recently, a group of fidgety fifth- and seventh-grade students from two local schools were being taught a lesson in urban renewal, environmental conservation and civic responsibility.

title: Lincoln Center Feels Strain as It Prepares New Festival for 1996
description: Lincoln Center's plans for a major new international arts festival in the summer of 1996 are placing a strain on the always delicate balance of interests among the center's cultural institutions, according to people who have been following the project.

title: Economic Scene; The dollar also rises, but not so much lately. Why is that?
description: THE weighty dollar, anchor to the world's monetary system, has once again torn loose in turbulent financial seas.

title: Fans Back Grobbelaar
description: BRUCE GROBBELAAR and two other English Premier League soccer players, HANS SEGERS and JOHN FASHANU, were released on bail yesterday in London after 30 hours of questioning over bribery allegations. The police are investigating allegations that the three players were paid to fix the outcome of games.

title: Duper Is Acquitted On All Drug Charges
description: MARK DUPER, the former Miami Dolphins wide receiver, was found not guilty in Federal court in Miami yesterday on all charges in a scheme to buy cocaine, convert it to crack and sell it in Louisiana.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Before Car Chase, a Robbery
description: Two of the four men captured in a wild car chase early Tuesday are suspected of having stopped here for gasoline (and about $300) shortly beforehand. The police say that John J. Carroll and Keyseaa Hodges robbed an Exxon station near the Lincoln Tunnel just after midnight and drove off in a stolen Acura. The money was found on Mr. Hodges when he was arrested, investigators say.

title: U.N. Force in Croatia Is Waiting for Orders
description: As diplomats in New York begin urgent discussions about an expanded mission for the United Nations military force in Croatia, their commanders in the field are worried that the troops will be given a mandate without the means to fulfill it.

title: Officials Ousted At Gibson Unit
description: The C. R. Gibson Company posted losses for the fourth quarter and 1994, citing improper accounting at its Rytex subsidiary, and said it had dismissed the president and controller of Rytex for concealing the problems at the unit.

title: Banks Earnings Hit Record High in '94
description: The earnings of Unites States commercial banks were $10.7 billion in the fourth quarter and reached a record high of $44.7 billion in 1994, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The name of the chairman of the benefit dinner for the National Conference of Christians and Jews may have a familiar ring: ALFRED E. SMITH 4th. Yes, he is a namesake and great-grandson of the 1928 Democratic Presidential nominee and three-term Governor of New York.

title: Marshall Industries(MI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a charge of $ 163,000, or 1 cent a share, related to tax rate increase, and an after-tax restructuring charge of $ 525,000, or 3 cents a share.Share earnings and shares outstanding for 1994 year were adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 28, 1994.

title: Henry Lieberman, a Times Editor, Dies at 78
description: Henry R. Lieberman, a foreign correspondent and later an editor for The New York Times, died yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 78.

title: UTI Energy Stake Sold
description: The Bear Stearns Companies has sold its 53 percent stake in the UTI Energy Corporation, an oil drilling services company based here, to Remy Capital Partners III L.P. for $7.8 million, UTI said today. Remy Capital, a private investment partnership, bought roughly 1.7 million shares for $4.50 each. Remy said it would aim to expand UTI's existing operations and seek acquisitions.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: From Boston With Blooms

title: Wiley (John) & Sons Inc.(WILLA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included after-tax charge of $ 1.1 million, or 13 cents a share, related to restructuring and consolidation of certain distribution and information technology support functions in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included an after-tax gain of $ 1.3 million, or 16 cents a share, related to the divestiture of the company's Canadian high school and Australian primary school publishing lines.The company also lists its class B shares on the Nasdaq Small Capitalization market under the symbol WILLB.

title: The Right Time to Visit Moscow
description: The White House should stop agonizing and accept the Russian invitation for President Clinton to attend ceremonies on May 8 marking the 50th anniversary of the German surrender in World War II.

title: Sizzler Intl.(SZ,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 5
description: b-Net loss(Loss)Systemwide sales from all franchised and company-owned restaurants fell to $ 273 million in the latest quarter from $ 280 million in the year-ago period. Systemwide sales in the latest 9 months totaled $ 723 million, compared with $ 760 million in year-ago period.

title: Hills Stores Co.(HDS,N) reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 28
description: b-Included a gain of $ 9.6 million related to a reversal of liabilities established in ''fresh-start'' accounting, partially offset by $ 2.2 million in additional amortization of deferred financing costs and $ 2.2 million paid to holders of senior notes connected to the company's self-tender. The net after-tax effect of these nonrecurring items was to increase fully diluted earnings by 19 cents a share.c-Included various nonrecurring gains which increased fully diluted earnings by 23 cents a share.The pro forma combined statement of operations presents the pro forma combined results of opeations of the successor and predecessor companies for the 52 weeks ended Jan. 29, 1994 and have been adjusted to reflect: the implementation of fresh start reporting as of Jan. 31, 1993; elimination of the effects of nonrecurring transactions resulting from the reorganization included in the results of the predecessor company; and payment to creditors pursuant to the plan of reorganization as of Jan. 31, 1993.The fiscal 1994 results are pro forma, reflecting the fact that the company emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy and adopted ''fresh-start'' accounting as of Oct. 2, 1993.

title: Risky Cure -- A special report; Parkinson's Sufferers Gamble On a Surgery With Hazards
description: A surgical treatment for Parkinson's disease has dramatically helped some patients with the debilitating disease, but, unknown to many eager and desperate Parkinson's sufferers, the surgery has left others paralyzed, blind, demented or comatose.

title: Oshkosh B'Gosh Inc.(GOSHA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a $ 7.1 million, or 49 cents a share, restructuring charge, in the quarter and year.(Loss)

title: Helms Seeks to Merge Foreign Policy Agencies
description: Senator Jesse Helms proposed a radical restructuring of foreign policy apparatus today that he said would save billions of dollars by merging half a dozen agencies into the State Department.

title: No Headline
description: "Many middle- and upper-level white male managers view the inclusion of minorities and women in management as a direct threat to their own chances for advancement." -- GLASS CEILING COMMISSION. [ A22:1. ]

title: A Fragile Hope in Croatia?
description: When President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia meets today with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, the most pressing item on his agenda will be war or peace in the northern Balkans.

title: Market Place; Another first for cyberspace! An S.E.C. suit for investor fraud.
description: THE slick pitches that dotted the classified ads of America Online promised, "You can't lose!" For $189 a share, investors could get in on the ground floor of an operation that would yield them a minimum $60 a week. It was, as the cyberspace ads crowed, "an amazing company."

title: Life Re Corp.(LRE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included an investment loss of $ 1,292,000 in the quarter and an investment gain of $ 89,000 in the year. Year-ago quarter included an investment loss of $ 1,655,000 and the year included an investment gain of $ 20,957,000.

title: William A. Fowler, 83, Astrophysicist, Dies
description: Dr. William A. Fowler, a Nobel laureate who played a leading role in developing the commonly accepted theory that virtually all of the elements throughout the universe were created inside the stars, died on Tuesday at Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena, Calif. He was 83 and lived in Pasadena.

title: ALLIANT TECHSYSTEMS COMPLETES DEAL FOR HERCULES UNIT
description: Alliant Techsystems Inc. said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of the aerospace division of Hercules Inc. for about $440 million in cash and stock. The price for the division, the Hercules Aerospace Company, includes $296 million in cash and 3.86 million shares of newly issued Alliant Techsystems stock. Alliant, a munitions maker based in Hopkins, Minn., said the combined aerospace and defense company would have annual revenue of $1.3 billion and 9,000 employees in 24 states. Hercules, based in Wilmington, Del., will now own 30 percent of Alliant. The deal was announced in October.

title: Judge Says Gay Group Can't March
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected the latest effort by a gay Irish group to win permission to march on Fifth Avenue tomorrow, St. Patrick's Day.

title: Mideast Goal Of Clinton And Hassan
description: With Israel and Syria set to resume direct talks soon, President Clinton and King Hassan II of Morocco called today for speeding up the quest for Middle East peace.

title: The Pop Life
description: Warner's Progress

title: Accounts
description: The Golden Grain Co. unit of the Quaker Oats Co., Pleasanton, Calif., to Young & Rubicam San Francisco, as the first agency of record for Nile Spice instant soup cups, which Golden Grain recently acquired. Y.& R. San Francisco already handles other Golden Grain brands. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $4 million.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Not Major League Baseball
description: QUICK now, do you know the names of any of baseball's so-called replacement players?

title: Chancellor Makes Bid for SFX Broadcasting
description: The Chancellor Holdings Corporation, a privately held radio broadcaster, offered yesterday to buy SFX Broadcasting Inc. for $26 a share, or about $160 million.

title: Filipinos Protest Singapore Death Sentence
description: The Government of Singapore, which has tried to portray the debate over its draconian legal system as a clash between Asian and Western values, now finds its courts under attack by fellow Asians who are campaigning to prevent the execution of a Philippine woman this week.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Preserving a Forest and Falls
description: The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee yesterday authorized $20.8 million to help northern New Jersey hold on to some of its past.

title: 'Boat People' Prefer Death To Homeland
description: Tran Ba is so desperate to avoid being forced back home to Vietnam that in a protest this month he doused himself with kerosene in front of horrified Philippine guards and threatened to set himself afire.

title: U.S. Steel Plans to Increase Its Prices on Sheet Products
description: The nation's newly prosperous basic steel industry appears on its way to even more prosperity by raising prices for the second time this year on the sheet products that go into automobiles, appliances and a broad variety of consumer and industrial products.

title: International Briefs; Fokker Selling Stake
description: The Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V. agreed yesterday to sell two-thirds of its space subsidiary, Fokker Space and Systems. Fokker said one-third would be sold to Utra Centrifuge Nederland and one-third to Parcom Ventures, a unit of the ING Group. The remaining third will remain in Fokker's hands. Financial details of the sales were not disclosed. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Turmoil After Fire At Design Center
description: SEVERAL years from now, the week the Decoration & Design Building was closed because of an electrical fire may become the stuff of legend, like the New York City blackouts and the winter of '94.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt City of New York is selling $445 million of tax-exempt general-obligation bonds through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 6.75 percent in 2014 and 6.80 percent in 2025. For short-maturity serial bonds, yields range from 5.25 percent in 1997 to 6.70 percent in 2010. The bonds are rated Baa1 by Moody's, A- by S.& P. and A- by Fitch. Commercial Credit Co., Baltimore, is selling $200 million of notes due in 2002 through CS First Boston Corp. The noncallable notes are priced at 99.441 to yield 7.375 percent and are rated A1 by Moody's, A+ by S.& P. and A+ by Duff & Phelps.

title: Manhattan Is Aiming To Prove It Belongs
description: For Manhattan College, the small Bronx school from a midlevel conference, the goal in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament is not to lay an egg.

title: Value City Department Stores Inc.(VCD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included $ 3.4 million, or 6 cents a share, from the results of the physical inventories completed in the latest quarter.c-Included $ 600,000, or 2 cents a share, for a net reduction of income taxes for retroactive adjustments brought about by tax law changes.

title: Power Play Falls Short Again for Rangers
description: Should the Rangers be concerned? Perhaps a little bit. After losing by 4-3 to the Philadelphia Flyers last night at Madison Square Garden, they are flirting with a slump.

title: Can It Be? Disney Builds Resort Without Mickey
description: The Walt Disney Company announced yesterday that it was building its first resort exclusively for adults and families with older children. When the Disney Institute, as the resort is called, opens next February on the grounds of the Disney World Resort near Orlando, Fla., such familiar Disney characters as Mickey, Minnie and Donald Duck will be conspicuous by their absence.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Plans to Divest Remaining Stake in RJR Nabisco
description: Putting an end to one of America's more rambunctious corporate sagas, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to divest itself of its remaining 8 percent ownership of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BUDD SCHULBERG was determined that the cast of his new play, "On the Waterfront," absorb the atmosphere of a place where dockworkers gathered. So yesterday, he accompanied 35 people to the Church of St. Francis Xavier, at 30 West 16th Street.

title: A Student Center That Defies Dull
description: FROM 7 A.M. to midnight, at least 100 of the 1,500 students at Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., are shooting billiards, drinking wine or chatting at the new 40,000-square-foot David Saul Smith Union, dedicated this month.

title: MICROSOFT DELAYS INTRODUCTION OF WINDOWS 95 AGAIN
description: The chief executive of the Microsoft Corporation, William H. Gates, said the company planned to have the newest version of its Windows operating system software, Windows 95, on the market by September -- a month later than previously estimated. Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash, had already postponed the introduction of the long-awaited product three times. Shipment of the software was originally supposed to begin in December. "Our goal is to continue to update Windows -- every couple of years we'll have a major update," Mr. Gates told an audience of more than 200 computer experts and government officials in Bonn.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Miller's 40 Points Lead Pacers Reggie Miller scored a season-high 40 points, including 17 in the final quarter when the Indiana Pacers rallied to defeat visiting Milwaukee, 117-108, last night. (AP)

title: Venezuela, Fearing an Uprising Today, Arrests 150 Leftists
description: Venezuelan authorities have arrested 150 leftists across the nation this week, alleging that they were plotting to set off an uprising on Thursday.

title: Strong Yen Aids Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Loyce Houlton, 70, Troupe Founder And Choreographer
description: Loyce Houlton, a leader in American regional dance and a choreographer whose works were performed by companies in the United States and Europe, died on Tuesday at United Hospital in St. Paul. She was 70 and lived in Minneapolis.

title: Jaguars Get Free Agent
description: DAVE WIDELL, a free-agent offensive lineman, signed yesterday with the Jacksonville Jaguars. Widell, a seven-year veteran, started all 16 games at center last season for the Denver Broncos after previously playing guard and tackle. He spent his first two years in the National Football League with the Dallas Cowboys in 1988-89. (AP)

title: American Israeli Paper Mills Ltd.(AIP,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rison to Join Browns
description: Wide receiver ANDRE RISON, leaving the Atlanta Falcons as an unrestricted free agent, said he will play for the Cleveland Browns next season.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 VIETNAM'S ADAMANT BOAT EXILES Two decades after the first vessels pushed off the shores, the tragic final chapter of Vietnam's boat people is being written in detention camps across Southeast Asia. More than anything, the boat people fear a return to their country, so forcing them home will be an ugly, possibly dangerous business. A1

title: Amid Accusations and Adjectives, Tension of 2 Lawyers Erupts
description: Smoldering tensions between the opposing lawyers in the O. J. Simpson case broke into the open today as Marcia Clark and F. Lee Bailey squared off in an unusually nasty exchange. Ms. Clark called Mr. Bailey a liar; Mr. Bailey dismissed Ms. Clark as "shrill."

title: Eagle-Picher Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Crackdown on Job-Injury Costs
description: Willie Brown, one of the most powerful politicians in California, recently found himself on the other side of the fence from the working people whose causes he likes to champion.

title: Accused Alcatel Chief Mounts a TV Defense
description: Breaking his silence by going on national television, the chairman of Alcatel Alsthom today denied all charges that he misused company funds to remodel his house and that his company, the world's largest maker of telecommunications equipment, had overbilled its biggest client, France Telecom.

title: Reviews/Fashion; In Paris, Clothes That Look Tough, Masculine and Dangerous
description: An underground fashion newspaper being passed out on the first day of the fall '95 women's ready-to-wear shows here opens with a chart listing the six most popular films in Paris: "Natural Born Killers," "Pulp Fiction," "Interview With the Vampire," "True Romance," "Serial Mom" and "Reservoir Dogs." Calling attention to their shared violence, the newspaper, called F (for freedom), asks: "New reality or fashionable attitude?"

title: A Mistake, a Rare Prosecution, And a Doctor Is Headed for Jail
description: The elderly nursing home patient was suffering from total kidney failure. She was blind and she could not speak. On the afternoon of May 18, 1990, Dr. Gerald Einaugler mistook a dialysis catheter in her abdomen for a feeding tube, and ordered feeding solution pumped through it.

title: State Leaders Agree on Revenue Estimate
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the state's legislative leaders passed the first milestone on the path to enacting a state budget by agreeing today on how much money they will have available to spend.

title: Chrysler Idles Plant to Repair Noise in Neons
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that a peculiar noise emanating from the front ends of its Neon subcompact cars had forced the company to idle the assembly plant in Illinois that produced the vehicles.

title: Italian Premier Calls for a Confidence Vote in Debate on Budget
description: Pushed to the brink by a debilitating budget battle, Prime Minister Lamberto Dini called today for a confidence vote on his two-month-old Government, a gamble that could force national elections to be held as early as June.

title: Mason-Riley Blowup Symptom of Internal Strife
description: The latest dispute between Pat Riley and Anthony Mason magnified a larger issue that the Knicks were ready to admit today. They are a team with internal problems, a team on the verge of letting petty gripes and a lack of unity ruin a chance to win a championship.

title: Angelica Corp.(AGL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Eagle Hardware & Garden Inc.(EAGL,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $ 14,331,000, or 63 cents a share, which included a write-off of Canadian deferred tax benefit of $ 1,616,000, and a loss on the sale of the company's Canadian unit of $ 12,715,000, in the quarter and year.c-Net income(Loss)

title: Sigma-Aldrich Corp.(SIAL,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 10,806,000, or 22 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: France Assures Public on an Ailing Bank
description: Seeking to bolster public confidence in Credit Lyonnais, the huge state-owned bank, and shore up the presidential hopes of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur, the Government has gone on a public relations blitz by assuring depositors that their money is safe, telling taxpayers they will not pay for future bank losses and warning bank officers that fraud will be prosecuted.

title: Sotheby's Holdings Inc.(BID,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Smoking Sickness
description: Ninety percent of all smokers pick up the habit in their teens, and their reasons for doing so are the same now as they were 50 years ago. Their friends smoke. A cigarette is a cool accessory. Smoking is a rite of passage. They will not know until the day they try to quit that they are exposing themselves to a substance, nicotine, that the National Institutes of Health says is as addictive as heroin and 5 to 10 times more potent than cocaine or morphine in producing effects on mood and behavior.

title: In French Presidential Race, Lagging Neo-Gaullist Hustles on the Hustings
description: Once the front-runner and now the underdog in the race for the French presidency, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur is trying to regain the lead with a new campaign full of hustle and hoopla.

title: Solectron Corp.(SLR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
A Violist Finds the Purity in Late Shostakovich
description: Shostakovich's Viola Sonata is less than 20 years old. It seems as if it has been around much longer, like a distant supernova whose light has just reached the eyes of earth. With this work, and with his 15th Symphony, Shostakovich began a new stylistic progression that death immediately cut short. The sonata does not carry forward the anguished personal dramas of the late quartets; it exists on a plane of pure music, conversing with voices out of the past. A ghostly echo of Beethoven's "Moonlight" glides through the finale. There is deep melancholy, but also deep repose.

title: Prudential Is Putting Its Home Mortgage Business Up for Sale
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced yesterday that it wanted to sell its home mortgage business, one of the largest in the country.

title: Cato Corp.(CACOA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
MARTIN MARIETTA-LOCKHEED MERGER IS APPROVED
description: Shareholders of the Lockheed Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation overwhelmingly approved the $10 billion merger of the companies yesterday. The new company, to be called the Lockheed Martin Corporation, will be based in Bethesda, Md., where Martin Marietta is based. Lockheed's headquarters in Calabasas, Calif., will be sold. Daniel M. Tellep, the chairman of Lockheed, will be chairman and chief executive of Lockheed Martin, but will retire when he turns 65 in about two years, making way for Norman R. Augustine, the chairman of Martin Marietta, who is 59. Lockheed Martin, with about 170,000 employees and annual sales of $23 billion, will be the nation's largest military contractor. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Lockheed fell 12.5 cents, to $81.50, while those of Martin Marietta rose 12.5 cents, to $50.375.

title: In Jersey City, It's Earning by Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Rifts Emerge Inside G.O.P.
description: For 70 days House Republicans have closed ranks, demonstrated remarkable party discipline and kept moving through the legislative agenda in their Contract With America. But now the familiar cracks are beginning to show.

title: One Trophy Missing From Marbury Case
description: Stephon Marbury has collected basketball awards the way the Internal Revenue Service collects taxes. Yet there is one achievement the 6-foot-2-inch senior guard from Lincoln High School conspicuously lacks: a championship.

title: HEALTH SYSTEMS ACQUIRES H.M.O. IN CONNECTICUT
description: Health Systems International said yesterday that it had acquired closely held M. D. Enterprises of Connecticut Inc. for about $100 million in cash. Health Systems, a health maintenance company based in Woodland Hills, Calif., had the option to purchase all the outstanding stock of M. D. Enterprises with cash or common shares, but elected to pay cash and account for the transaction as a purchase. M. D. Enterprises is the parent of M. D. Health Plan, the third-largest health maintenance organization in Connecticut. Health Systems, one of the nation's largest H.M.O.'s, serves more than 1.6 million members in Connecticut and several states in the West.

title: Whitman Bond-Recycling Plan Would Provide $500 Million to Stimulate Housing
description: By recycling state mortgage bonds and refining construction rules, New Jersey housing agencies will put more than $500 million into urban and suburban low- to medium-income housing in the next nine months.

title: Once Again, Record Levels Of Lobbying
description: Amid concerns about budget cuts and health care overhaul, spending on efforts to lobby state officials reached a record of $39.1 million last year, a report released today said.

title: Dole's the One For Delegation In Congress
description: The 14 Republican members of the New York delegation in Congress today declared their support for Senator Bob Dole for the party's Presidential nomination.

title: Some Drugs Rise in Price At Fast Pace
description: Pharmaceutical companies have increased the pace of price increases on many of their best-selling drugs since the collapse of the Clinton Administration's health care proposal last year.

title: Corrections
description: A headline and an entry in the front-page "Inside" listing on Tuesday referred incorrectly in some editions to the trend in welfare and food stamp rolls. They have leveled off, not decreased.

title: History Standards for All Tastes
description: To the Editor:

title: Simpson Defense Details Glove Theory
description: F. Lee Bailey, one of O. J. Simpson's defense lawyers, today laid out more explicitly than ever before just how Detective Mark Fuhrman could have removed a bloody glove from the spot where Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend were killed last June, stored it on his person without being detected, carried it to Mr. Simpson's house and deposited it there without being seen.

title: Western Beef Inc.(BEEF,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
History Standards for All Tastes; Arts Agency's Mistake
description: To the Editor:

title: Wallace Computer Services Inc.(WCS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 663,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: E.C.A.C. Tournament

title: Big B Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Included a pretax write-off of about $ 1 million, or 4 cents a share after tax, for unusable equipment.

title: Calendar: Crafts Shows, Gardens and an Auction
description: Crafts Times Three American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street; (212) 956-3535.

title: Michael Dash; Countertenor and Baritone, 36
description: Michael Dash, a singer who functioned both as a countertenor and a baritone and who appeared with numerous opera companies around the country, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 36.

title: SDL SHARES SURGE $12 IN INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Shares of SDL Inc., which makes integrated circuits and semiconductor lasers, rose $12, to $28, in Nasdaq trading yesterday, after its initial public offering of 2.4 million shares of common stock. More than 2.5 million shares of the company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., were traded. SDL said it intended to use the proceeds from the offering to repay debt, expand manufacturing operations and for general corporate purposes. SDL designs, manufactures and markets integrated circuits and high-powered lasers used in communications, printing, data storage and the medical industry.

title: Police Say Store Victim Was Killed By Husband
description: The investigation into the fatal shooting of a woman in a botched jewelry store robbery in New Jersey took a bizarre turn yesterday when the authorities said that the victim was killed not by a robber but apparently by her own husband.

title: CUNY Doesn't Have Budget Fat to Trim
description: To the Editor:

title: Gerry Adams Shakes Hands With Clinton
description: For Congress's annual St. Patrick's Day luncheon, Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, invited Ireland's new Prime Minister, John Bruton, to be the main event. But the first handshake between President Clinton and Gerry Adams, the head of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, stole the spotlight.

title: National Service Industries(NSI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
CHRONICLE
description: Dr. JOYCELYN ELDERS, the former Surgeon General, who resigned in a blaze of controversy in December, is coming to town next week. She is to address a breakfast of the Prochoice Resource Center, a national organization that trains groups how to protect women's rights to abortion.

title: Interference Irks Lemaire in Devils' Tie
description: The Devils came up with another mediocre performance tonight, settling for a 2-2 tie with the Hartford Whalers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Stock Prices Set Records Once Again
description: Despite some new and conflicting economic reports, traders sent stock prices to record levels yesterday as bond prices fell slightly and the dollar seemed to steady overseas.

title: Shredding Documents to Shield Victims of Sexual Assault
description: As in the United States, the Criminal Code in Canada generally protects victims of sexual assault from direct questioning in court about their sexual past. But that protection is often circumvented when defense lawyers subpoena the medical and psychological counseling records of a victim, including those kept by rape crisis centers that help women deal with their trauma.

title: British Veto Cheaper New Bid for Utility
description: Trafalgar House P.L.C. must abandon a reduced-price bid for a regional British utility, Northern Electric P.L.C., the British Government's takeover panel said today.

title: Trial Details the Selecting of Bomb Targets
description: Seeking to deflect charges that an informer entrapped Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman and 10 other defendants, prosecutors tried to demonstrate yesterday that one suspect who has already pleaded guilty was the first to suggest bombing targets in New York City.

title: Simpson's Lawyer Fails To Crack Crucial Witness
description: Detective Mark Fuhrman left the witness stand today, far more intact than lawyers for O. J. Simpson and his lawyers would have liked.

title: At the Bar; Justice Scalia, cheerfully, tells what's behind following the letter of the law.
description: In pointed, stylish, occasionally idiosyncratic opinions, Justice Antonin Scalia has carved a distinctive role on the Supreme Court by questioning the conventions of modern statutory and constitutional interpretation. Judges, he insists, stray too often from the intellectual purity of the text, smuggling personal values into decisions under the rubric of twin will-o'-the-wisps, legislative history and "intent."

title: Americans Should Care About an Irish Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Stop Now
description: Scientists say that human evolution may be at an end. Natural selection is stopping, no doubt as a result of natural selection. Homo sapiens, always the finest proof of the survival of the fittest, appears to have concluded that it is fit enough.

title: Entrepreneur Gets $30 Million To Establish For-Profit Schools
description: A few months after financial pressures seemed to put its future in jeopardy, the Edison Project, the media entrepreneur Christopher Whittle's groundbreaking venture into for-profit education, announced yesterday that it had secured $30 million in financing and would open its first schools next fall.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the front page of Business Day yesterday reporting the Producer Price Index going back to 1993 carried the wrong scale, making the figures incorrect. A corrected chart appears today on page D2.

title: Consumer Prices Up 0.3%; Data Point to a Slowdown
description: A variety of fresh Government statistics released today showed that an economic slowdown, becoming more pronounced by the day, was helping to moderate the sting of inflation.

title: Congressman Opens 2d Office
description: Representative Bill Martini, Republican from Paterson, willopen an office in freshman Congressman will greet visitors in his new office from noon to 1 P.M. Mr. Martini also has an office in Paterson

title: What's Wrong With UConn? Not a Thing.
description: Their fragility was checked at the door. For one purposeful afternoon in the national collegiate tournament, far from the high expectations of home, the Connecticut Huskies didn't have their psyches probed, their deficiencies analyzed or their chances questioned.

title: Police Cleared of False Reporting Charges
description: A review by New York City's Department of Investigation has rejected accusations, based on internal memorandums publicized last year, that police officers had filed false reports on the effectiveness of community policing. Instead, it concluded that the memos showed a range of problems that police officials were addressing.

title: Calpers Calls Bankers Trust Unresponsive
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System contends that Bankers Trust New York Corporation is overpaying its chairman and ignoring requests to make its board more responsive to stockholders.

title: Restaurants
description: "A luncheon I had at the Four Seasons last Monday was perfect," James Beard wrote to a California friend in early 1960. "I had blue trout with a spoon of butter sauce on it, one little new potato, a piece of good cheese and a double espresso. The trout had come that morning and was torn from the water when I ordered it."

title: Market Place; Peso crisis, not Barings price tag, is a big question mark for ING.
description: IT was audacious but not out of character for the ING Group of the Netherlands to plunk down more than $1 billion earlier this month for the corporate remains of Barings P.L.C., the bankrupt British investment bank.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 23 of Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy misstated both the name and the location of the school from which she graduated in 1910. At that time, it was known as the Academy of the Sacred Heart, not Manhattanville College, and it was located in Manhattanville, N.Y., not Purchase. A recent letter from a reader pointed out the error.

title: Sex Offender Is Arrested Again
description: A convicted sex offender who registered with the authorities under "Megan's Law" last month has been charged with assaulting a 5-year-old child on Wednesday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID BROWN, the film producer, is one of 11 people who plan to roast his wife, HELEN GURLEY BROWN, at a luncheon on Tuesday to celebrate her 30th anniversary as the editor in chief of Cosmopolitan magazine. But he's not worried about having to face her if she takes umbrage.

title: When House Killed The 4th Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Farmer Protection Act Defended
description: New Jersey's Agriculture Secretary, Art Brown, yesterday defended a Federal Agriculture Department program before a House subcommittee.

title: Herb McCracken; Inventor of Huddle, 95
description: Herb McCracken, a college football player and coach credited with inventing the huddle and co-founder of the Scholastic publishing company, died last Saturday in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 95. His family said the cause of death was renal impairment.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: As Automotive Air Bags Become Common, So Does Stealing Them
description: One morning last December, Martin Rothberg found a large hole in the center of his steering wheel.

title: First Year of Lopez Era Ends With Humbling Loss
description: A season that began with hysteria and hype because of the dawning of the Felipe Lopez Era ended with humbled expressions and hushed glances for St. John's tonight as South Florida roared to a 74-67 victory in the other post-season basketball tournament.

title: Juan Burciaga, 65, Judge Who Ended TV Football 'Cartel'
description: Judge Juan G. Burciaga, whose 1982 ruling put the National Collegiate Athletic Association out of the business of televised football, died on March 5 at Presbyterian Hospital in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 65 and lived in Albuquerque.

title: Same Time, Next Year: Knicks Again Suspend the Volatile Mason
description: Neither the creativity of Anthony Mason on the basketball court, nor the creativity of Anthony Mason's barber on Anthony Mason's head, will be visible in a Knicks uniform for at least five games. The Knicks yesterday suspended without pay their volatile forward and valuable sixth man after a confrontation with Coach Pat Riley during Tuesday night's game against Denver.

title: Rangers Know They Can't Live in Past
description: When the Rangers visit President Clinton in the White House Rose Garden this afternoon, they will present him with a miniature Stanley Cup that bears the inscription: "From One Madison Square Garden Victor to Another."

title: Pakistan's Ties to U.S. Remain Strong
description: To the Editor:

title: YELTSIN TO ALTER PARADE ON V-E DAY TO DRAW CLINTON
description: In a fresh effort to persuade President Clinton to come to Moscow for the 50th anniversary of the Allied victory in Europe, President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that he would tailor the Red Square military parade on May 9 to avoid embarrassing the American leader.

title: Hampton Industries(HAI,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax gain of $ 1,099,000 related to refund of U.S. customs duties in the quarter, and the year included pretax charges of $ 2,278,000 for restructuring and pretax gains of $ 1,983,000 related to refund of U.S. customs duties.c-Net loss, which included $ 41,100 of restructuring costs in the quarter, and the year included pretax charges of $ 668,000 for restructuring.(Loss)

title: Feminist Art, 1962 Until Tomorrow Morning and International
description: Why have there been there no great historical shows of feminist art? The work is there, 30 rich years of it since the woman's movement caught fire, but no major museum has yet been willing to take up the challenge and tell the story.

title: Inside Art
description: What's a van Gogh Worth? $7 Million?

title: Art in Review
description: Charles Long Tanya Bonakdar Gallery 130 Prince Street SoHo Through March 25

title: Mediocrity on the Bench
description: As President Clinton struggles to moderate his views on affirmative action, he is less than contrite about his Federal court appointments. "I've appointed more women and more minorities to the Federal bench than my predecessors combined at this point in our terms," he boasted this month. Unfortunately, his single-minded pursuit of diversity, combined with an eagerness to avoid controversy, has kept him from appointing the best available legal minds to the courts.

title: LTX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss, which included a restructuring charge of $ 17,876,000, or 71 cents a share, in the quarter and 6 months.(Loss)

title: Debate? Campaign Issues? But This Is Scarsdale
description: ROBERT HARRISON is trying to bring American democracy to Scarsdale, but he is having a tough time of it.

title: Reading & Bates Rejects Offer by Sonat Offshore
description: The Reading & Bates Corporation today rejected an unsolicited $450 million takeover offer from Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc., saying it was not in its shareholders' long-term interest. Instead, the company adopted a "poison pill" takeover defense.

title: Changes for Pirelli And Princess Cruise
description: A cruise line and a tire marketer are making changes in their agency rosters.

title: Rockefeller Drug Plan Is Best in the Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutilating, Murderous Lesbians, With a Light Side
description: "Naked Killer," an amusing action-adventure spoof from Hong Kong, unfolds on territory that is way, way beyond the "Valley of the Dolls." Imagine the erotic world of "Basic Instinct" exaggerated into a kung-fu cartoon of sexy lesbian avengers executing quadruple leaping somersaults in a deadly assault against the opposite sex. Their campaign of assassination involves not only murder, but castration and genital mutilation as well.

title: Karachi Journal; In a Hellish City, There's Still a Kind of Saintliness
description: Most people in Karachi would rather have been anywhere but in the Pak Colony on Sunday, but Allah Yar went to work as usual. In fact for Mr. Yar, Pak Colony was the only place to be: gang wars had overwhelmed the district overnight, scattering corpses along the narrow lanes and turning virtually every corner into a potential death trap.

title: A Correction: Producer Prices
description: A chart yesterday included incorrect figures for the index of finished goods prices, seasonally adjusted. Here are the correct figures. 1982 = 100.

title: Clinton Meets With Bosnian and Croatian Chiefs
description: President Clinton met today with Bosnian and Croatian leaders in an effort to give new life to a languishing political federation that his Administration says is vital to helping Muslims and Croats stand up to their joint enemy, the Serbs.

title: Nine West And U.S. Shoe Agree on Deal
description: The United States Shoe Corporation, which has been battling a surprise hostile takeover offer from an Italian eyewear company, Luxottica S.p.A., said yesterday that it had a definitive deal to sell its shoe division for cash and warrants worth about $600 million to Nine West Group Inc., a suitor it had twice spurned in recent months.

title: NIKE INC. (NKE,N)
description: Nike Inc. said yesterday that its earnings soared by 51 percent for the fiscal third quarter, exceeding Wall Street's expectations, buoyed by strong increases in sales of basketball, outdoor and women's fitness shoes.

title: Awad Closes Fast at Gulfstream Park
description: Gulfstream Park ended its two-and-a-half-month racing season today with a slight drop in attendance but a strong gain in its favorite export, simulcasting. It also declared Jerry Bailey its leading jockey, Bill Mott and Frank A. Passero Jr. its leading trainers and the 5-year-old Awad the surprise winner of its closing feature, the $300,000 Pan American Handicap.

title: Smithers Alcoholism Unit to Leave Its East Side Mansion
description: St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center is moving its Smithers Alcoholism and Rehabilitation Center from the Upper East Side mansion where the program was begun more than 20 years ago to the hospital's Roosevelt division, at 58th Street and 10th Avenue.

title: Conoco Told U.S. Years Ago Of Oil Negotiations With Iran
description: A senior Administration official acknowledged today that Conoco Inc. had repeatedly told American officials over the last four years that they were negotiating with Iran on the development of a $1 billion oilfield, but that the Government focused on the issue -- and decided to block it -- only after the deal was reached earlier this month.

title: International Briefs; Glaxo-Wellcome Merger Receives F.T.C. Approval
description: Glaxo P.L.C. said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission in the United States had effectively cleared its merger worth $:9.1 billion ($14.3 billion) with Wellcome P.L.C. But Glaxo said the agency told it to divest itself of a migraine drug that Wellcome has in development. The F.T.C. decision, which was expected and follows a similar ruling by the European Commission, clears the creation of the world's largest prescription drug maker, with more than $13.7 billion of annual sales.

title: Art in Review
description: Christopher Wilmarth Sidney Janis Gallery 110 West 57th Street Through March 25

title: BOX ENERGY REPORTS A BUYOUT OFFER BY SIMPLOT
description: The Box Energy Corporation, a natural gas exploration and production company based in Dallas, said yesterday that it had received a new $210 million buyout offer from one of its big shareholders. Box Energy said the Idaho potato magnate J. R. Simplot had offered to buy all the class A voting stock of Box Energy for $14 a share and all its class B nonvoting stock for $11 a share. In October Mr. Simplot offered to buy at least 50.1 percent of the class A stock for $15 a share, which topped an earlier offer of $13.50 a share by the Phoenix Canada Oil Company of Toronto. In mid-February Phoenix Canada raised its offer to $14 a share, but later lowered it to $12.

title: Art in Review
description: Kenneth Noland Leo Castelli Gallery 420 West Broadway (at Spring Street) SoHo Through March 25

title: Skyline Corp.(SKY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
An Expanded Business Day
description: With Wall Street suffering from a downturn in which thousands are being laid off, foreign and regional banks are taking advantage of the carnage to pick up new talent. Business Day examines the implications.

title: Accounts
description: * Omni Hotels, Hampton, N.H., to Gearon Hoffman, Boston, to handle its account, previously at Earle Palmer Brown, Philadelphia. The billings were estimated at more than $3 million. * Heinz U.S.A., Pittsburgh, to J. Brown/LMC Group, Stamford, Conn., as the first agency to handle programs that combine advertising and retail promotion for its Heinz Ketchup, Heinz 57 Steak Sauce and Heinz Homestyle gravy brands. J. Brown joins agencies on Heinz's roster like the Pittsburgh and San Francisco offices of Ketchum Advertising. The billings were not disclosed.

title: International Briefs; BMW's Profit Rises 35%
description: The German car maker Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G., or BMW, said yesterday that its net income increased 35 percent in 1994 to 697 million marks ($505 million), from 516 million ($374 million), far exceeding most analysts' expectations. The 1994 net profit figure includes 12 million marks from BMW's acquisition of the Rover Group of Britain. As reported earlier, BMW's 1994 sales increased 45 percent, to 42.1 billion marks, helped by the first-time inclusion of the Rover unit.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Scary Mountain Fall Leaves Street Bruised
description: The American downhill champion PICABO STREET escaped with only bruising after a terrifying fall yesterday in a super-giant slalom race at the World Cup finals in Bormio, Italy. United States Ski Team officials said Street was flown by helicopter to a hospital in the town of Sondalo, 12 miles from Bormio, after the crash, but was allowed to return to the team hotel later.

title: A Stop Sign for the Yankee Regulars
description: The commissioner's office has informed the Yankees that several striking major leaguers must stop working out at the minor league complex here because it is a violation of league policy. The Yankees, who have allowed some major leaguers to use the facilities since January, had not fully heeded the demand by today.

title: Worthington Industries(WTHG,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Duff & Phelps Merger With Govett Collapses
description: Govett & Company Ltd. and the Duff & Phelps Corporation broke off a $230 million merger agreement today that would have created one of the largest global investment-management firms.

title: Arizona Waiting Game Benefits Miami of Ohio
description: The University of Arizona's Damon Stoudamire was eligible today, but the result was the same as the one last Saturday, when he sat out a one-game suspension: defeat.

title: On Stage, and Off; Donald G. McNeil Jr.
description: Getting Your Irish On

title: Destructive Tuition Hikes
description: Politicians in Albany have discovered to their distress that slashing state aid to New York State's public higher education system would require closing down programs and even campuses as well as stiff tuition increases. The Legislature thus appears ready to restore some of the disproportionate cuts imposed on higher education in Gov. George Pataki's budget. Whatever else is done, the priority should be to ease up on the huge tuition increases proposed by Mr. Pataki and academic leaders -- even if that means cutting academic programs.

title: On My Mind; Kisses for Castro
description: No question at all, it was a real fun time for the hosts and the guest at the combination house party and political fund-raiser the Mitterrands threw in Paris for Fidel Castro.

title: A Valentine to the Perils of Film Making
description: AN inspired choice opens this year's New Directors/New Films series tonight: "Living in Oblivion," Tom DiCillo's wonderfully funny behind-the-scenes look at the perils of film making, no-budget style. While he nominally presents the directing process as a series of hellish travails, Mr. DiCillo captures such delicious mischief that his indictment becomes a valentine.

title: New Directors/New Films Schedule
description: The New Directors/New Films series, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the department of film at the Museum of Modern Art, opens today and runs through April 2. Screenings are in the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1 at the museum, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan.

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: Courtaulds P.L.C., a British chemical company, said its joint venture with Japan's Nippon Paint Co. would buy a privately owned German chemical coatings company for an undisclosed sum. Courtaulds Nippon Paint Ltd. will acquire Mehnert & Veeck G.m.b.H. for cash. The sale, to be completed on April 1, is subject to approval from the German cartel office.

title: Note Indicates Resignation Of Anita Hill
description: Prof. Anita F. Hill, who testified that Clarence Thomas had sexually harassed her while they both worked in the Federal Government, is planning to leave her tenured job at the University of Oklahoma, where she teaches law, according to a memorandum circulated by the law school dean. But university officials said yesterday that they had not received any official notification of this.

title: Two Youths Sentenced to Prison For Attack on Homeless People
description: Lamenting the heartlessness of teen-agers who would attack "the powerless," a judge in Manhattan yesterday gave the maximum sentence of three and a third to seven years to two youths convicted of setting fire to a cardboard box in which a homeless man was sleeping.

title: Prices Rise for Natural Gas On Report of Increased Demand
description: Natural gas prices surged almost 8 percent yesterday, after an industry report showed more gas was taken out of storage last week than anticipated. Gasoline and crude oil prices also rose.

title: INSIDE
description: Protest by Vietnamese

title: A Novel About a Novelist and His Messy Life
description: WONDER BOYS By Michael Chabon 368 pages. Villard Books. $23.

title: Pitching Camp Where the Old Soldiers Live On
description: Here towered Patton, binoculars in hand, vigilant against an unseen enemy. Or perhaps, as West Point lore has it, looking for the library. There stood bronzed MacArthur, defiant, campaign jacket flung over an arm. And the five-star Ike, businesslike, hands on his hips, gazing over the Plain.

title: Doubletree Hotels To Withdraw Spot
description: The Doubletree Hotels Corporation said yesterday that it would withdraw, effective immediately, a television commercial deemed offensive by a Muslim-American organization.

title: People
description: * Arthur Selkowitz, executive vice president and worldwide account director on the Procter & Gamble account at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, was promoted to president of D.M.B.& B./Asia-Pacific. He succeeds John C. Ferries, who continues as president of D.M.B.& B./Americas and overseeing the agency company's public relations subsidiary, Manning, Selvage & Lee.

title: Ireland's Great Hunger, 1845-1849
description: This was a fine spring in Ireland 150 years ago. By summer, farmers were forecasting an abundant potato crop of "the most luxuriant character." But in September came the first reports of a disease that could blacken crops overnight and putrefy an entire field within days. Ireland's eight million people were overwhelmingly reliant on potatoes.

title: Melvin Glasser, 79, Supervisor Of Field Trials of Salk Vaccine
description: Melvin A. Glasser, a former director of the Health Security Action Council who supervised the medical field trials for the anti-polio Salk vaccine, died on Monday at Washington Home in Washington. He was 79.

title: The Melancholy Images That Made an Era Real
description: The first task some viewers will face when they look at the photographs in "Dorothea Lange: American Images," the stirring exhibition now at the International Center of Photography, is to strip the pictures of their dulling glaze of fame. Lange had an astonishing ability to make images that summed up the terrible impact of the Depression of the 1930's on people's lives, and many of the pictures here have become classics, not only of photography but of the history of America.

title: Republicans Lop $100 Billion from Budgets to Pay for Tax Cuts
description: Much as they have promised for months, Republicans on the House Budget Committee voted today to lop $100 billion from future Federal budgets to pay for a hefty chunk of the tax relief promised in their Contract With America.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MOTOR WHEEL CORP., Lansing, Mich., a manufacturer of steel and aluminum wheels, said it would shut its Lansing plant in the next 10 to 12 months. The closing will affect 165 of the company's 1,550 employees. TRIANGLE CORP., Stamford, Conn., which makes chemicals and other products, said its shareholders had approved a merger with Audits and Surveys Inc., a market research company.

title: U.S. Dealt Setback in Effort to Curb Dinosaur Fossil Hunters
description: In a setback for Federal prosecutors seeking to curb the activities of commercial excavators and dealers in valuable fossils, a jury in Rapid City, S.D., has acquitted a group of South Dakota dinosaur hunters of most of the 149 felony charges that had been brought against them.

title: A Little Boy and a Plot Worthy of Solomon
description: Hot-button social issues are usually the province of television movies, but "Losing Isaiah" deserves its status as a feature film. This drama about interracial adoption is serious and affecting, thanks in large part to the presence of its two magnetic stars. Duly positioned on opposite sides of this central issue, both Jessica Lange and Halle Berry breathe real life into their debating positions, which are well articulated by the material. The tone is thoughtful and temperate. Only once does anyone exclaim, "What about love?"

title: Yesterday in Washington
description: G.O.P. SUCCESS IN HOUSE -- House Republicans advanced their Contract With America on two fronts, with the full House voting to approve $17.3 billion in cuts in the current budget and the Budget Committee sending to the floor a plan that would reduce Federal spending by nearly $200 billion over five years to pay for a promised tax cut. A CONTRACT VICTORY -- The House approved a bill requiring the Federal Government to pay for carrying out many rules and regulations it imposes on states and localities. The vote was 394 to 28, with Democrats casting all the votes against it. The bill was approved by the Senate on Wednesday by 91 to 9, and President Clinton is expected to sign it.

title: Big Tax Preparers Accused of Misleading Ads
description: The nation's largest tax preparation company, H & R Block, and two other tax preparation companies were charged yesterday by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs with deceptive advertising and misleading the public about their electronic filing and rapid refund services.

title: Ruling Keeps Alive Hopes for Bronx Railyard
description: A judge's ruling has revived the possibility that a moribund railyard in the South Bronx could be turned into a major center for transfering freight from trains to trucks.

title: Art in Review
description: Frank Stella Gagosian Gallery 136 Wooster Street SoHo Through April 15

title: Officer Reports Death Threats
description: A black East Orange police officer says he has received death threats because he worked to calm citizens in Paterson after a black teen-ager was killed by a white officer last month.

title: Javits Center Figures Blame Each Other
description: The former head of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and a local labor leader pointed fingers at each other yesterday for appointing two men said to have ties to organized-crime figures to head the carpenters union at the convention center.

title: En Route the Night the Lights Went Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Happy Returns for LaFontaine
description: This is what the fans up here have been waiting for the past 16 months for.

title: ROUSSEL UCLAF TO BUY LATIN DRUG UNIT OF DOW
description: The French drug maker Roussel Uclaf S. A. said yesterday that it planned to acquire the Latin American pharmaceutical operations of the Dow Chemical Company for $200 million. Roussel Uclaf said the deal would occur in conjunction with the planned $7.1 billion purchase of Marion Merrell Dow Inc., the pharmaceutical arm of Dow, by the German chemical company Hoechst A. G., the parent of Roussel Uclaf. Dow Chemical, of Midland, Mich., owns 72 percent of Marion Merrell Dow.

title: Robbins & Myers Inc.(ROBN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Robbins & Myers said that results in the latest second quarter and 6 months included the operations of Pfaudler, Chemineer and Edlon, acquired in July 1994.

title: Deal for SFX Still Possible
description: The Chancellor Holdings Corporation, a privately held radio broadcasting company, said today that it was still interested in acquiring SFX Broadcasting Inc. despite the company's rejection of Chancellor's $160 million bid earlier in the day.

title: First Union to Sell Annuities at Branches
description: The already weakened barriers between banks and insurance companies were further breached yesterday, when the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., announced plans to license 800 of its employees to sell annuities through its branch offices.

title: 50-Off Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Included pretax charges of $ 5.1 million in the quarter and $ 6.1 million in the year for costs related to the closing of seven stores in fiscal 1995 and 12 stores to be closed in fiscal 1996. The charges include $ 836,000 for inventory valuation adjustments related to the 10 stores the company is closing during the first quarter of fiscal 1996.c-After a charge of $ 3,404,000, or 33 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.The latest periods included one extra week in the quarter and year.(Loss)

title: Producer of Auto Show Details The Steep Cost of Javits Center
description: Anyone who thinks automobile prices are high may want to listen to Mark Schienberg, an executive producer of the New York Auto Show. He knows about sticker shock, too.

title: Tongue Found to Hold Natural Antibiotics
description: In a significant finding about the body's natural defenses, scientists have found that the tongue harbors natural antibiotic substances that protect cuts from being infected by the billions of microbes that infest the mouth.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Rodman a No-Show, but Spurs Beat 76ers David Robinson had 26 points and 11 rebounds in three quarters as the San Antonio Spurs -- playing without Dennis Rodman, the National Basketball Association's leading rebounder -- beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 112-86, last night in San Antonio. Rodman arrived in the Spurs locker room at the beginning of the second quarter. He never emerged from the locker room during the game. J. R. Reid, starting for Rodman, had 16 points and 7 rebounds. Dana Barros led the 76ers with 17 points. The Spurs led by as many as 31 points in the third quarter, and San Antonio Coach Bob Hill benched Robinson and his other starters with 3 minutes 15 seconds remaining in the third. (AP)

title: Death Penalty II
