description: Tara VanDerveer not only has a big, fast and smart Stanford basketball team going to the Final Four to meet unbeaten Connecticut this week, but the head coach of the Cardinal has the friendship and guidance of one of the game's most astute teachers, Pete Newell.

title: International Briefs; Pirelli Has a Profit
description: The Italian tire and cable maker Pirelli S.p.A. said yesterday that it had earned a profit last year, its first since 1990. The return to profitability was a result of a reorganization that ended in 1993, in which Pirelli sold all its noncore businesses. A 5.9 percent rise in car sales in Europe in 1994 also played a part. The profit was 110 billion lire, or $65 million, in contrast to a loss of 62 billion lire in 1993. From 1991 through 1993, Pirelli had losses totaling almost 229 billion lire.

title: Panel Backs Tagamet Use in Treatment of Heartburn
description: A panel of scientists recommended unanimously yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration allow a much less potent form of the ulcer drug Tagamet to be sold without prescription for the treatment of heartburn.

title: Clarcor Inc.(CLC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 4
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 630,000, or 4 cents a share.Clarcor said it anticipates capital expenditures in fiscal 1995 of about $ 15.5 million, up from $ 11.4 million in fiscal 1994, primarily to expand manufacturing capacity for both the filtration products group and consumer products groups, and to continue productivity improvement programs.The company also said its goal for the rest of fiscal 1995 is to increase earnings from operations by 10 percent to 15 percent. This increase would be entirely driven by growth in the company's current businesses.

title: Altschiller in a Split With Liz Claiborne
description: Altschiller & Company in New York and Liz Claiborne Inc. said yesterday that after eight years they had parted ways on the company's apparel and fragrance account, with billings estimated at $8 million.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: European Championship

title: 2 California Health Care Providers Agree to a $1.8 Billion Merger
description: Two big California health maintenance organizations, Wellpoint Health Networks and Health Systems International have agreed to a $1.8 billion stock swap that would create the biggest stockholder-owned H.M.O. in the lucrative California market and the fifth largest in the country, people close to the deal said yesterday.

title: Chess
description: Viswanathan Anand of India has defeated Gata Kamsky of Brooklyn to become the challenger who will face Gary Kasparov for the Professional Chess Association's world championship. The two will meet in a title match, starting on Sept. 10, in Cologne, Germany.

title: Women in Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title: T. G. Gradnauer, 54, Teacher of the Deaf
description: Thomas George Gradnauer, an advocate for and teacher of the deaf, died on Sunday at his home in Ewing, N.J. He was 54.

title: Maple Leaf Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Included in sales and operating earnings are sales of serviced lots from its real estate development in Maple, Ont. of $ 25.1 million in latest period, compared with $ 9.7 million in year-ago period.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges with the ticker symbol MLF.The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Olbermann Puts His Serious Side on the Shelf
description: Keith Olbermann, ESPN's black-belt wiseacre and chief nasty boy, hates replacement baseball, detests those who may play it come opening day Sunday, and makes clear that he will mock, mock, mock, till the major leaguers return.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Volkswagen propels Arnold Fortuna from dark horse to hot shop.
description: VOLKSWAGEN OF AMERICA wrote a startling end to its review yesterday by selecting the dark horse among four finalist agencies to handle its North American account, with billings estimated at $90 million to $110 million.

title: Court to Review Forfeiture in Drug Case
description: The Supreme Court said today it would decide whether criminal defendants who agree as part of guilty pleas to forfeit their property to the Government are entitled to procedural protections, including a jury trial on the amount to be forfeited.

title: Senate Offers Twist on Plan For Curbing Federal Rules
description: The Senate today debated a new twist on efforts to curb Federal regulations: a proposal to give Congress a quick opportunity to review and possibly overturn new rules as soon as they are issued by Government agencies.

title: Lockout Doubt Builds Beyond Steinbrenner
description: George Steinbrenner swooped into the Yankees' spring training complex here today sounding extremely edgy about voting to lock out major leaguers if the National Labor Relations Board obtains an injunction that would prompt the players to scrap their strike.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Beggars Can't Be Choosy, So They Choose PATH
description: JOEL B. has become a reverse commuter. He used to ask for money on the subways in Manhattan. Now he takes the PATH train to Hoboken and works the teeming masses here.

title: In Hometowns, Spy Charges By Baghdad Are Rejected
description: This Iowa town was draped in yellow ribbons today in a gesture of support for its native son, William Barloon, who with another American, David Daliberti, has been sentenced to an eight-year prison term in Iraq after their puzzling foray into that country two weeks ago.

title: George Names an Editor
description: Eric Etheridge, executive editor of The New York Observer and a former senior editor at Rolling Stone, will be the editor of George, a political magazine being introduced in September, the magazine's editor in chief, John F. Kennedy Jr., announced on Friday. George is jointly owned by by Hachette Filipacchi Magazines and Random Ventures, a company owned by the magazine's co-founders, Mr. Kennedy and Michael Berman. Mr. Kennedy said Matt Berman, art director of Metropolitan Home, would be the art director of George. The Bermans are not related.

title: Turning Up The Sound And the Beat
description: Veruca Salt was slightly defensive at the Academy on Friday night. Nina Gordon and Louise Post -- its guitarists, singers and songwriters -- formed Veruca Salt in Chicago in 1993 and had a hit single, "Seether," and a major-label contract by the end of 1994. The band arrived in the wake of the Breeders, who use a similar combination of breezy voices and muscular guitars, and its fast ascent drew suspicion from an alternative-rock scene that's both wary and jealous of commercial success. "I hope we're worth the hype," Ms. Post said as the set ended.

title: Housing Voucher Test in Maryland Is Scuttled by a Political Firestorm
description: The theory was elegant, the outcome anything but.

title: Dr. James Coleman, 68, Dies; Work Helped to Foster Busing
description: Dr. James S. Coleman, the renowned University of Chicago sociologist whose controversial studies laid much of the groundwork for and against the use of busing to desegregate schools in the 1960's and 1970's, and later helped shape American education policies by comparing public and private schools, died on Saturday at the University of Chicago Hospital. He was 68.

title: Return of the Winners From Westwood
description: Welcome back to the U.C.L.A. Invitational, and thanks for all your patience during our decade and a half of nagging scheduling difficulties.

title: Robinson 40 Pace Spurs' 8th in Row
description: Spurs 114, Pistons 93

title: Market Place; Equifax's expansion in medical data is seen as a healthy move.
description: AFTER Equifax Inc. announced a deal earlier this month with the AT&T Corporation to provide expanded services by the consumer data agency's budding health care information unit, Equifax's stock edged up to a high of $33.50 a share. It has remained near there, as many analysts continue to rate it a buy.

title: Alpine Lace Brands Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring charge and write-down of Mountain Farms Inc., totaling $ 4,158,000.Alpine Lace Brands said 1993 and 1994 operations excluded the results of its Mountain Farms Inc. unit. Figures for 1993 included $ 1,061,000 in income tax benefits. Figures for 1994 included no income taxes benefits.The company said its net income before the charge and write-down totaled $ 1,035,000, or 21 cents a share.Of the charge, Alpine Lace took $ 1,512,000 in noncash charges to write off its Marolf Dakota Farms Inc. trademark and packaging equipment. The company closed its skim milk cheese production facility at the unit.The company also took noncash charges of $ 1,071,000 to sell a 65 percent stake in its Mountain Farms unit and $ 450,000 to settle the unit's inventory and accounts receivable guarantees.The charge for the quarter also reflected $ 55,000 in termination pay obligations and an accrual of $ 1,070,000, payable over 26 months, to terminate its supply and conversion agreement with the Mountain Farms unit.(Loss)

title: Blenheim Group PLC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring charge of $ 6.2 million.

title: Mayor Asks Broad Powers Over Fulton Fish Market
description: The Giuliani administration, unveiling details of plans to rid the Fulton Fish Market of mobsters and corruption, yesterday asked the City Council for broad powers to determine who can do business and who can work at the market.

title: Mr. Exon's Foolish Farewell
description: Senator James Exon has already announced his retirement, but rather than going harmlessly, he has decided to leave behind one truly bad idea that will cause mischief for years to come. The Senate Commerce Committee, eager to share in the foolishness, voted last week without hearings or argument for Senator Exon's plan to outlaw "indecency" in communications by computer.

title: Gendis Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Gramm Sees Effort To Deny Him a Spot On New York Ballot
description: Senator Phil Gramm of Texas brought his fledgling Presidential campaign to Manhattan yesterday, saying he was optimistic about gathering support here even though virtually every Republican leader in New York State backs Senator Bob Dole.

title: Garden's March Madness: Jordan in Town
description: It will have the drama of a playoff game and the glitter of a Hollywood premiere, with celebrities filling the courtside seats.

title: It's Natives vs. Newcomers Down in the Worm World
description: AS the ground warms up across North America, billions of earthworms are uncoiling from the little balls of dormancy in which they have spent the winter and are once again renewing the vitality of forest, field and garden.

title: Southern Co.(SO,N) reports earnings for 12mos to Feb 28
description: The latest year included after-tax charges of $ 10 million and the 1994 year included after-tax charges of $ 51 million, both related to system work-force reduction programs.Revenue is operating revenue.

title: Iraq's American Hostages
description: Iraq has handed down unjustifiable eight-year sentences for two Americans who trespassed on its territory. Their imprisonment poses a delicate diplomatic problem for President Clinton. Already Republican Presidential hopefuls have called for forceful action to free the men. In coming weeks the easing of economic sanctions on Iraq will come before the United Nations Security Council.

title: Employee Owners Still Need Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Speeds Cases From Police to Prosecutor
description: In a cramped warren of offices at Queens Borough Hall in Kew Gardens, old ways bump up against the new in a little-known but crucial corner of the criminal justice system.

title: Kaneb Services Inc.(KAB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 15.1 million, or 47 cents a share, on issuance of units by partnership. Before the gain, loss was 1 cent a share.Regarding the latest periods' results--After payment of $ 387,000 for preferred stock dividends, loss applicable to common stock was $ 274,000, in the quarter, and after payment of $ 1,489,000 for preferred stock dividends, net income applicable to common stock was $ 546,000, in the year.For the year-ago periods, after payment of $ 348,000 for preferred stock dividends, net income applicable to common stock was $ 599,000, in the quarter, and after payment of $ 1,451,000 for preferred stock dividends, net income applicable to common stock was $ 14,703,000, in the year.(Loss)

title: The Nets' Good Soldier, Williams Is Now Fed Up
description: In the middle of all the verbal grievances filed by their players this season -- and there have been many -- Jayson Williams was one of the few employees the Nets could count on not to complain about his job description.

title: INSIDE
description: Vacancy at Federal Reserve

title: Was It Fumes (or Faking)?
description: About two dozen students and teachers at Junior High School 210 in Woodhaven, Queens, may have thought they were suffering another attack yesterday of the noxious mace-like fumes that spread through the school last Friday. Either that, or they wanted to get the day off, the authorities said.

title: Small Machines Make Big Strides
description: LITTLE computers are always compromises. Subnotebook models, the size of a couple of computer magazines, have been as remarkable for what the manufacturers leave out as for what they put in. But manufacturers keep finding new ways to break miniaturization's bounds.

title: Congoleum Corp.(CGM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 800,000 in after-tax recoveries of legal fees connected with settlement of a lawsuit in both the quarter and year. The year also included an elimination of related party interest expense paid to Congoleum Holdings.c-Included $ 2 million in after-tax accelerated amortization of debt issuance costs and original issue discount associated with debt repaid in February 1994, and an after-tax gain of $ 600,000 from the sale of a trademark. The periods also included an elimination of related party interest expense paid to Congoleum Holdings.Year-ago results reflect the 10 months ended Dec. 31, 1993, as the company adopted a calendar reporting year effective Feb. 28, 1993.Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the effect of the company's recapitalization completed Feb. 8, 1995.Year-ago shares outstanding included the dilutive effect of warrants repurchased in February 1994.Upon completion of a public offering of class A common stock on Feb. 8, 1995, Congoleum Corp. recapitalized and implemented a plan of repurchase of its class B shares. Pursuant to the repurchase plan, Congoleum Holdings, a former parent holding company, was merged into Congoleum Corp. The company's financial results are presented as if Congoleum Holdings and Congoleum Corp. were combined as of Feb. 26, 1993, the date of formation of Congoleum Holdings.

title: Impressive Reports, To Stay And to Go
description: YOU are showing the first-quarter sales surge to the board of directors on the 21-inch monitor of a computer running Microsoft Windows 3.1. Cheerfully colored words appear on the screen, remain long enough for even a director to read and slide off to be replaced with a bar chart, then a brief video of the C.E.O. with a snippet of upbeat melody.

title: National Education Corp.(NEC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax net charge of $ 471,000, or 2 cents a share. Items included a pretax charge of $ 2,623,000 from amortization of the company's deferred marketing balance; and a pretax gain of $ 2,152,000 from selling and promotion spending ''below the amortization that would have been expensed in accordance with the company's previous accounting policy.''c-Included pretax net charge of $ 27,410,000, or 72 cents a share. Items included cumulative pretax charge of $ 19,836,000 from amortization of the company's deferred marketing balance; and a pretax charge of $ 7,574,000 from selling and promotion spending ''below the amortization that would have been expenses in accordance with the company's previous accounting policy.''d-Included pretax charge of $ 9,232,000, or 22 cents a share, from write-down of certain intangible assets acquired in the company's 1986 acquisition of Deltak; an after-tax gain of $ 21,260,000, or 71 cents a share, from the company's initial public offering of about 18 percent of its Steck-Vaughn unit's common shares; and a pretax charge of $ 23,626,000, or 55 cents a share, from write-down of certain assets and closing of 14 schools.(Loss)

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday about market trends over the last six months included an incorrect figure supplied by Salomon Brothers Inc. for the dividend yield of the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday. The yield was 2.64 percent, not 0.03 percent.

title: Lazard Freres Units Form New Partnership
description: The three Lazard Freres partnerships have banded together to form a new partnership, Lazard Capital Markets, to enhance their financing and trading operations in Europe and in emerging markets.

title: U.S. Denies 2 Americans Entered Iraq As Saboteurs
description: The Clinton Administration today rejected assertions from Baghdad that two Americans being held prisoner there had crossed into Iraq as saboteurs or spies.

title: Injunction Hearing Set; Clubs Offer New Plan
description: In the most active day-night doubleheader baseball may see all year, a Federal judge yesterday scheduled a hearing for Friday on a request for an injunction that the players say would end their seven-and-a-half-month strike, and the owners last night presented the players union with a new proposal they believe should end the strike.

title: Allen Officially a Saint
description: ERIC ALLEN, a Pro Bowl cornerback, is now a New Orleans Saint. The Philadelphia Eagles informed the Saints yesterday that they would not match New Orleans's offer to Allen, reportedly worth more than $14 million. Allen was designated as a transition player by the Eagles.

title: Zofar Journal; Israel's Crops in Jordan's Fields? It Must Be Peace
description: With a small Jordanian flag on the windshield, Nissim Douek recently drove his dusty station wagon across the border to work his fields in territory that was handed back to Jordan under a peace treaty with Israel.

title: Leucadia National Corp.(LUK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 129,195,000, or $ 4.41 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Leucadia National said that it had $ 12,004,000 in securities losses in the latest year, compared with securities gains of $ 51,923,000 in the 1993 year. For the quarterly periods, there were $ 1,883,000 in securities gains in the latest fourth quarter, against $ 5,486,000 in securities gains in the year-ago period.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Lightning Tops Canadiens in Overtime Petr Klima scored on a breakaway 2 minutes 23 seconds into overtime last night, giving the Tampa Bay Lightning a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens, who lost their eighth straight road game. Tampa Bay ended its five-game home losing streak. Klima took a pass from Brian Bradley and skated in on Patrick Roy, faking to his backhand and sliding the puck inside the right post. Mark Recchi scored his ninth and 10th goals for Montreal. (AP)

title: Jury Still Out in Bribery Case
description: Jurors in the bribery trial of two Newark politicians did not reach a verdict yesterday in their first day of deliberations in Federal District Court. The jurors asked for transcripts of testimony about a meeting at a restaurant during which, the prosecution contends, Councilman Gary Harris, one of the defendants, accepted a $3,000 cash bribe. Mr. Harris and the other defendant, former Councilman Ralph T. Grant Jr., are accused of accepting tens of thousands of dollars in return for helping a towing company try to obtain municipal contracts.

title: New York Democrats See 'Nightmare' in Republican Welfare Bill
description: The welfare bill passed in the House last week would push more than half of all New York City children receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children off the welfare rolls and would cost city residents $6 billion in aid over the next five years, according to New York Democrats.

title: Redskins Re-sign Back
description: The Washington Redskins re-signed running back and kick return specialist BRIAN MITCHELL yesterday to a three-year deal worth $4.2 million, which includes a $1.5 million signing bonus. Mitchell set or tied six team records in 1994 and also set an National Football League record for combined punt and kickoff return yardage with 1,930 yards. Earlier yesterday, the Redskins lost a pair of free agents as guards RALEIGH McKENZIE and MARK SCHLERETH signed with Philadelphia and Denver, respectively. (AP)

title: In 6-Day Offensive, Algerians Step Up War on the Rebels
description: Algeria's special forces have killed between 300 and 600 Islamic militants in the last six days, creating the biggest military engagement in three years of strife between the two sides and suggesting that the rebels' military sophistication is increasing even as their losses are widening.

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: * MGM Grand Inc., the hotel-casino company, will buy the Diamond Beach Hotel and Casino in Darwin, Australia, for about $75 million, including the assumption of debt. MGM said the resort, on 100 beachfront acres, includes a public casino, a private gaming operation and about 100 rooms. * Marks & Spencer, Britain's biggest clothing retailer and the parent of Brooks Brothers, said yesterday that it planned to expand into Germany and China.

title: Drivers File Appeal
description: Both the Williams and Benetton Formula One teams have lodged appeals after disqualifications for using illegal fuel wiped out their 1-2 finish Sunday at the Brazilian Grand Prix.

title: And the Winners Are. . .
description: BEST ACTOR Tom Hanks who starred in "Forrest Gump" won the best actor award. BEST ACTRESS Jessica Lange won best actress award for "Blue Sky".

title: Fed Governor to Step Down; Clinton Gets a 3d Vacancy
description: John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve Board governor with a reputation for favoring higher interest rates and opposing the Clinton Administration's banking policies, announced his resignation today, to take effect April 30.

title: A Dispute Over Hearing Aids
description: A man charged with sexually assaulting a 2-year-old girl maintains that any statement he made to officers should be suppressed because he wears hearing aids in both ears and no qualified interpreter was present. The lawyer for the man, Bryan Rosolen, 37, of Kinnelon, said his client understands less than half of what is said to him. But the Morris County Prosecutor, Leslie Wade, said that Mr. Rosolen does not qualify as hearing-impaired under a 1984 state statute that says statements by such a person cannot be used against him unless an interpreter is present and the statement was made "knowingly, voluntarily and intelligently." Mr. Roselon is free on $50,000 bail.

title: River Blindness Disease Has 2d Devastating Side
description: The skin disease associated with river blindness, the debilitating parasitic affliction that affects millions of people in tropical Africa, has more serious consequences than previously believed and should be attacked as a separate health problem, a new study has found.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Three rare gold trinkets stolen on Friday evening from the National Geographic Society's museum in Washington were recovered last weekend.

title: Science Times E-Mail
description: Science Times has an electronic mail address for comments from readers about published articles and suggested areas of coverage:

title: What's the Big Trend? It's No Trend
description: Trends in fashion are a bit like the aroma of good food, drawing women to the table: once there they may pass over the very pungent goodies that attracted them for more palatable and familiar fare.

title: Damage to Conner's Keel May Hurt Cup Hopes, Too
description: The fact that Dennis Conner doesn't know how to swim didn't help his peace of mind Sunday when his America's Cup yacht, Stars & Stripes, started taking on water during a race with Young America.

title: Debussy and Ravel, All Day and All Ways
description: Debussy and Ravel are as inseparable as any two composers in the whole binary firmament of music. It becomes an interesting exercise to try to separate them. There are, of course, historical, biographical and stylistic distinctions to be made. There are also vagaries of taste: are you a Debussy person or a Ravel person? A random telephone poll might favor Ravel by a slight margin. Debussy takes historical precedence, but Ravel gets under the skin.

title: How Do You Stop Agonizing Pain In an Arm That No Longer Exists? A Scientist Does It With Mirrors
description: THE third time he lost his left arm, Derek Steen yelped with joy. He could not believe his good fortune.

title: As TV Sows Outrage, Guess What It Reaps
description: Although the producers of "The Jenny Jones Show" did not take credit for the murder of Scott Amedure after he revealed during a taping that he had a crush on Jonathan Schmitz, the event was a new peak for confrontation television: a small truth followed by the ultimate consequence.

title: The Game's First True Big Man; Kurland, 6-10 1/2, Led Oklahoma State's Predecessor to the 1945 Title
description: He was the first true big man of basketball, a Hall of Famer who won two national collegiate titles, two Olympic gold medals and became a legend not only in his home state but also around the world. And now that another gentle giant is leading his alma mater to this year's Final Four, Bob Kurland is again surrounded by tall tales.

title: Value Health Plans to Buy Diagnostek In Stock Swap
description: Value Health Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy Diagnostek Inc., a prescription drug benefits manager, for stock currently valued at about $500 million.

title: WALGREEN COMPANY (WAG,N)
description: The Walgreen Company said yesterday that its earnings increased 14 percent in its second quarter, bolstered by strong growth of prescription-drug sales.

title: Hunter College Selects Midwestern Dean and Professor as Its New President
description: A Midwestern educator whose interests range from Italian culture to the financing of American political campaigns was selected yesterday as Hunter College's new president.

title: On My Mind; The Limp Noodle
description: At least this much can be said about a new human rights initiative of the Clinton Administration: There are people in the Government who understood and argued that it was an embarrassing piece of hypocrisy, saying much, meaning nothing, fooling nobody.

title: Stocks Set New Marks Amid Questions on Durability of the Rally
description: Stocks hit record levels once again yesterday, even as analysts questioned whether the rally could last.

title: Delay in Postal-Killings Case
description: A bail hearing for Christopher Green, 29, accused of fatally shooting four men and wounding another last week at a Montclair post office, was postponed yesterday. The reason for the delay, at the request of Mr. Green's court-appointed lawyer, was not given. Mr. Green's next court appearance is scheduled for tomorrow. In East Orange, meanwhile, 400 people filled the Messiah Baptist Church for the funeral of Ernest Spruill, 56, the last of the four slain men to be buried.

title: In Praise of Greedy Lawyers
description: Tort reform, a rallying cry of the Republican revolution, has hit upon a scapegoat with unlikely mass appeal. Contingency-fee lawyers, blamed as the root evil of our litigious society, have been socked with the "Attorneys Accountability Act," one of three legal reform bills passed by the House this month. The Senate is scheduled to begin debating its own, related bills next week.

title: Bank Stocks Up On Merger Talk
description: Shares of Mitsubishi Bank and Bank of Tokyo surged today following reports by Japanese news agencies that the two giant Japanese commercial banks had agreed to merge.

title: Price of Independence; A Disabled Man's Quest to Be Free
description: He is confined to a wheelchair. He cannot speak or write. He needs help eating, dressing and going to the bathroom. Yet Donald Jantzen wants to leave home.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about the dismantling of border controls by 7 of the 15 European Union members mislabeled Switzerland. It is not a member of the European Union.

title: Shares of American Express Surge After Buyback Plan
description: Shares of the American Express Company surged yesterday after the company said it would buy back as much as 8 percent of its common stock.

title: Coastal Healthcare Group Inc.(DR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring charges totaling $ 1,250,000 in both the quarter and year; acquisition related expenses of $ 2,500,000, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 8,209,000, or 37 cents a share, in the year. The year also included unrealized loss on securities investment of $ 393,000, or 2 cents a share.c-Included acquisition and related expenses of $ 1,350,000, or 7 cents a share.Latest and year-ago net income are pro-forma and assumed status as ''S'' corporation prior to mergers.Year-ago results are restated to include Health Enterprises Inc., Southeast Health Systems Inc., Medical Associates Systems Inc. and related companies.Coastal Healthcare Group said nonpro-forma fourth quarter net income fell to $ 4,631,000, or 20 cents a share, from $ 6,998,000, or 35 cents a share, in year-ago period.Coastal Healthcare said nonpro-forma 1994 net income fell to $ 20,668,000, or 92 cents a share, from $ 34,303,000, or 1.27 cents a share, in 1993.

title: Testing for Cancer Risks
description: Genetic tests that can tell if you are likely to get cancer are moving rapidly into the marketplace before there is a medical consensus on their value or how to use them. The swift advance has understandably alarmed leading authorities on ethics and medicine. But many people will no doubt feel, as we do, that any information that can give them a head start in fighting a dreaded disease is more a blessing than a cause for fear.

title: Bank Robberies Soaring Despite the Risks
description: One summer night here in 1934, the defiant John Dillinger watched his last picture show, "Manhattan Melodrama," before walking out of the Biograph Theater into a deadly hail of bullets -- an example of the perils of robbing banks for a living.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about the four victims of the post office shootings in Montclair, N.J., reversed two names in some editions. The bearded white man was Stanley Scott Walensky; the mustached white man was Robert Leslie. The two other victims were correctly identified: George Lomago was the clean-shaven white man and Ernest Spruill was the black man with a mustache.

title: Nigeria Accused of a 2-Year War on Ethnic Group
description: Two years ago, when a handful of villages were destroyed and residents began fleeing a wave of killings in the oil-producing Niger River Delta country near this small town, the Government and refugees gave starkly different explanations of the violence.

title: Ito Rules Simpson Guest To Be a 'Hostile' Witness
description: The Deputy District Attorney, Marcia Clark, persuaded Judge Lance A. Ito to declare Brian (Kato) Kaelin a hostile witness today, as opposing lawyers leaned on Mr. Kaelin to present his imprecise and inarticulate memories about O. J. and Nicole Brown Simpson in the starkest, most partisan light possible.

title: With All His Rainbows, Thurman's a Rainmaker
description: The Final Four nets might as well be chain-link, because Scotty Thurman still thinks he's at West Side Park. He was a preteen one day when the 16-year-olds in Ruston, La., shouted, "Clear out," and shoved him the basketball. "To test my manhood," he said. The score was 11-11, the game was to 12, and Scotty Thurman let go with a rainbow that is still his patent a decade later.

title: Welfare Bill Is Attacked
description: More than 280,000 of the 540,000 children in New York City receiving welfare would be pushed off the roles under the House bill, a report by a Democrat says. Page B9.

title: Entergy Corp.(ETR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charges of $ 44.8 million, or 20 cents a share, from merger and restructuring costs, New Orleans Public Service settlement, site closure and other costs.c-Included charges of $ 154.3 million, or 68 cents a share, from merger and restructuring costs, deferred tax adjustments, New Orleans Public Service settlement, site closure and other costs.d-Net incomee-Included gains of $ 80.6 million, or 47 cents a share, from unbilled revenues, offset by adoption of SFAS 109.(Loss)Entergy said that its Gulf States Utilities unit received on March 20 a final order from the Public Utility Commission of Texas, reducing Gulf States' rates. The final order required Entergy to establish a 1994 refund reserve of $ 54.7 million.With this final order, Entergy now reports results for 1994's fourth quarter and year, with revenues reduced by $ 54.7 million and net income reduced by $ 32.9 million. Above are the final consolidated results for 1994, compared with 1993.

title: Skin Lesions Were Removed During President's Checkup
description: President Clinton had several precancerous skin lesions removed from his forehead and behind his ear during his annual medical checkup on Friday, the White House said yesterday.

title: High Court to Decide Case on Drug Testing of School Athletes
description: The question of random drug testing reached the Supreme Court today for the first time, in an argument over whether the Constitution permits public schools to test student athletes for drug use without any particular reason for suspecting any individual student of wrongdoing.

title: Garden Falls Victim To Unstoppable Force
description: He went around Greg Anthony, through Anthony Bonner and over Patrick Ewing. John Starks, though, took the worst of it. Starks was again cast in the role of unsuspecting playground victim, the kid with the hand in the face, the forearm in the back, the one man who kept waiting for him to miss, while everyone stood around the asphalt in awe.

title: Welfare's Vital Core
description: The welfare system is at a turning point. No longer are Republican politicians arguing over how best to improve a system that all agree needs improvement. Instead, House and Senate Republicans have now agreed to eliminate the core principle of the system -- that assistance should be provided throughout the nation to all people poor enough to be "entitled" to it. With one ill-considered legislative lurch, the Republicans would destroy the beacon that has guided the system humanely for more than half a century and would leave the poor to the mercies of state spending whims.

title: QUAKER STATE HAS AN AGREEMENT TO PURCHASE SLICK 50
description: The Quaker State Corporation said yesterday that it had an agreement to buy Slick 50 Inc., a Houston-based manufacturer of chemicals and lubricants for the automotive and industrial markets. Quaker State did not provide a precise price, only saying that it valued the deal "in the range of $60 million." Slick 50's leading product is Slick 50 Automotive Engine Treatment, which holds a 60 percent share of the car engine treatment market, according to Quaker State. Slick 50 has annual sales of about $85 million. Quaker State produces lubricants, motor oils and related products for the automotive market and has annual sales of about $755 million.

title: High Court Ruling Upholds Trademarking of a Color
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that color can be registered as a trademark when it distinguishes a particular product and serves no other function.

title: Home Holdings Bondholders' Plan to Save Insurer
description: Bondholders of Home Holdings Inc. have submitted a plan to New Hampshire state regulators to save the loss-ridden insurance company that is different than an earlier plan proposed by Home and the Zurich Insurance Group.

title: Barry's Jewelers Inc.(BARY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect the 1-for-5 reverse stock split in November 1994.

title: People's Choice Purchase
description: The People's Choice TV Corporation said today that it would acquire Eastern Cable Networks' wireless cable system in Detroit for $15 million in cash and stock in its second acquisition announcement in two days. People's Choice, which operates wireless cable systems, said the deal also included the assumption of about $9 million of debt, as well as the rights to Eastern's Baltimore wireless cable system, once it is developed. On Monday, People's Choice said it would acquire Preferred Entertainment Inc., owner of a system in the Chicago area, in a stock transaction valued at about $60 million.

title: Budget Battling: Tale of the Red Tape
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Senate leaders have reached a general agreement on revisions to Mr. Pataki's initial budget proposal, but the Assembly has not signed on. Here are some major issues under discussion: The Bottom Line

title: How Five-Spice Powder Can Liven Up Shrimp
description: THIS quick and easy shrimp dish gets its flavor from Chinese five-spice powder, which consists of cinnamon, cloves, fennel seed, star anise and Sichuan peppercorns. Steamed asparagus and dark, crusty bread are fine accompaniments. Five-Spice Shrimp And Pasta 10 jumbo shrimp in their shells 1 teaspoon five-spice powder Freshly ground black pepper to taste 1 large clove garlic 1 piece fresh or frozen ginger, large enough to yield 1 tablespoon coarsely grated 1/3 cup orange juice 1 tablespoon reduced-sodium soy sauce 1 tablespoon rice vinegar 1 teaspoon honey mustard 1/8 teaspoon hot pepper flakes 8 ounces fresh eggless linguine.

title: A.L. Pharma (ALO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge for loss on extinguishment of debt related to combination with A.L. Oslo of $ 683,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and year.c-Net incomeLatest quarter and year's loss from continuing operations of $ 12,066,000, or 56 cents a share, and $ 1,703,000, or 8 cents a share, respectively, included $ 17,025,000 after-tax charge, or 79 cents a share, related to combination with A.L. Oslo.Results for the year-ago quarter; fiscal 1994 and fiscal 1993 are all restated to reflect combination with A.L. Oslo.(Loss)

title: Rams Given More Time
description: The Rams and the city of St. Louis yesterday pushed back the deadline for filing antitrust lawsuits against the National Football League. Under an agreement with the N.F.L., the Rams had until Friday to file litigation first and thus set the site for trial. The agreement was moved backed to April 17 to give both parties more time to work out a deal.

title: Arrest in Missing-Teen Case
description: The search for 16-year-old Nicole Russo continues, but the hunt for the teen-ager charged with her murder has ended. At Los Angeles International Airport early yesterday, F.B.I. agents and the police arrested Louis P. Urcinoli, 19, of Seaside Park. He had been sought since March 17, four days after Ms. Russo, a Brick High School student, was reported missing. The police said that Mr. Urcinoli killed his girlfriend of a few weeks in a Seaside Park motel. Mr. Urcinoli has said that he dropped her off in Brooklyn. Her family is clinging to hope that she might still be alive.

title: Oxford Industries(OXM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Gloomy Reports to the Contrary, 87% of Americans Feel Healthy
description: IN a national survey that challenges doomsayers' views of American health, a Federal agency has found that nearly 87 percent of adults said their health was good to excellent.

title: Expansion at Bell Atlantic
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said today that it would expand its computer systems integration division beyond its mid-Atlantic base to seven more cities. Bell Atlantic already has 14 offices stretching from New Jersey to Virginia. It said the expansion would contribute $50 million in new revenue in 1995. The cities being added are New York, Chicago, Atlanta, Boston, Dallas, San Francisco and Los Angeles. The move, announced at the Networld Interop 1995 conference in Las Vegas, bolsters the company's stake in the $12.5 billion systems integration industry.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT doesn't take much to prompt an idea. For Marcel Proust, the taste of a madeleine provided the inspiration for "Remembrance of Things Past."

title: Officials Guilty of Taking Bribes
description: Two politicians were found guilty yesterday of accepting bribes in the continuing investigation of city government by Federal authorities. After a five-week trial on the awarding of city towing contracts, a jury deliberated for eight hours before convicting Councilman Gary S. Harris and former Councilman Ralph T. Grant Jr. Page A1.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Lemieux
description: Seated on the Devils' bench, Claude Lemieux did not think the officials were watching when he sucker-punched Brett Lindros in the face as the Islander rookie was leaning into the bench while fighting with Scott Stevens during Sunday afternoon's 5-5 tie at Nassau Coliseum. But SportsChannel's television cameras were watching, and that is going to cost Lemieux three games without pay.

title: Bond Funds Reverse a Yearlong Course and Report a Rise in Investments
description: For the first time in a year, mutual fund investors are putting more money into American bond funds than they are taking out. And with the stock market at record highs, they are adding more money to stock funds, though not at a record pace.

title: Mark IV Industries(IV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included extraordinary charge of $ 1.1 million, or 2 cents a share, on loss from extinguishment of debt.c-Included extraordinary charge of $ 47.7 million, or $ 1.12 a share, from extinguishment of debt and noncash expense from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for postretirement benefits.Mark IV Industries attributed its increase in sales for the fiscal fourth quarter and 1995 year to the acquisition of Purolator Products Co., which had sales of $ 138.6 million from the Nov. 4, 1994 acquisition to the end of fiscal 1995.

title: Jeweler Describes Shooting
description: Jeffrey Wolf did not speak publicly for two weeks after his wife was shot and killed during a robbery in his Franklin Township jewelry store. Mr. Wolf had said that a robber shot his wife; the police said that Brenda Wolf was fatally wounded by her husband's .357-caliber Magnum.

title: Has-Beens vs. Never-Weres, If You Keep Score at Home
description: "Bob Stoddard, who's retired 10 in a row, is in danger of having his streak broken. Ohh, a walk breaks the spell."

title: Koor Industries Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its share in the profit of Tadiran Ltd. accounted for $ 24 million, or 19.8 percent of net income in 1994.Financial expenses for 1994 were $ 40 million, compared with $ 29 million for the same period a year ago. The increase was due to last year's crisis on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange, which caused a loss of $ 7 million, compared with a profit of $ 16 million a year earlier.

title: Topps Co.(TOPP,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
Corrections
description: A picture of Nigerian villagers yesterday, with an article about a wave of killings in an oil-producing region of Nigeria, carried an incorrect credit. The picture was by Robert Grossman for The New York Times, not by Reuters.

title: Lobo Is Too Generous Distributing Her Passes
description: In the last two weeks, Rebecca Lobo has been named to four all-America teams in women's college basketball. She was voted the Naismith Award Sunday as the player of the year and is favored to win the similar Kodak Award this week in Minneapolis, where she will lead unbeaten and top-ranked Connecticut against Stanford Saturday in the Final Four.

title: Article 359395 -- No Title
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company went public with a $1.3 billion hostile bid for the Clark Equipment Company yesterday after Clark's board spurned its cash offer.

title: Atom Powers Want to Test Despite Treaty
description: Four of the world's main nuclear countries are locked in a dispute as they negotiate a comprehensive ban on nuclear testing: they all want to retain the right to conduct tiny blasts but disagree over the size that should be permitted.

title: A Changing California Emerges From Recession
description: New evidence shows that three years after the rest of the country, California has finally pulled out of its brutal recession, with job growth and incomes rising swiftly. There are even signs that the outflow of residents from the state has slowed sharply and may reverse in coming years.

title: House Republicans Reinvent WIC
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Airlines Break Ranks Over Fees Paid Travel Agents
description: Several airlines, following in their long tradition of breaking collective decisions, are already starting to chip away at the industry's recent move to cap commissions for travel agents.

title: Vivra Inc.(V,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included income of $ 697,000, or 3 cents a share, from discontinued operations.

title:
Time for a Fitness Pyramid?;
Extra Benefits From Exercise At Any Age
description: PEOPLE may know that exercise is good for them -- but they may not know how good.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Another former couple, DONALD and IVANA TRUMP, will be seen together again by millions of people this weekend.

title: Ukraine's Schoolchildren Are Keystone to Building a Nation
description: Before 1991, every first grader in the Soviet Union opened the standard Russian textbook to a story about young Lenin. Today the textbooks given 7-year-olds at Taras Shevchenko School No. 112 here are written in another language and begin in verse: "Beautiful Ukraine, here live you and I."

title: Giuliani Audience for Pete Wilson
description: With most of New York State's Republican leaders lined up behind Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani planned to conduct his first meeting with a Presidential hopeful today -- not Mr. Dole, but Gov. Pete Wilson of California.

title: Sports of The Times; The Night To Savor Jordan
description: SOME nights, the Madison Square Garden electricians don't have to turn on the lights. Some nights, the athletes do it themselves.

title: Homeless, 2 Die in a Fire
description: Two homeless people died yesterday morning in a trash fire beneath a parking-lot ramp in the East New York section of Brooklyn, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: As a Lobbyist, King Hussein Finds It Cool on Capitol Hill
description: Lobbying may not come naturally to kings. But King Hussein of Jordan is doing his best this week to charm, cajole, even embarrass Capitol Hill into making good on the Administration's promise to forgive his country's debt to the United States.

title: Foreign Affairs; Wednesday News Quiz
description: In the old days, The Times ran a news quiz every Saturday. It was always a favorite of mine, and I think it's time for a revival. Here are this week's questions:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CUNY Budget Protesters Didn't Stir Disorder; Childish Excesses
description: To the Editor:

title: When Removing Lead From Homes Increases the Health Risk; Hot Line Offers Help
description: To the Editor:

title: A Longtime Theater Virtuoso Who Keeps Being Discovered
description: Every evening at the Cort Theater, Cherry Jones glides down a long staircase and becomes Catherine Sloper, the repressed title character in "The Heiress," a woman very much of her time, the 1850's. Backstage in her dressing room before a recent performance, the actress is, unsurprisingly, the opposite of her character: vibrant, down to earth and filled with enthusiasm for the actor's life.

title: Students Turn to Internet for Nationwide Protest Planning
description: Gone are the phone chains that mobilized antiwar efforts in the 1960's. Campus activism has launched into cyberspace.

title: Facing Facts In Balkans
description: A small but significant change took place recently at the United States Embassy here: the brass plaque saying "Ambassador" outside the office of the senior American diplomat in Belgrade was replaced by one saying "Chief of Mission."

title: Super Rite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 4
description: b-Net lossc-Included special charges net of income taxes of $ 3,281,000 related to the disposition of Washington, D.C., area stores and $ 1,169,517 related to a contingent stock option. Before these special charges, the company reported net income of $ 2,559,000, or 28 cents a share, for the fourth quarter and $ 9,503,000, or $ 1.04 a share, for the fiscal year.(Loss)

title: His Party Asks, Elect Clinton in '96?
description: When hundreds of thousands of prospective Democratic contributors opened their mailboxes in recent weeks, they spotted what might be taken for an envelope from the Republican Party. Its message, in bold type, was, "Should President Clinton be re-elected?"'

title: Teledyne Solicits Bids and Asks WHX to End Proxy Fight
description: Teledyne Inc., which last year rejected an unsolicited $1.2 billion takeover bid from the WHX Corporation, said yesterday that it was considering putting itself up for sale.

title: Panel Vote Is Set on Repeal of a Federal Wage Act
description: Senate Republicans have scheduled a committee vote on Wednesday on legislation to repeal the Depression-era law that guarantees workers on Federal construction jobs the prevailing wage.

title: U.S. Bank in South Africa
description: The First Union Corporation said today that it would open an office in South Africa to support United States companies trading with the country. First Union said it would work with local banks to help South African companies finance purchases of United States exports. First Union, a bank holding company, said it had processed more than $200 million in trade transactions from South African banks last year.

title: Payroll Scheme Is Suspected
description: Eighteen employees of Continental Airlines kept getting fatter paychecks than they had earned, and the problem was not a clerical error, according to the Essex County Prosecutor, Clifford J. Minor. Rather, Mr. Minor said, a payroll padding scheme operated at Newark International Airport over seven months in 1992. Yesterday, the workers -- now former employees -- were indicted along with the man the prosecutor says they shared their extra money with, Henry Onyluke, who used to be a payroll clerk for the airline. Continental officials said some employees had their pay inflated by $30,000, and the overall loss to the company was about $296,000. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

title:
About Real Estate;
Office Tenants Drawn To Tysons Corner, Va.
description: The Tysons Corner section of Fairfax County continues to be a leading draw for office tenants in northern Virginia. A recent example is a $32 million office building under construction that will serve as the headquarters of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc., the consulting firm.

title: Class Notes; California mother's lawsuit puts a personal spin on the debate over affirmative action.
description: "My name is Janice Camarena," begins the statement given by the 25-year-old woman from Crestline, Calif. "I'm a student at San Bernardino Valley College. Getting an education is especially important for me. I'm a widowed mother of three young children who will depend upon me for food, support and shelter for many years to come."

title: Blockbuster Music, Motorola Reviewing
description: Two large marketers have placed portions of their accounts in review.

title: Shopping for Rice Is No Longer A Simple Choice
description: TEN years ago, the choice of rice was basic: plain white or brown. Apart from international travelers, few cooks really knew about long- or short-grain rice, let alone basmati, texmati, Wehani, fragrant jasmine, arborio and carnaroli, not to mention black rice from Thailand or round-grain rice from Spain's east coast.

title: Bed Bath & Beyond Inc.(BBBY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
Signs of a Power Struggle Come to Light in China
description: Despite an outward appearance of calm, a power struggle appears to be getting under way in the Communist Party leadership as the death of Deng Xiaoping, the paramount leader, nears, Western diplomats and Chinese say.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BALL CORP., Muncie, Ind., which makes aluminum cans and glass containers, will build a plant to make plastic beverage bottles within a year, marking its entry into the plastic beverage bottles and food containers business.

title: The Winner Isn't David Letterman
description: As the stars glittered, Dave fizzled. The biggest surprise of Monday's Academy Awards telecast on ABC was the growing insignificance of David Letterman as the evening droned on. Instead of keeping things moving smartly, Mr. Letterman stuck with his late-night shtick, too often leaving the show's pacing in shambles. Glamorous people waiting for awards announcements aren't terribly interested in New York City cabdrivers or stupid-pet tricks.

title: Wall St. Firm Is Suspended From Trading
description: A. T. Brod & Company was shut down by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday for failing to set aside the required capital to back its broker-dealer securities transactions.

title: Dollar Is Pushed Down Sharply As Fed Declines to Raise Rates
description: The dollar fell sharply against the German mark and the Japanese yen yesterday as the Federal Reserve left interest rate unchanged.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Bert Sugar; Attention, Fans: Amazing Facts! Fun Fictions!
description: BERT SUGAR?"

title: Cinemark USA Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue is total revenues.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 17 about a sex-discrimination lawsuit against the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People misstated the terms under which an employee in its economic development department left the organization. N.A.A.C.P. officials and the former employee, Ann Taylor -- who was not involved in the suit -- say she resigned from the organization. Ms. Taylor approached The Times last week; this correction was delayed for checking of the discrimination complaint.

title: U.S. Support for Turks' Anti-Kurd Campaign Dims
description: After clashing with European allies and members of Congress, the Clinton Administration has softened its support for Turkey's offensive against Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq and has stepped up pressure on Turkey to withdraw its 35,000 troops.

title: Two Greek Brothers Surrounded by Enigma
description: Early in "Borderline" there is a telling image: an extreme close-up of a partly eaten apple with ants crawling over it. Think of it as a warning. When a film goes over the edge with such an arch, pretentious symbol, there's no turning back. The apple sits on the grass and two little boys are tied by their wrists to a tree while their father sleeps. Whether the boys are tied for punishment or safekeeping is one of the lesser mysteries of this intentionally enigmatic and unintentionally tired Greek film.

title:
N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT;
Smith's Winning Formula: Stay Flexible
description: Dean Smith has won 830 games and two national championships at the University of North Carolina. Yet the persistent knock on his coaching has been that it's too prone to stifling individual talents and personalities to meet the demands of his unchanging formula.

title: SMITHKLINE BEECHAM AND COASTAL HEALTHCARE ALLIANCE
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. and Coastal Healthcare Group Inc. formed an alliance yesterday to offer pharmacy benefit management and laboratory services to 600,000 patients through Coastal's health plans. Coastal, based in Durham, N.C., is a physician management company with more than 6,000 affiliated doctors. SmithKline Beecham is the big pharmaceutical company based in England. As a pharmacy benefit manager, SmithKline negotiates prescription-drug discounts for employer health plans and tries to persuade physicians to prescribe generic or lower-priced brand-name drugs.

title: Surveys Find Lack of Knowledge Limits Use of Morning-After Pill
description: Most gynecologists know about morning-after pills that can prevent unwanted pregnancies, but they seldom prescribe them because they wait for women to ask, a new survey finds. And most women, a related survey shows, do not know enough about the pills to ask for them.

title: QUAKER OATS TO CUT JOBS AS FOOD UNITS MERGE
description: The Quaker Oats Company said yesterday that it would slash 600 jobs, or 3.2 percent of its work force, as it merges its cereals, snacks and convenience food divisions into a single United States food unit. The cuts will be paid for with part of a $75 million to $90 million charge announced on March 8. At the time, Quaker, of Chicago, said the restructuring would generate annual savings comparable to the amount of the charge. Shares in Quaker Oats closed yesterday at $34, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange. William D. Smithburg, its chairman and chief executive, said the company would eliminate jobs in its corporate, shared services and strategic business units beginning next month.

title: TPI Enterprises Inc.(TPIE,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-Included $ 1.6 million charge from chairman's retirement and $ 1 million reduction in restructuring reserve, in the quarter and year.c-Included $ 35 million restructuring charge in the quarter and year. The year also included a gain of $ 5.3 million from sale of 50 percent stake in theater operations.(Loss)

title: Rangers' Help Wanted: Someone Who Can Score
description: A hand-written sign was posted next to the dressing-room stalls of Mike Richter and Glenn Healy today. It read: "Hail Mary, full of grace, put the puck in the right place -- Go Rangers!"

title: BRITISH CONCERN TO TAKE OVER SYROCO, FURNITURE MAKER
description: Marley P.L.C., a British building-materials concern, said yesterday that it would acquire a furniture maker, Syroco Inc., for $140 million in cash from its parent, the Syratech Corporation, a furniture and flatware maker in East Boston, Mass. The transaction for Syroco, which is based in Baldwinsville, N.Y., should close by mid-April, Syratech said. After the announcement of the sale, Syratech's stock rose $1.75, to $18.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Eating Well
description: THE selling of the Mediterranean diet pyramid through articles and cookbooks is proceeding at a breathtaking pace. Food writers who never liked the United States Agriculture Department's Food Guide Pyramid have embraced the Mediterranean version with gusto. The primary difference between the two, and the one that endears the Mediterranean pyramid to food writers, is the recommendation that generous quantities of olive oil be used.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a proposed acquisition of Health Systems International by Wellpoint Health Networks misstated a term of the deal. Under the plan being discussed, the owners of stock in Wellpoint, not Health Systems, would receive $1.2 billion in cash.

title: Congressman Seeks Intelligence Data on Slayings in Guatemala
description: A member of Congress told the National Security Agency and the United States Army tonight to secure records that might shed light on what the United States Government knew about the killings in Guatemala of an American citizen and a guerrilla married to an American lawyer.

title: Duckwall-Alco Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma. Excluded the effect of accretion in the carrying value of a warrant and includes the effect of the issuance of 350,000 common shares under the exercise of the warrant.

title: Another Unhappy Night For Nets
description: Three nights ago in Miami, the Nets made a valiant and heroic fourth-period comeback against the Heat to keep themselves alive for the eighth and final playoff spot. Two nights later, they fizzled in Indianapolis, losing to the Pacers.

title: Audience Odder Than the Repertory
description: Audiences can be peculiar, but the one Mstislav Rostropovich faced on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall was odder than most. When Mr. Rostropovich took his first bow, at the intermission, a young boy walked across the stage seeking an autograph. The cellist guided him backstage and sent him off before the next curtain call. And at the end of the concert a sketch artist handed Mr. Rostropovich his afternoon's work, but when the cellist took it with him instead of signing it, the portraitist climbed on stage, looked puzzled for a moment, then headed backstage in pursuit. In between, there were more typical annoyances: antiphonal coughing, but in greater measure than usual, and stragglers.

title: Food Notes
description: Sorbet Heads the List

title: Stocks End Day Mixed, Deflated Somewhat by Bond Prices
description: The stock market closed mixed yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling, the Standard & Poor's 500 index edging again into record territory and the Nasdaq composite index, which is rich in technology stocks, surging to another high.

title: KODAK ANNOUNCES ALLIANCES FOR DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHY
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, as expected, announced a variety of new products and alliances yesterday, to help build its digital photography business. The company reached an agreement with the Microsoft Corporation to develop software for manipulating pictures on personal computers; with the Sprint Corporation to develop a system for transmitting images of data files over telephone lines; with the Hewlett-Packard Company to develop low-cost scanners and printers, and with I.B.M. to develop systems to move images over computer networks.

title: Apple Stock Falls on Chip-Supply Concern
description: The shares of Apple Computer Inc. dropped nearly 8 percent yesterday on concerns about possible shortages of chips for its new lines of desktop and notebook computers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 GIANT BANK DEAL IN JAPAN Two of Japan's financial giants, Mitsubishi Bank and the Bank of Tokyo, agreed to merge. The deal would create a bank three times the size of Citicorp, the largest United States banking company. A1 A CALL TO DISARM Haiti's President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, asked the international security force taking over from Americans to intensify efforts to disarm "opponents of democracy." A1

title: Personal Health; Underactive thyroids are treatable but often missed.
description: SIX to seven million Americans have thyroid glands that produce insufficient amounts of two hormones that affect virtually every organ of the body, from the heart and brain to the digestive tract and skin. Unfortunately, about half of those with underactive thyroids do not know they have a definable and treatable problem.

title: Gingrich Asks Panel to Quash 'Malicious' Ethics Complaints
description: Facing a growing number of ethics complaints from his Democratic opponents, Speaker Newt Gingrich responded today with a spirited defense of a college course he has taught and a blistering attack on his critics. He called the accusations against him "baseless and malicious" and urged the House ethics committee to dismiss them.

title: Consumer Optimism Hurts Treasury Prices
description: Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday, hurt by a report showing consumer confidence was higher than expected. The selloff gave back more than half of the gains of a two-day bond rally.

title: A Puzzle Of Pieces In an Odd Fit
description: Dean Moss is an elegant performer and a choreographer of obvious intelligence. But the full-evening piece he presented on Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater was a conundrum, starting with its inscrutable title, "Commodities, Identities and Synchronized Swimming." Like the rest of the piece, the meaning of its parts or why they were joined remained a mystery that was doubly frustrating because Mr. Moss seemed to have intentionally made a lazily roiling, neatly ordered mess.

title: Aristide Urges U.N. to Disarm Thugs in Haiti
description: With the United States scheduled to hand over responsibility for Haiti's security to the United Nations this week, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide asked the international force today to intensify efforts to disarm those he called "opponents of democracy."

title: Gingrich Acknowledges That Tax-Cut Plan Is in Trouble
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that his party's five-year, $189 billion package of personal and business tax cuts was "in some trouble," but left murky how much.

title: Steinbrenner And Wilpon Wish for a Silver Lining
description: Before and after George Steinbrenner and Fred Wilpon met here for 90 minutes today, New York's two baseball owners tried bolstering their wish to return major league players to the field by trumpeting the owners' latest proposal as something too good for the union to turn down.

title: Suspect in Murders Traces Troubled Past
description: In one moment during a prison interview today, Reginald McFadden, the parolee who authorities suspect went on a murderous rampage after his release from a Pennsylvania prison last year, maintained that he was not guilty of any murders.

title: Maple Leaf Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Included in sales and operating earnings are sales of serviced lots from its real estate development in Maple, Ont. of $ 25.1 million in latest period, compared with $ 9.7 million in year-ago period.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges with the ticker symbol MLF.The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Martinique Band at Play With Mimicry and Mood
description: Dede Saint-Prix's show at Gould Hall on Saturday night rocked with mimicry. Mr. Saint-Prix sang drum figures. The drums talked. The bassist played rolling figures that caught the gait of a lazy animal walking down a road. Mr. Saint-Prix and a drummer, Rene Baubant, produced a ritualized version of a fight. It was play turned into music.

title: Now Playing on Beverly Blvd.: The Last Days of Chasen's
description: For four more days, Chasen's will still be the classiest restaurant in town.

title: Time for a Fitness Pyramid?; After Thigh Master, a Stream of Fitness Gadgets
description: REMEMBER the last time a rush of resolve pulsed through your sluggish heart, the moment when you knew that this time you would do it, you would exercise regularly? It was a beautiful moment, in which you knew that you would triumph over grim encounters with full-length mirrors.

title: OroAmerica Inc.(OROA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-On a pro-forma basis, the company reported net income of $ 1.64 million, or 26 cents a share, in latest fourth quarter, compared with $ 3.17 million, or 50 cents a share, in year-ago period.c-On a pro-forma basis, net income was $ 5.53 million, or 88 cents a share, in latest year, compared with $ 9.13 million, or $ 1.45 a share, in 1994. The year also included extraordinary charge of $ 564,000, or 12 cents a share, on loss from early retirement of debt.Pro-forma calculations assume the company's initial public offering and retirement of subordinated debentures were completed as of the end of fiscal 1993. The pro forma figures also do not reflect accounting adjustments and related charges from gold price fluctuations, and the substantial reduction in April 1994 in the amount of gold the company owned.

title: The Backlash Against New Deal Liberalism
description: THE END OF REFORM New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War By Alan Brinkley 371 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50

title: Generation Gap for a Generation
description: Wu Nien-Jen's autobiographical film, "A Borrowed Life," is a reverie of the past that is so concentrated in its vision that after a while you begin to feel you are living in the shabby mining village in northern Taiwan where much of the story takes place.

title: Showing Shostakovich's Ties To Bach and Beethoven
description: Pianists interested in exploring both the diversity and continuity of the repertory in a single stroke would do well to look at the program Christopher O'Riley played on Saturday evening at Washington Irving High School. Before the intermission, four of Shostakovich's Preludes and Fugues were sandwiched between Mr. O'Riley's own transcriptions of a Bach Sonata (BWV 529) and a Toccata and Fugue (BWV 538). Shostakovich's debt to Bach is never far from the surface, yet these works spin off into harmonic worlds of their own. Even some of the fugue subjects (particularly the extraordinarily long theme in Fugue No. 16) are outlandish by Bachian standards.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: PATAKI DROPS THREAT OF SHUTDOWN

title: California Leader Visits a State Crucial for '96
description: Gov. Pete Wilson of California took his "exploratory" Presidential campaign to New Hampshire today, looking over the state where the first 1996 primary will be held and getting looked over in return.

title: MERGER TO CREATE NEW JAPAN BANK, WORLD'S LARGEST
description: Two of Japan's most powerful financial institutions, the Bank of Tokyo and the Mitsubishi Bank, announced today that they planned a merger creating the world's largest bank. With about $819 billion in assets, the new bank would be about a third larger than the Sumitomo Bank, now the biggest with $604 billion, and more than three times the size of Citicorp, the largest in the United States.

title: A Former Major Leaguer Wonders What to Do Now
description: Carmelo Martinez peruses the talent on the field, dares to gauge it against what he still possesses and knows that he, more than any so-called replacement player, can fit the bill of major leaguer.

title: Another Chapter In Cowboy Story
description: It's understandable how someone could get lost in the shadow of Oklahoma State center Bryant (Big Country) Reeves. But Randy Rutherford doesn't mind being out of the spotlight. In fact, he seems to prefer it.

title: Informer in Terrorism Trial, Pressed by Defense, Is Cool
description: For two grueling days, a lawyer for Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman has tried to pressure the Government's main informer in the terrorism conspiracy trial in Manhattan into admitting that he is in fact an Egyptian spy. And for two days, the informer, Emad A. Salem, has brushed aside the questions with a polite "absolutely not."

title: Valve Is Cited in Acid Spill
description: A leaky valve appears to have been the cause of a spill of thousands of gallons of potentially lethal hydrochloric acid solution on Sunday at a chemical plant three blocks from a densely populated neighborhood. The preliminary finding by the Hudson Regional Health Commission, an environmental enforcement agency, said no fumes had been detected outside the Henkel Corporation plant, which manufactures ingredients for beauty products. The commission said the spill, from one of two 10,000-gallon tanks on the property, was contained. Hydrochloric acid's gaseous form, hydrogen chloride, is a respiratory irritant.

title: How About X Ratings On the Internet?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mason Is Glad To Be Back
description: Last night was Anthony Mason's first home game since his five-game suspension, making it a special occasion for him even if Michael Jordan had not been in town.

title: Quick & Reilly Group Inc.(BQR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
RAYTEL BEGINS TALKS TO ACQUIRE MEDICAL DIAGNOSTICS
description: The Raytel Medical Corporation said yesterday that it had entered into talks to acquire Medical Diagnostics Inc. Medical Diagnostics said the talks with Raytel and certain other parties were aimed at finding an alternative to an existing $5-a-share tender offer made by Raytel. Raytel last extended its $20 million offer for Medical Diagnostics on March 7, the fifth time it extended its hostile bid. Raytel's cash tender offer of $5 a share is scheduled to expire tomorrow. Shares of Medical Diagnostics were up 50 cents yesterday, at $4.875, in Nasdaq trading. Medical Diagnostics, based in Burlington, Mass., provides mobile Magnetic Resonance Imaging services in New England and New York. Privately held Raytel is based in San Mateo, Calif.

title: P.R. Survey Reports Fee Income Gains
description: An annual public relations survey has reported that fee income for the 50 largest agencies rose 8.5 percent in 1994 from 1993.

title: Paris Tablecloth Sketches From a Golden Age of Art
description: The sight of earnest young artists sketching away at sidewalk cafes may seem familiar enough, but even in Paris not many restaurants can claim to have inspired the likes of Picasso, Max Ernst, Alexander Calder, Jean Cocteau, Paul Valery, Paul Eluard and Balthus. Between 1944 and 1952, though, a coterie of artists and poets were regulars at a little Left Bank bistro called Le Catalan. And as they sat around chatting, smoking, eating and drinking, many of them drew playfully -- and often erotically -- on the paper tablecloths that were then the norm.

title: International Briefs; 8% Increase in Profits Reported by Ciba-Geigy
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G., the Swiss pharmaceuticals and chemicals company, reported yesterday that its profit for 1994 rose 8 percent, to 1.91 billion Swiss francs ($1.64 billion). The results were stronger than expected.

title: 2 Newark Politicians Convicted in Graft
description: Two prominent Newark politicians were found guilty of accepting tens of thousands of dollars in bribes. The verdicts appear to add impetus to a wide-ranging Federal inquiry into the city government's dealing with private companies.

title: A New Chapter in the Gates Story
description: The most compelling sidebar to the National Invitation Tournament took another turn yesterday morning: William Gates became a father for the second time.

title: H & R BLOCK SELLS PERSONAL FINANCE SOFTWARE HOLDING
description: H & R Block Inc. said yesterday that it intended to sell its Meca division, which produces the Managing Your Money personal finance software. Block, the tax preparation company and also the owner of the Compuserve computer network, said it intended to specialize in on-line services. Earlier this month, Block agreed to buy Spry, a leading provider of software for use on the Internet, for $100 million. Block has hired Salomon Brothers to sell Meca. Block figures it will get a high price because many banks see personal finance software, which people use to track their investments and spending, as a key to offering electronic banking services. The company invested $50 million in Meca, including the Tax Cut tax software program, which Block is not selling.

title: Conner Wins on Water, But Has Problems on Land
description: With his grip on the America's Cup slowly but surely slipping, Dennis Conner went out on the water today needing to win to remain a viable threat in the 1995 defense trials.

title: National Education Corp.(NEC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax net charge of $ 471,000, or 2 cents a share. Items included a pretax charge of $ 2,623,000 from amortization of the company's deferred marketing balance; and a pretax gain of $ 2,152,000 from selling and promotion spending ''below the amortization that would have been expensed in accordance with the company's previous accounting policy.''c-Included pretax net charge of $ 27,410,000, or 72 cents a share. Items included cumulative pretax charge of $ 19,836,000 from amortization of the company's deferred marketing balance; and a pretax charge of $ 7,574,000 from selling and promotion spending ''below the amortization that would have been expenses in accordance with the company's previous accounting policy.''d-Included pretax charge of $ 9,232,000, or 22 cents a share, from write-down of certain intangible assets acquired in the company's 1986 acquisition of Deltak; an after-tax gain of $ 21,260,000, or 71 cents a share, from the company's initial public offering of about 18 percent of its Steck-Vaughn unit's common shares; and a pretax charge of $ 23,626,000, or 55 cents a share, from write-down of certain assets and closing of 14 schools.(Loss)

title: Flag Symbolizes the Country We Share
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bank of Tokyo to Merge With Mitsubishi Bank

title: In America; A Tale of Two Citizens
description: Sarah Evans lives alone in a single-family house in Queens. She is 69 years old and blind. Her husband died five years ago. She has spent several years struggling with congestive heart failure, diabetes, failing kidneys and periodic bursts of dangerously high blood pressure. If she has found any of this daunting, she keeps it to herself.

title: Pataki Drops Threat to Close Down Government
description: Gov. George E. Pataki backed away today from his repeated threat to close down state government if a budget is not enacted by Saturday, the start of the fiscal year. He conceded that a timely budget, which he had made a priority of his administration, was slipping out of reach.

title: Tyson and King a Team
description: MIKE TYSON and DON KING will appear at a news conference in Cleveland tomorrow, King's boxing director, AL BRAVERMAN, said yesterday. "This will put to rest all the rumors and stories," he said.

title: Walker Out, Watters In
description: Yesterday, the Philadelphia Eagles released HERSCHEL WALKER, a two-time Pro Bowl selection and their most valuable player on offense the past two years, and introduced RICKY WATTERS, a 25-year-old running back who won a Super Bowl two months ago with San Francisco. Watters's youth and championship ring made the difference to Coach RAY RHODES, who was the 49ers' defensive coordinator last season.

title: For 6 Firms, a 'Negative' S.& P. Outlook
description: The large borrowings that big Wall Street firms use to finance their businesses are likely to get more expensive in the coming months, making profits harder to come by.

title: Major Ethnic Changes Under Way
description: New York City's white population, which made up more than 60 percent of the residents in the city in 1970, will decline to 35 percent by the end of the century, predicts a new forecast by the City Planning Department.

title: Andy Kaufman's Beloved Antics
description: The most original comedian of the last few decades is celebrated with appropriate zest in tonight's NBC special, "A Comedy Salute to Andy Kaufman." Kaufman was born in New York on Jan. 17, 1949. He died of lung cancer on May 16, 1984.
