title: Lockout Appears Unlikely if Judge Issues an Injunction
description: Despite a new proposal from the club owners, a Federal judge continues to hold the key to a baseball season with major leaguers.

title: Owen Healthcare Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Bill Tice, 52, Creator Of Stylish Clothing To Wear at Home
description: Bill Tice, a fashion designer who was known for stylish robes and lounge wear, died on March 9 in the Heather Glen care center in Glendale, Ariz. Mr. Tice, who was 52, was a long-time resident of Manhattan and moved to Phoenix two and a half years ago.

title: Inheritance Plot Feared in Deaths of Couple
description: Sometime in January, a Staten Island couple walked into a patch of dense woods in the Pennsylvania Poconos and were beaten to death. The bodies lay there more than two months, slowly decomposing in the winter chill, until they were found last Thursday by a passer-by.

title: The Foxwoods Myth
description: The phenomenal success of the Foxwoods casino in Ledyard, Conn., has led many Americans to believe that gambling is an economic panacea for Native Americans. Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: SENATE IN ACCORD ON PLAN TO ALTER RULE-MAKING ROLE
description: The Senate reached broad bipartisan agreement today on a proposal to greatly expand the role of Congress in routinely reviewing and possibly rejecting major regulations issued by Federal agencies.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: International Briefs; Renault Says Earnings Tripled During 1994
description: Renault S.A., the largest car and truck maker in France, said yesterday that its profit more than tripled in 1994, aided primarily by one-time items and buoyant sales of small cars. Renault said net earnings jumped to 3.64 billion francs ($736 million) from 1.07 billion francs in 1993. Revenue rose 5.2 percent, to 178.5 billion francs ($36 billion).

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A Celtics Beat Heat Dee Brown matched his career high with 41 points as the Boston Celtics overcame a 14-point third-quarter deficit and beat the host Miami Heat, 126-115, last night. Dominique Wilkins added 19 points and increased his career total to 25,209 to move past Jerry West (25,192) into eighth place on the league's career scoring list. (AP)

title: Imposing Embargo on Libyan Oil No Easy Task, Experts Say
description: A global embargo on Libyan oil that Washington has proposed would be difficult to impose, executives in the industry said today, citing opposition by Libya's major customers as well as by a number of Arab allies of the United States.

title: Man's Best Friend's Fiercest Foe: Man
description: WHEN Noel Velez describes the pit bull fights he and his friends have attended, the revulsion he plainly reveals is accompanied by an adolescent's complicated pride of place. It is as if by having witnessed the illegal and barbarous dogfights the 14-year-old boy has glimpsed secrets of his Washington Heights community that have further bound him to his neighborhood.

title: If There Is a Lockout, Owners May Face Risks
description: If a Federal court judge rules in favor of the players, then the owners of the major league baseball teams would find themselves open to much greater risk opening the season next week with replacement players.

title: Editorial Notebook; Pulp Television
description: With their spiffy new technology, the magicians in Hollywood can do just about anything. They can make Gary Sinise's legs disappear in "Forrest Gump." They can make Jim Carrey's eyes jitterbug in "The Mask." They can make dinosaurs out-act Jeff Goldblum in "Jurassic Park."

title: INSIDE
description: Jordanian King's Visit

title: 3 From Queens Precinct Indicted in Theft of $1,400 From Man
description: A grand jury has indicted two Queens police officers and a former officer in the theft of $1,400 from the apartment of a man in Flushing. Investigators have said another officer or two may soon be arrested in an investigation into drugs and petty thievery involving the 109th Precinct.

title: Fuller (H.B.) (FULL,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 2,532,000, or 18 cents a share.

title: Robert Ruehrwein, Laser Pioneer, 79
description: Robert A. Ruehrwein, a research scientist who devised manufacturing processes used in developing the optoelectronics industry, died on March 10 in St. Luke's Hospital in Chesterfield, Mo. He was 79 and lived in Chesterfield.

title: Irving Shulman Is Dead at 81; Wrote of City Life's Tough Side
description: Irving Shulman, a novelist and screenwriter known as a chronicler of gritty urban life, died on March 23 at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 81.

title: The Fed Meets, and Doesn't Raise Rates
description: The Federal Reserve's interest-rate-setting committee met here today without changing short-term rates, the latest sign the central bankers think that the United States economy is settling down to steady growth with low inflation.

title: Market Place; The S.E.C. says a broker helped friends and relatives be insiders.
description: IT'S nice work if you can get it. You're a securities analyst with some influence in the markets. You reach a positive or negative conclusion about a stock, tell your buddies and relatives, and then let the public know about your new position -- after your pals have already traded on the information first.

title: Book Notes
description: Turning the Last Page?

title: James G. Horsfall, Leading Plant Pathologist, 90
description: Dr. James G. Horsfall, a plant pathologist whose discovery of organic fungicides changed the way the world's farmers combat blight and other fungus diseases, died on March 22 at his home in Hamden, Conn., not far from the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station's Lockwood Farm, where he did much of his research. He was 90 years old.

title: New Sony President Hopes to Fill Missing Links in U.S.
description: The incoming president of the Sony Corporation said today that he hoped to move his company into the communications business, including possibly television broadcasting and on-line information services in the United States.

title: The Budget: Back Room to Living Room
description: A working-class woman anguishes over her children's future, wondering whether she will ever be able to afford to send them to college.

title: Limited Inc. to Split Its Chains Into 3 Companies
description: Limited Inc. announced a plan yesterday to carve its specialty store chains and other operations into three companies that would let investors choose among some of its best-performing and worst-performing businesses.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Theme of Avrett, Free: Johnnie Walker Black has 'more to explore.'
description: FAMILY values, traditional values, basic values. It could be enough to drive you to drink.

title: Hillhaven Corp.(HIL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early extinguishment of debt of $ 48,000 in the quarter and $ 222,000, or 16 cents a share, which included unspecified nonrecurring gain, in the 9 months.c-After an extraordinary charge from early extinguishment of $ 73,000, or 10 cents a share, which included unspecified nonrecurring gain, in the quarter, and $ 1,013,000, or 77 cents a share, which included unspecified nonrecurring gain, in the 9 months.Year-ago 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 46,239,000, or 80 cents a share, included $ 20,225,000 pretax credit from reserves unused at completion of disposition program.Year-ago results are restated to reflect October 1994 acquisition of CPS Pharmaceutical Services Inc. and Advanced Infusion Systems Inc., accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: In an Unofficial Referendum, Bridgeport Voters Show Overwhelming Support for a Casino
description: Residents voted overwhelmingly in support of a casino for Bridgeport today in an unofficial referendum, giving casino advocates the ammunition they wanted to win legislation in the General Assembly authorizing one.

title: Accounts
description: * Balet & Albert, New York, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $2 million: Food & Wines of France, New York, previously at Lois/U.S.A., New York, and Atlanta Apparel Mart, Atlanta, previously in-house.

title: Limousine Driver Deals a Blow to Simpson
description: The limousine driver who picked up O. J. Simpson on the evening of June 12 testified today that in three drives up and down Mr. Simpson's block of North Rockingham Avenue, at a time when prosecutors say he killed two people and Mr. Simpson insists he was home, the driver never saw Mr. Simpson's white Ford Bronco parked on the street.

title: Bronx Man, Beaten by Police, Settles Case
description: A Bronx man who was beaten by police officers was awarded $1 million yesterday after New York City officials decided to settle in the middle of a trial in the case, the man's lawyer said.

title: Two Newark Politicians Found Guilty in Bribe Case
description: Two prominent Newark politicians were found guilty today of accepting tens of thousands of dollars in bribes in verdicts that appear to bolster a wide-ranging Federal inquiry into the city government's dealings with private companies.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After months of speculation about the state of their marriage, JULIA ROBERTS, the actress, and LYLE LOVETT, the singer, songwriter and actor, announced yesterday that they were separating.

title: You're Fired! See You Out of Court; Using In-House Panels to Keep Disputes Within a Company
description: The first time that one of Tom Frederick's management decisions at the Marriott hotel here was overruled by an employee jury, he didn't like it, and he did not agree.

title: Mrs. Mandela and the Rule of Law
description: It could not have been an easy decision for Nelson Mandela, but the South African President was right and courageous to dismiss his estranged wife, Winnie, from the Government. Her expulsion is an important step in the development of the new South Africa, making clear that lawlessness and racial divisiveness will not be tolerated in the highest councils.

title: Gallup Journal; Crossroads Where Old And New Coexist
description: Things were slow on Front Street, the doors of its trading posts and pawn shops and cafeterias rattling a little in the wind that blew in off the Navajo reservation 10 miles away.

title: Looking Like Mike Again, Jordan Beats Knicks
description: It was an incredible performance, even by Michael Jordan's standards. It was a game that 100,000 people will probably swear they saw at Madison Square Garden. And in the end it was Jordan who made one final remarkable play that gave the Chicago Bulls a victory.

title: Japanese Police Say They Found Germ-War Material at Cult Site
description: Japanese police have found materials that raise the possibility that a religious cult suspected of unleashing a poison gas attack in the Tokyo subways might also have been trying to develop biological weapons.

title: North West Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title:
Business Travel;
At some big-city hotels, new rules mean it's harder to make last-minute changes in plans.
description: A NUMBER of large hotels in major American cities are imposing charges for failing to cancel guaranteed reservations at least 72 hours before arrival, or for checking out earlier than planned.

title: Grozny Journal; Picking Up, After Guns Have Done Their Worst
description: The man installed by Moscow as the leader of a new, interim government for the rebellious Chechen region is a soft-spoken technocrat who understands that his efforts to restore a semblance of normal life to this war-smashed city may sign his death warrant.

title: Women of Science And the Old Boys Club
description: "Discovering Women" is an effort by public television, powered by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the National Science Foundation, the Intel Foundation and other money-givers, to bring more women into a male-dominated field.

Many House Republicans who will vote tomorrow for a constitutional amendment imposing term limits have alluded to 1776 and 1789 in arguing that the November election was a mandate for a revolution. The statesman who fought for independence in 1776 were indeed revolutionaries, in one sense. They committed the fortunes of a new country to an untried system of government. But in today's sense, Washington, Hamilton, Madison and John Adams would not have called themselves revolutionaries. And they would have been suspicious of term limits. They believed they were building on the foundation of good institutions such as town meetings and colonial legislatures.

title: U.S. Plan on Utility Pricing And Power Access Awaited
description: The Federal agency that oversees the utility industry is expected to propose guidelines today on access to transmission lines and the prices charged by utilities for such access.

title: Council Set to Fight Mayor On Service Cuts in Budget
description: Drawing battle lines over Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed New York City budget, officials of the City Council said yesterday that they would scale back some or all of the Mayor's $185 million in proposed tax cuts if the city failed to receive enough state aid and could not find ways to pay for the cuts without drastically reducing services.

title: Philadelphia Rail Run Is Saved
description: The ticket costs $2.5 million, but it will keep commuters riding for another year on New Jersey Transit's Atlantic City-to-Philadelphia rail line. Under a plan adopted unanimously yesterday by New Jersey Transit, the number of daily trips on the 67-mile route will be increased. Alfred H. Harf, New Jersey Transit's assistant executive director for planning, said that the board seriously considered dropping the run when Amtrak announced it would end service, but that "universal support" dissuaded the board. New Jersey Transit and Amtrak share the line and Amtrak maintains it. The $2.5 million will cover the cost of maintenance. After a year, New Jersey Transit will review the expanded operation.

title: When Removing Lead From Homes Increases the Health Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Ameritech Capital Funding, a unit of Ameritech Corp., Chicago, is selling $192.16 million of senior notes due in 2005 through Lehman Brothers. The notes are priced at 99.915 to yield 7.512 percent. The noncallable isssue is rated Aa2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc., AA+ by the Standard & Poor's Corp. and AA by Duff & Phelps.

title: Port Chester Battles Plan To Cut Back Counseling
description: When Luis Marmol enrolled in Port Chester High School two years ago, he had just emigrated from Peru and spoke no English. He was confused by his new surroundings, but a Spanish-speaking guidance counselor helped ease his transition to life in a suburban American high school.

title: S.E.C. Urges Clarity On Mutual Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today took another step to help average investors better understand the risks involved in mutual funds.

title: Arrow International (ARRO,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
North Korea Alone Stalls on Nuclear Reactor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Charm School For Car Salesmen; In Class, Making Peace With Buyers; Then There's the Real World
description: It is barely 8:30 in the morning, but already Timothy C. Gercke, auto industry educator and evangelist, has invoked Henry Ford, Moses and the Masai in trying to rouse the two dozen auto salespeople before him to the potential of their calling.

title: No Headline
description: "It's like marrying the two most beautiful people in the world." ALICIA OGAWA, a financial analyst, on a merger that created the world's largest bank. [ A1:6. ]

title: Hanns Friedrichs, 68, Who Set Style of TV News in Germany
description: Hanns Joachim Friedrichs, a journalist who shaped the style of German television news for four decades, died at his home in Hamburg on Monday. He was 68.

title: Mandela Against Mandela; South African Cabinet Split Sets Up Political Test of Strength
description: The caller identified himself as a former anti-apartheid guerrilla, now a brigadier in South Africa's newly integrated army. He had a warning for the white radio host who sounded so pleased about the dismissal of Winnie Mandela.

title: Memorial for Carjacking Victim
description: Gail Shollar died in 1992, a victim of carjacking, rape and murder. Her name will live on in a playground under construction in Quibbletown Park. Mrs. Shollar's husband, Robert, asked Mayor Ted Light last week if the community would consider naming an existing park for his wife. The Mayor suggested the playground, and township officials approved the idea. Mr. Shollar called Mr. Light's suggestion "perfect." Last month, Scott R. Johnson, 25, was convicted of murdering Mrs. Shollar, 35, after abducting her from a South Plainfield shopping center. He will be sentenced April 17.

title: Giant Food Inc.(GFSA,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Included a gain from change in accounting principle for deferred income taxes of $ 3,934,000, or 7 cents a share.

title: A Russian Expatriate Adrift in Berlin
description: The most striking image in "Gorilla Bathes at Noon," Dusan Makavejev's whimsical cinematic collage set in present-day Berlin, is a gigantic statue of Lenin that stands as a ludicrous anachronism in the post-Communist era. In one of the film's zanier scenes, Victor Borisovich (Svetozar Cvetkovic), an expatriate Russian soldier and the film's main character, impulsively hoists himself on ropes to the statue's head to wash its face. Moments later, the police arrive and ensnare him in a net from which he protests, "Ich bin ein Berliner!"

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan Hits Garden at Cruising Speed: 55
description: People were scouring the record books to find out when anyone had done in Madison Square Garden what Michael Jordan had done last night against the Knicks. Like most points in a half, or most points in a game, or most points in . . . . They were looking in the wrong place.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Henley Is Convicted Of Running Drug Ring
description: Cornerback DARRYL HENLEY and four other men were convicted yesterday of running a cocaine ring. Henley, a 28-year-old unrestricted free agent who played with the Los Angeles Rams last year while free on bond, was accused of financing an operation that packed cocaine at his home in Brea, Calif., for sale in Memphis and Atlanta.

title: Peter Sandfort, 79; Dairyman Fought Milk Price Controls
description: Peter H. Sandfort, a dairyman who fought New Jersey's pricing policies on milk in a campaign that was closely followed by the industry in the 1960's, died on Saturday in Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 79 and a resident of Hawthorne, N.J.

title: CUNY Budget Protesters Didn't Stir Disorder
description: To the Editor:

title: For Directors, Board Room Survival 101
description: First, a passel of background papers comes by overnight mail. Then, about a week before directors of Megamicro Inc. are to meet, an inch-thick "board book" arrives, outlining the knotty issues on the agenda. Tucked in with the binder is the customary invitation to cocktails and dinner with the chief executive on the eve of the meeting -- when the role-playing begins.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the O. J. Simpson trial referred incorrectly in some copies to the length of time a limousine driver said Mr. Simpson appeared to be away from home. The witness, Allan Park, said he was sure that for 17 minutes -- not 27 -- he did not see Mr. Simpson's Ford Bronco.

title: Edwin Hartrich, 82, Reporter and Author
description: Edwin E. Hartrich, a journalist and author who wrote about West Germany's economic recovery after World War II, died last Friday at Hines Hospital in Maywood, Ill., near Chicago. He was 82.

title: Dentist Accused in Holdup Plot
description: A Franklin Township dentist was identified yesterday as a mastermind of the March 14 jewelry store holdup that left the owner's wife dead. The Somerset County Prosecutor, Nichols L. Biddell Jr., said that the dentist, Harry Insabella, was the local contact for four men who flew in from the Kansas City area to rob Jeffrey Scott Fine Jewelers. During the holdup, the owner, Jeffrey Wolf, fired several shots. One killed his wife, Brenda, the authorities said, and another injured a robber. Dr. Insabella was arraigned on murder, robbery and weapons charges and was being held at the Somerset County Jail on $1 million cash bail.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Head of Police Is Ambushed In Tokyo
description: The head of the National Police Agency was shot outside his home this morning, and the police said that he was seriously injured but that his life was not in danger.

title: Lone Star Steakhouse & Saloon Inc.(STAR,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to March 21
Bojana Journal; What's There to Pardon? Bulgaria's Old Boss Asks
description: Inside a whitewashed villa surrounded by a wire fence and protected by police guards, Bulgaria's longtime Communist leader, Todor Zhivkov, is living out his last years under house arrest.

title: CHRONICLE
description: And the winner is . . . blue.

title: Whitman Backs Bond Issue
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday that she stands behind a $310 million bond issue for land preservation that includes $30 million for a so-called blue acres program to acquire property at risk of flooding. After appropriate legislative action, permission to issue the bonds would require voter approval.

title: Matteau Could Spend Some Time on Bench
description: During this shortened National Hockey League season and through the Rangers' current six-game losing streak, Coach Colin Campbell has been reluctant to embarrass his slumping regular players by taking them out of uniform and assigning them to watch the games from the press box or on the locker room television monitor.

title: C.I.A. Settles Suit on Sex Bias
description: The Central Intelligence Agency said tonight that it would pay more than $1 million in back pay and salary increases to settle charges of sex discrimination filed against the agency by female employees who conduct or supervise clandestine operations around the world.

title: Maude B. Feld; Antiques Dealer, 94
description: Maude B. Feld, a retired Manhattan antiques dealer and expert on early American glassware, died on March 13 at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

title: For U.C.L.A.'s Zidek, Life's More Than Game
description: George Zidek's U.C.L.A. teammates were listening to more questions about competing for a national basketball championship, questions that had to do with timing and pressure and the burdens of history.

title: Plot and Subplot On a Village Lot
description: IT seems absurd to remove a garden to make a movie about saving a garden," said Martha Danzinger, the district manager of Community Board 3. But that's what's happening to the ABC garden on Eighth Street between avenues B and C.

title: Foote, Cone Office Names Executive
description: The San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding has named Paul Wolfe executive vice president and executive creative director, succeeding Mike Koelker, 56, who is taking a medical leave of absence.

title: A Building of Hard Toil and Shady Deals
description: From the day it opened 88 years ago, it was known as the Tin Building, a gritty structure that became the center of the landmark Fulton Fish Market.

title: Five Bags or Three Bags? Simpson Prosecutor Asks
description: A skycap at Los Angeles International Airport testified today that O. J. Simpson boarded a flight to Chicago around midnight with only three pieces of luggage. That is two fewer suitcases than a limousine driver said he saw at Mr. Simpson's home half an hour earlier, and at least one fewer than the driver said he loaded into the car.

title: Police Officer Kills Man
description: A police officer shot and killed a suspected gunman in the Washington Heights section of upper Manhattan last night after witnessing a shooting, the police said.

title: Turkey Moved on Iraq to Combat Terrorism; In Iran, Who Dictates?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reckoning With Mrs. Mandela
description: A longtime member of the African National Congress told me the other day that he was thrilled Winnie Mandela had been fired from President Nelson Mandela's Cabinet -- but not because he is one of her many detractors. "At last," he said, "she can do the real work of liberation. The Government is not delivering on its promises, and now Winnie is free to hold it accountable to the people who elected it in the first place."

title: Dollar Slumps as Dealers Expect No Rate Change to Ease Pressure
description: The dollar slumped against leading currencies yesterday as dealers increasingly saw little chance that interest rate changes would provide any relief for the currency.

title: Report Casts Doubts On Trenton Tax Cuts
description: A nonpartisan legislative research group predicted that New Jersey would take in $680 million less in revenue than Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has anticipated, raising questions about her ability to deliver another round of tax cuts.

title: Synergistics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 181,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 79,335, or 2 cents a share, in the year. The year also included a gain of $ 1,067,600 on the sale of investment. This was equal to 23 cents a basic share.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: No Bail in Montclair Killings
description: The man accused of killing four people and wounding another in a robbery at a Montclair post office was denied bail at a five-minute court hearing yesterday. Citing his "truly heinous crime" and risk of flight, the United States Attorney, Faith S. Hochberg, argued that Christopher Green, 29, should be imprisoned until he goes on trial.

title: A Swamp? Take That Back!
description: He may be the Governor of New York, but George E. Pataki is not going to get away with calling New Jersey a "swamp." Not if the assistant State Senate minority leader, Bernard J. Kenny Jr., a Hoboken Democrat, has anything to say about it. In a letter to Mr. Pataki that was inspired by a comment reported in The Buffalo News, Mr. Kenny suggested yesterday that the Governor might like to apologize for remarks that "reflect a huge amount of insensitivity" to New Jersey. "My point is that good neighbors should speak kindly of one another," Mr. Kenny said. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

title: Sinclair to Sell Stock
description: The Sinclair Broadcast Group, a Baltimore-based television station owner and programmer, has filed to sell stock to the public for the first time. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said it expected its 3.75 million class A common shares to be priced from $19 to $21 each. Proceeds will be used to repay bank debt, the filing said.

title: Electricity Rates Are Frozen For Con Ed and Lilco for Year
description: Electricity rates will be frozen this year for customers of Consolidated Edison and the Long Island Lighting Company under rate plans approved yesterday by the State Public Service Commission.

title: Maj. Gen. John M. Dunn, 69, Military Aide to Vice Presidents
description: John Michael Dunn, a veteran of three wars who rose to become a major general and a military aide to two Vice Presidents, died on Friday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 69.

title: Clubs to Vote Again on Rams
description: Paul Tagliabue has called a special owners meeting in Dallas on April 12 so they can again vote on the Rams' proposed move to St. Louis, which was voted down in Phoenix two weeks ago. Tagliabue and the National Football League president, Neil Austrian, met with the Rams in Los Angeles on Monday and Tuesday in an effort to reach an agreement that would allow the team to move to St. Louis.

title: Owner of Collapsed Building Got City Renovation Deals
description: One of two men who owned a Harlem building that partly collapsed last week, killing three tenants, is also the president and part owner of a construction company that is receiving city money to oversee the multimillion-dollar renovation of low-income apartment buildings in the same neighborhood.

title: AT HOME WITH: Loretta Young; Life Waltzes On
description: THE IMAGE is frozen in the scrapbook of memory: Loretta Young twirling through the door in an elegant gown to introduce her weekly television show.

title: Suddenly Put on the Defensive, Pataki Takes to the Road to Do Battle for His Budget
description: Gov. George E. Pataki hunched forward in the metal chair and stared intensely at the student with the nose ring, someone else upset about his budget: It would increase state college tuition, close campuses, hurt poor people, hurt single mothers, hurt her, she said.

title: Pentagon Picks Miami as Base for Latin America Command
description: In a decision that could bring 1,500 new jobs and thousands of additional visitors to Florida, the Pentagon today selected Miami as the next headquarters for United States military activities in Latin America.

title: Minister, Quizzed in Killing Of S.I. Couple, Dies in Crash
description: As his world was caving in on him Tuesday afternoon, the Rev. James S. Castria stopped at a religious bookstore in Mountain Lakes, N.J., and asked the clerks to suggest a prayer.

title: Turkey Moved on Iraq to Combat Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians Shut Down Branch of Japanese Sect
description: The Russian branch of Aum Shinrikyo, the Japanese cult that is the leading suspect in the poison gas attack in the Tokyo subway system, has been shut down by Russian authorities. One of the country's most aggressive cults, Aum Shinrikyo says it has more than 30,000 followers in Russia.

title: Economic Scene; Illinois is looking to market forces to help reduce its smog.
description: LIKE the vast region in and around New York City, the six counties of northeastern Illinois forming the Chicago sprawl have a wretched summer smog problem. And both do not have many years to address the problem before the Environmental Protection Agency is supposed to impose harsh sanctions that would slash economic development.

title: International Briefs; Shares of Renault Fall Despite Earnings Surge
description: The shares of Renault S.A., the French car maker, fell sharply yesterday as financial analysts cut their forecasts despite tripled 1994 profits. The stock closed down 9.2 francs, or 5.3 percent, at 164 francs ($33.44).

title: Bridge
description: Among the three living players who will be inducted into the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame here tonight is Edgar Kaplan. In Monday's column, he was incorrectly included among the deceased inductees. The other living inductees are Alvin Roth and Robert Wolff.

title: In Open Panel, Albany Tries Democracy In Lawmaking
description: The move toward greater legislative democracy did not go smoothly here today.

title: T.V.A. Seeking Small Investors
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority said yesterday that it would soon issue $500 million of its first bonds specifically aimed at small retail investors.

title: Excerpts From Debate On House Term Limits
description: Following are excerpts from speeches in the House today by Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, a leading foe of Congressional term limits, and Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia, a supporter, as transcribed by The New York Times: Representative Hyde

title: JAMES RIVER HOLDERS TO GET COMMUNICATIONS PAPER UNIT
description: The James River Corporation of Virginia, based in Richmond, said yesterday that it planned to spin off its communications papers business to shareholders as part of its strategy to reduce debt and focus on its consumer products business. The move would create a company with more than $1 billion in annual sales that makes paper for publishing, business, advertising and corporate communications uses, as well as specialty packaging products.

title: Knicks Snap Back And Feel Relief
description: The Knicks needed a victory tonight. They needed to soothe the pain inflicted by Michael Jordan's 55-point performance on Tuesday. They needed to stop their two-game losing streak. And they needed to stay ahead of the streaking Indiana Pacers.

title: Rochester Community Savings Bank (RCSB,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Bilingual Education Trains Citizens of Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentine President Discourages New Revelations on 'Dirty War'
description: In a radio interview President, Carlos Saul Menem has called on former military torturers and murderers to confess to priests and not to "rub salt in old wounds" by publicly recounting their deeds. "Publicly coming forward to give testimony is a way of returning to a horrible past that we are trying to forget," he said.

title: GARDEN Q.&A.
description: Yellow Flowering Corydalis

title: METRO DIGEST
description: MINISTER QUIZZED IN DEATHS DIES IN CRASH A Protestant minister, under investigation in connection with the deaths of a Staten Island couple who were found slain after their bank account was looted, steered his car into an abutment, killing himself in an apparent suicide, the police said. A1. FALLEN BUILDING'S OWNER GETS CITY MONEY One of two men who owned a Harlem building that partly collapsed last week, killing three tenants, is also the president and part owner of a construction company that is receiving city money to oversee the multimillion-dollar renovation of low-income apartment buildings in the same neighborhood. A1.

title: Serena's Song Is Lukas's Current Guessing Game
description: Five weeks before the Kentucky Derby, the nation's top 3-year-old horses are gathering for prep races from Santa Anita in California to Keeneland in Kentucky. But the favorite in the richest of the preps, the $600,000 Jim Beam Stakes at Turfway Park in Kentucky on Saturday, is the filly Serena's Song, who may not even run in the Derby.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about possible layoffs of two bilingual guidance counselors in Port Chester, N.Y., misidentified the counselor shown talking with supporters. She was Helena Valdes, not Martha Cabanillas.

title: Jos. A. Bank Clothiers Inc.(JOSB,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Excluded a net of tax charge of $ 4.1 million due to the terminations of a pension plan and an executive equity plan, along with a $ 3 million tax benefit of a nonrecurring net operating loss carryback, in the quarter and the year. The year also excluded a nonrecurring benefit of $ 2.1 million from the cumulative effect of SFAS 109. Including these amounts, net income was $ 100,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter, and net income was $ 3.8 million, or 78 cents a share, in the year.Sales are net sales.

title: International Briefs; Volkswagen's Deliveries Down in First Quarter
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that its sales volume was down in the first quarter and warned that its future profitability could be hurt by the strong German mark.

title: International Briefs; Profit at Deutsche Bank Declined 39% in 1994
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Germany's largest bank, said yesterday that bond trading losses slashed its profit by 39 percent, to 1.36 billion marks ($980 million), in 1994. The managing board chairman, Hilmar Kopper, said profit would rebound amid confidence that 1995 would be a better year for financial markets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Good Things Come in Threes for Miller At Indianapolis, Reggie Miller's trio of 3-pointers last night gave the Indiana Pacers the lead for good and he finished with 22 points in a victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers. Miller's long-range shooting sparked a 15-4 Indiana spurt as the Pacers extended their winning streak to five games over all and seven straight at Market Square Arena. Cleveland trailed by 64-60 after Mark Price hit a 3-pointer with 7 minutes 50 seconds left in the third quarter. After two free throws by Cleveland's Chris Mills, who led all scorers with 25 points, the Cavaliers trailed, 66-62. Indiana responded with 14 consecutive points, sparked by Miller's 3-pointer with 6:51 remaining in the period. The Cavaliers went more than six minutes without a field goal. (AP)

title: Aristide Condemns Killing
description: President Aristide strongly condemned the killing of Ms. Durocher Bertin today and said his Government would do "everything in our power" to apprehend those responsible for it.

title: Williams-Sonoma Inc.(WSGC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Robert A. Kennard, 74, Is Dead; Architect and Mentor for Blacks
description: Robert A. Kennard, a Los Angeles architect who turned his struggles as a young black apprentice into a lifelong campaign to ease the way for other minority members who are professionals, died on Friday at the University of Southern California Norris Cancer Center. He was 74 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: The Wrong Pressure on Libya
description: Libya continues to shield two suspects wanted for the terrorist bombing of a Pan Am airliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988 that killed 270 people. In a well-intentioned but flawed effort to press Libya to turn them over, the Clinton Administration has proposed tighter economic sanctions.

title: Tridel Enterprises reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included noncash write-downs of $ 7.9 million in the carrying values of the assets of the company's residential real estate division. The period also included a pretax charge of $ 4.5 million for restructuring of the company's construction technology division, and income from discontinued operations of $ 1.1 million, or 9 cents a share.c-Included noncash write-downs of $ 100.6 million in the carrying values of the assets of the company's residential real estate division. The period also included a pretax charge of $ 25.6 million for restructuring of the company's construction technology division, and income of $ 3 million, or 26 cents a share, from discontinued operations.(Loss)The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Guatemalan Chief Tells Colonel to Sue
description: President Ramiro de Leon Carpio said today that he had advised a Guatemalan Army colonel who has been accused by an American Congressman of being a paid agent of the C.I.A. and of involvement in two killings to sue the lawmaker for defamation.

title: Binks Manufacturing Co.(BIN,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included one-time gain of $ 134,000 from sale of properties.

title: Furor Over Equipment Change
description: America's Cup matches on the Pacific Ocean course here paled today compared to rancorous confrontations ashore involving the fate of Stars & Stripes in the defense semifinals.

title: Trump Plan Is Rejected
description: Donald Trump got bad news yesterday in Atlantic County Superior Court. Judge Richard Williams rejected his plans for a $55 million expansion of Trump Plaza Hotel Casino. The action overturned approval by the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority of $19.5 million in credits for the project and set aside condemnation proceedings that would have given Mr. Trump control of neighboring properties. But Mr. Trump's lawyer said construction would continue despite the decision.

title: Commission Policy Changed At Prudential
description: Prudential Securities Inc. said yesterday that it would stop paying its brokers more to sell in-house products than offerings from other companies, which make less money for Prudential.

title: Corrections
description: The Bridge column on Monday, about inductions into the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame in Phoenix tonight, referred to one inductee incorrectly and omitted another. Edgar Kaplan is a living inductee, not deceased; B. Jay Becker, a deceased inductee, should also have been listed. Corrected references appear in the column today, on page C17.

title: Fire Sweeps Through Major Building at Fulton Fish Market
description: A fire swept through one of the main commercial buildings at the Fulton Fish Market yesterday, incinerating offices and storage rooms and largely destroying the 88-year-old structure that housed a number of the market's major wholesalers.

title: Bond Prices Surge on Home Sales Data, Then Slip on a Weak Auction
description: Prices of Government securities ended with modest gains yesterday, following an early rally that had been spurred by yet another report indicating that the economy's growth is slowing.

title: International Briefs; Pearson to Expand in TV
description: Pearson P.L.C., the media company based in London, said yesterday that it would expand its global television operations through the purchase of Grundy Worldwide Ltd., an Australian television producer, for $279 million. Pearson will pay cash for all of Grundy's stock, including a stake of about 85 percent held by the founder and chairman, Reg Grundy, who will remain as a consultant. Grundy will drop plans to sell a 35.5 percent stake in a public stock offering in the United States and Australia. (AP)

title: Foster-Care Discharge Grants to End Monday
description: For years, children leaving foster care have received up to $500 to buy the things necessary to start their lives over again: furniture, bed linens, dishes.

title: Constance M. Morgan; Smith Trustee, 81
description: Constance Morrow Morgan, a longtime Smith College trustee, died on Saturday in Portland, Ore., at the home of her son, Rhidian. She was 81 and lived in Ridgefield, Wash., and North Haven, Me.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Tale of Evasion Of Ban on Aid For Guatemala
description: The Bush Administration, in a show of public anger over the killing of an American, cut off military aid to Guatemala in 1990 but secretly allowed the Central Intelligence Agency to send millions of dollars to the military Government to make up for the loss, members of the Bush and Clinton Administrations said today.

title: Essay; Stop the Turks
description: Ten days ago the military-dominated Government of Turkey sent at least 35,000 troops, with tanks and F-16's, across the border into the northern portion of Iraq. That is the "no-fly zone" where the U.S. and its allies -- including Turkey -- are protecting Iraqi Kurds from the genocidal fury of Saddam Hussein.

title: Panel Agrees to Let New York Hospitals Subsidize the Poor
description: New York hospitals were spared potentially devastating losses by some last-minute, late-night Capitol Hill deal making intended to allow New York to continue subsidizing care for the indigent by charging other patients extra.

title: Acklands Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included gains and one-time restructuring costs resulting in a net gain of about $ 1.2 million in the quarter and about $ 4.8 million in the year.The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The New Pedicure Is Gentle on the Feet
description: IT'S a nightmare for the pedicure business," said one beauty salon owner, who didn't want his name used because, he said, he feared repercussions by the state licensing agency. "Half the process was using a blade to take off dead skin. Now, if you do that you can't get liability insurance."

title: Baby Is Said to Have Cast Off H.I.V., but Some Are Skeptical
description: Scientists in California report that a child infected with the AIDS virusat birth successfully cast off the infection by the age of 1, but some other experts doubt that the case has been fully proved.

title: Proposed F.C.C. Deal Would Avoid Delay of License Auction
description: The Federal Communications Commission proposed a deal today that it hoped would extract itself from a messy legal battle over the agency's plan to reserve wireless telephone licenses for small businesses, minorities and women.

title: Homeowners Will Rue Property Legislation
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani and Whitman Welcome California's Wilson, Without the Embrace
description: With Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani laughing warmly at his side, Gov. Pete Wilson of California said yesterday that he would fight for a ballot spot in New York's Republican Presidential primary, despite the strong show of support for Senator Bob Dole by virtually every top G.O.P. official in the state -- except the Mayor.

title: Officials Say U.S. Is Unlikely to Meet Clean-Air Goal for 2000
description: In a move that seems likely to reduce their leverage at a global conference, Administration officials conceded today that the United States was unlikely to meet President Clinton's goal of limiting emissions of heat-trapping gases to 1990 levels by the year 2000.

title: Don't Eat The Painting
description: THE subject matter could not be more appropriate. Twenty-eight of Linda Miller's 12-inch-square artworks, in which she incorporates oil paint, photographs and wax, are on display at two Dean & DeLuca cafes, at 1 Wall Street Court, at Pearl Street, and at 9 Rockefeller Plaza, at 48th Street. Ms. Miller has concentrated on such edibles as cheese, peppers, pears and fish. "Sometimes I thought I was cooking dinner," she said. The paintings are $500 each. Ms. Miller is at (212) 533-1677.

title: Thorny Issues Are Holding Up a Pivotal Health Care Deal
description: Getting the buyer and seller to agree in negotiations for a giant health care merger in California was only the first step. Wellpoint Health Networks and Health Systems International cannot complete their $1.8 billion stock swap without the approval of the state commissioner of corporations, who has sweeping authority over health maintenance organizations.

title: Bank Failures Undercut Venezuelan Government
description: Fourteen floors above the disconnected teller machines of the failed Banco La Guaira, Luis Raul Matos Azocar revels in his new penthouse office with its Persian carpets, leather sofas, antique tables and a small rock garden overlooking this capital's Andean valley.

title: Marcus Cable Pursues Cencom
description: The Marcus Cable Company is in talks with certain limited partners of Cencom of Alabama L.P. to acquire the interest in Cencom that Marcus does not already own.

title: Sports of The Times; Has Anybody Seen a Goal Around Here?
description: IF it's any consolation to all those Ranger rooters who suffered so much for so long since 1940, and are now suddenly suffering again, Mike Keenan is suffering too.

title: Va. Tech Wins Thriller
description: The 58th-annual National Invitation Tournament came down to two free throws. Two free throws with 0.7 seconds left in overtime and an unflappable 6-foot-6-inch, 249-pound junior by the name of Smith at the line.

title: Acting Out the Stories And Miracles in Mark
description: "Laurence Olivier," said Hermione Gingold in an ancient (1940's) London revue, "is a tour de force. Donald Wolfit is forced to tour." The indomitable Alec McCowen is both in his two-hour solo presentation, "St. Mark's Gospel," which last night opened at the Lamb's Theater, where it was last seen in 1990.

title: Hillary Clinton Finding a New Voice
description: Halfway around the world from the battles that haunt her, an outspoken American woman found a new voice today in the words of an Indian schoolgirl, who composed a poem called "Silence" and sent it to Hillary Rodham Clinton with the handwritten exhortation: "More power to you."

title: Private Research Unit Sees Big Shortfall for Whitman
description: A respected nonpartisan legislative research group predicted today that the state would take in $680 million less in revenue than Gov. Christine Whitman has anticipated, raising serious questions about her ability to deliver another round of tax cuts.

title: Clinton Opens Drive on Economic Gains
description: President Clinton engaged in an all-day public discussion of the Southern economy here today as he began a yearlong campaign to overcome a political conundrum: that his standing with the voters remains mediocre despite the nation's economic health.

title: Corrections
description: A company symbol in some editions of Business Day yesterday, with a brief report in the Company News column about a plan by Tandy Brands Accessories Inc. to discontinue its television home shopping business, was published in error. The symbol was that of the Tandy Corporation, a separate company.

title: Fringe Group Distorts the Quebec Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: An Insider's Guide to the Art of Film
description: MAKING MOVIES By Sidney Lumet Illustrated. 220 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOEING CO., Seattle, the aerospace concern, said Bavaria Fluggesellschaft, a German aircraft leasing company, had confirmed an order for two additional next-generation Boeing 737-700 twin jets worth an estimated $80 million. KOBE STEEL LTD., Tokyo, plans to merge two of its U.S. construction machinery subsidiaries, Kobelco America Inc. of Houston and Kobelco Construction Machinery (U.S.A.) Inc. of Calhoun, Ga., into a new company.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Talk about coincidence.

title: Wall-to-Wall, If Home Is a Yurt
description: ON the northwest corner of 14th Street and Eighth Avenue stands one of New York City's best examples of Greek Revival style, an 1896 building designed by R. H. Robertson that once housed the New York Bank for Savings. After a landmark-sensitive restoration by the Staten Island architectural firm of Scarano Englert & Norton, it reopened a few months ago as the "grand palais of rugs," Central Carpet.

title: Premdor Inc.(PI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hartmarx Corp.(HMX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: Mexico's Rebels Offer a Proposal for Peace Talks
description: In their first concrete proposal for new peace talks with the Government, peasant rebels in the southern state of Chiapas called today for a wide-ranging discussion to be held in Mexico City.

title: Discovery Zone Inc.(ZONE,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 5,773,000, or 12 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in method of accounting.c-Net income(Loss)Financial information for 1993 reflects restatements that were required as a result of acquisitions which were accounted for as pooling of interests combinations.

title: Union Takes One Step Toward The Fields
description: With a unanimous voice vote, the executive board of the players union yesterday took its step, the middle one, in the three-part process that could snatch major league baseball away from replacement players and restore it to major league players.

title: No Headline
description: "We've already got term limits. They're called elections." -- REP. BILL RICHARDSON. [ A1:6. ]

title: House Subcommittee Initiates a Bill to Establish a Board to Manage Washington's Finances
description: A House subcommittee today voted unanimously to establish a board that would essentially take over the financial management of the District of Columbia. The city, which is on the verge of bankruptcy, faces a deficit of about $400 million.

title: Interstate Bakeries Corp.(IBC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 4
description: b-Net loss, which included charge of $ 5,687,000, or 28 cents a share, related to LC Cake bakery disposition and environmental matters.(Loss)

title: Heavy Angst When It's 'Ivy or Else'
description: Within easy reach in the green canvas backpack that Karen Sumberg carries to high school is a pocket-size daily planner that helps her track all the assignments, volunteer activities, projects and club meetings that are crammed into every free hour.

title: Hermitage, in Its Manner, Displays Its Looted Art
description: With the opening of a much-anticipated exhibition of long concealed French paintings today at the State Hermitage Museum, Russia took a major leap in its coquettish dance with honesty about art looted from Nazi Germany at the end of the war.

title: Indian Point A-Plant's Safety Doubted on Eve of U.S. Visit
description: After more than two years of work on the equipment at Indian Point 3 and on the attitudes of the people who work there, the New York Power Authority says it believes it is almost ready to reopen its hard-luck nuclear reactor.

title: What Would Fay Wray Say?
description: The Empire State Building turned blue last night at sunset. New York City's most famous symbol is periodically lit up with different colors to mark holidays, large and obscure. It glows red for Valentine's Day and Fire Prevention Day. It is a bouquet of yellow and white for Easter. It gleams green, white and orange for India Independence Day, red and white for Pulaski Day, lavender for Gay Pride Weekend.

title: Dr. Joseph Post, 82, Cancer Researcher And Expert on Cells
description: Dr. Joseph Post, who developed the first successful nutrition-based treatment for liver disease, died on Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 82 and lived in Manhattan.

title: CLARK EQUIPMENT SHARES UP 53% ON TAKEOVER THREAT
description: Shares of the Clark Equipment Company rose 53 percent yesterday in the wake of the Ingersoll-Rand Company's threat to undertake a $1.34 billion hostile takeover of the construction-machinery maker. Ingersoll-Rand, based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., a maker of construction equipment, said it still hoped for a friendly union with Clark, whose board on Monday rejected as inadequate a cash offer of $75 to $77 a share. Under Securities and Exchange Commission rules, Ingersoll-Rand has until April 6 to nominate directors to be voted on at Clark's annual meeting on May 9. Shares of Clark, based in South Bend, Ind., rose yesterday $28.125, to $81.25, on volume of almost 2.7 million shares. Ingersoll-Rand stock closed unchanged at $32.125.

title: HOST MARRIOTT CONSIDERING SPINOFF OF CONCESSIONS UNIT
description: The Host Marriott Corporation said yesterday that it was considering a spinoff of its food concession division. Host Marriott, based in Bethesda, Md., the owner of hotels and food and merchandise concessions, expects the stock market may value the businesses more as separate entities, Stephen Bollenbach, president and chief executive, said on Tuesday. A spinoff would also make the businesses easier to understand for potential investors, he said. The concessions business operates food and merchandise concessions, including franchised Pizza Hut, Sbarro's and Taco Bell restaurants along toll roads, at airports and at tourist attractions.

title: International Briefs; Ratings Cut for 2 Firms
description: The Standard & Poor's Ratings Group said yesterday that it had downgraded slightly some credit ratings of the Nomura Securities Company and the Yamaichi Securities Company, two of Japan's largest investment firms. The new ratings, which will make it more expensive for the firms to borrow money, affect about $1.7 billion of Nomura's debt and $40 million of Yamaichi's debt. (Dow Jones)

title: Sprint and Cable-TV Partners Plan $4.4 Billion Investment
description: The Sprint Corporation and its cable-television partners said today that they would invest $4.4 billion in the biggest challenge yet to the Baby Bells and the GTE Corporation.

title: Nike Enlists Female Athlete For a New Line of Footwear
description: In a case of footwear gender equity, Nike Inc. said yesterday that it would introduce the Air Swoopes basketball shoe, named for Sheryl Swoopes, who led Texas Tech to the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball championship in 1993.

title: Aquarium to Be Enlivened
description: Send in the clownfish. With $4 million here and $5 million there, Camden is angling for visitors. The $4 million will pay for a makeover at the New Jersey State Aquarium, to add more colorful fish (visitors have complained that too many are brown), and birds, aquatic animals, interactive exhibits and laser lights. And $5 million will be applied to transforming the 91-year-old sailing ship Mosholu into a restaurant anchored just north of the aquarium.

title: Mr. D'Amato, Let Your People Go
description: Senator Alfonse D'Amato, in his kingmaker mode, has informed most Republican officeholders in New York that they like Senator Bob Dole for President. With the exception of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, they are following orders. The D'Amato plan has the virtue of efficiency. We have a bias for the process known as democracy. Therefore it is necessary to protest the Senator's plan to enforce his preference by, in effect, canceling the state's Republican Presidential primary.

title: Students Protest Education Cuts at Rallies Around U.S.
description: Students at universities around the country held rallies, marches, teach-ins and vigils today to protest both proposed Federal cuts in education and the Republicans' Contract With America, which they said was responsible.

title: Police in an Informer Program Are Investigated Themselves
description: A Police Department program in which officers work in regular assignments but secretly provide information on corruption is under investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Cintas Corp. (CTAS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a first-quarter charge of 2 cents a share for a tax adjustment.

title: Grey Loses Some Slim-Fast Work
description: The Slim-Fast Foods Company, the marketer of diet products in West Palm Beach Fla., dismissed Grey Advertising in New York yesterday on the domestic creative, strategic planning and research portions of its account, which Grey had handled since August 1987, and shifted those assignments to Young & Rubicam New York after a brief review. The billings were estimated at $30 million but are expected to increase to as much as $60 million to $70 million.

title: Kitchenware With a Switch
description: SERENDIPITY might well describe 32-year-old Richard Wrightman's life. After he decorated his Manhattan apartment two years ago, friends asked Mr. Wrightman -- who had been a clothing designer -- to do theirs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The troubles of STEPHEN FRY continue.

title: Yesterday in Washington
description: TERM LIMITS The House voted squarely against the will of the people by rejecting, one after another, four proposed constitutional amendments that would have limited the number of terms served by members of Congress. The result made term limits the first item in the Republicans' Contract With America to go down to defeat in the House.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters last Thursday about transplants of immature brain cells in mice to treat a genetic brain abnormality misstated the surname of an author of the study. He is Dr. Evan Snyder, not Smith.

title: After Dark, 4 Agents Light Out
description: In a late-night drama worthy of an action-adventure movie, four top agents at International Creative Management left their jobs shortly after midnight today to start their own agency. They took their files with them, prompting the threat of legal action on the part of their former employers.

title: International Family Entertainment Inc.(FAM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss, which included extraordinary charge of $ 52,087,000, or $ 1.29 a share, in the quarter and $ 1.32 a share, in the year, from loss on early extinguishment of debt.(Loss)

title: Cuts Must Go to Deficit, Senate Says
description: The Senate today unanimously approved an amendment that would require $13.5 billion in cuts from spending in the current fiscal year be applied to reducing the Federal budget, not reducing taxes. The move was intended to blunt the opposition of Democrats to the spending-cut plan.

title: Gasoline and Oil Prices Jump After Big Refinery Shuts a Unit
description: Gasoline and crude oil prices rose sharply yesterday after the largest refiner on the East Coast said a power failure had forced it to shut some critical gasoline-making equipment.

title: Where Gods and Athletes Part Company
description: To the Editor:

title: No Sentimental Journey For a Stubborn Wooden
description: He is the father of their country, but the U.C.L.A. Bruins have been unable to coerce John Wooden to attend this weekend's Final Four in Seattle.

title: INSIDE
description: Players Vote to Play, if. . .

title: Retrial in Stabbing of Seles
description: The prosecution demanded a prison sentence in the retrial yesterday of the man who idolized STEFFI GRAF so much that he stabbed MONICA SELES in the back during a tennis tournament. But the court in Hamburg, Germany, also heard testimony that GUNTHER PARCHE, 40, needed treatment rather than prison time, and that he is no longer a danger. Parche was given a suspended sentence after his first trial for the April 1993 stabbing. The leniency triggered an uproar, and the prosecution, backed by Seles and her lawyers, won a retrial. Today, the court will hear closing arguments by the defense and Seles's lawyers. A ruling is likely on April 3. (AP)

title:
N.I.T.;
Georgia in the Party Without an Invitation
description: Andy Landers isn't offended that no one in the country thinks his Georgia Lady Bulldogs have a chance to make the finals of the women's collegiate basketball tournament. Instead, the 42-year-old head coach said he liked his chances against Tennessee in Saturday's opening game in Minneapolis.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10 SECRET U.S. FUNDS FOR GUATEMALA The Bush Administration, in a show of anger over the murder of an American citizen, cut off military aid to Guatemala in 1990 but secretly allowed the C.I.A. to send millions of dollars to the military Government, U.S. officials said. A1

title: For Mets, the Next Best Thing to Dugout Chatter
description: After months of what one player called unencouraging conversations, members of the Mets' 40-man roster held a conference call today and discussed -- albeit tentatively -- the process by which they could soon return to work.

title: FX Narrows Review To 4 Finalists
description: FX, the cable television network operated by Fox Inc., said yesterday that it had narrowed the review on its consumer and trade account to four finalists from nine semifinalists. The account, with billings estimated at $5 million to $10 million, had been at the Venice, Calif., office of Livingston & Company until that agency and Fox ended their yearlong relationship in December.

title: Shabazz Case Illustrates the Havoc Caused by Paid Informers
description: To the Editor:

title: And Now for Some Serious Fun
description: STEPHEN CALLOWAY once hung a pasteboard caveat at the entrance to one of his exhibitions here at the Victoria and Albert Museum: "The organizers wish to point out some of the material in this exhibition is of a disturbing and challenging nature."

title: Another Ailing Rocket
description: Houston Rockets guard VERNON MAXWELL has iron-deficiency anemia even more serious than HAKEEM OLAJUWON's condition, the team's doctor, JIM MUNTZ, said yesterday. "We're 100 percent certain that both of those guys have iron-deficient anemia," Muntz said. "Max's blood count is even lower than Hakeem's. They can both practice and shoot around but they'll just fatigue quicker."

title: End of Urban Agency Draws Fears of Neglect
description: Seventeen floors above 125th Street in Harlem, Donald J. Cogsville was reluctantly preparing to move out of his corner office, with its expansive windows and sweeping views of Central Park and the Hudson River.

title: Corestates to Cut 2,800 Jobs And Shut 10% of Its Branches
description: The Corestates Financial Corporation said today that it planned to cut almost 20 percent of its work force, or 2,800 jobs, and close 10 percent of its branches in an effort to trim costs and increase profits.

title: Report on Bus Problems Cites Maintenance Errors
description: New York's buses are chronically unreliable because of an aging fleet that has not been replaced fast enough and because transit officials repeatedly glossed over serious design flaws and failed to enforce maintenance standards, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Stocks in Sharp Reversal After Early Rally
description: Wall Street shocked itself yesterday. The stock market rallied sharply in the morning, with the Dow Jones industrial average coming within two points of a record 4,200-point level. It then plunged sharply in the afternoon, giving up most of its gains, yet managed to close the day up 8.99 points at 4,160.80, still good for a record.

title: If You Spoof a Cartoon, You'd Better Be Funnier
description: People who live in quotation marks are not, perhaps, the easiest figures to satirize, a lesson amply demonstrated in Charlie Varon's "Rush Limbaugh in Night School."

title: For Folk Art's Sake
description: THERE'S nothing like a country auction to inspire bidding fever. At least that's what the Museum of American Folk Art is counting on when Sotheby's, 1334 York Avenue, at 72d Street, auctions folk art donated to benefit the museum, on April 11. (Previews begin April 8.)

title: International Briefs; BASF Sees Higher Profit
description: BASF A.G., the German chemicals company, said yesterday that its earnings would be considerably higher in 1995 than in 1994, buoyed by the German economic recovery and despite the recent surge in the mark. The company's managing board chairman, Jurgen Strube, said at a news conference, "We look for a considerable rise in sales and earnings compared with 1994." For the first two months of 1995, BASF reported that revenue climbed 16 percent, to more than 7.7 billion marks ($5.59 billion). But Mr. Strube declined to put a figure on expected 1995 results, saying predictions would be premature. (Reuters)

title: COCA-COLA TO ACQUIRE BARQ'S, A ROOT BEER MAKER
description: In a move to enter the fast-growing root beer market, The Coca-Cola Company signed a preliminary agreement yesterday to acquire Barq's Inc., the nation's eighth-largest beverage company. Coca-Cola, based in Atlanta, is the world's largest soft-drink maker. It did not disclose terms of the acquisition, which would be the company's first purchase of a United States beverage maker since it acquired Minute Maid 35 years ago.

title: F.C.C. WILL ORDER PHONE COMPANIES TO CUT ACCESS FEE
description: The Federal Communications Commission will order the nation's local telephone companies on Thursday to reduce the access charges they impose on long-distance carriers by about $1 billion a year for the next few years, agency officials said today.

title: What Else Did The C.I.A. Know?
description: The disclosure that the C.I.A employed a Guatemalan Army colonel involved in the torture and murder of Michael DeVine, an American who ran an inn in the jungle, and an insurgent married to Jennifer Harbury, an American lawyer, comes as no surprise to my family.

title: At Wharton's House, a Drama-Architecture Collision
description: IN a familial clash of values worthy of an Edith Wharton novel, a battle is unfolding over the Mount, a 35-room house that Wharton commissioned in 1902 as her "first real home."

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the conviction of two Newark politicians on Federal corruption charges referred incompletely in some editions to a prosecutor in the case. He is Larry R. C. Stephen, chief of the corruption division in the United States Attorney's office in Newark.

title: Dolphins Trade Jackson
description: KEITH JACKSON, one of the National Football League's top tight ends, was traded yesterday by the Miami Dolphins to the Green Bay Packers for a second-round choice in April's draft. But the five-time Pro Bowl player wants a new long-term contract before joining the Packers. As part of the trade, the Dolphins returned to Green Bay a fourth-round draft pick acquired in the March 21 deal that sent Miami's MARK INGRAM to the Packers. (AP)

title: Ex-Boyfriend Charged in Fire
description: The former live-in boyfriend of a Camden woman has been charged with setting a fire that killed two of her children and seriously injured two others. The ex-boyfriend, Miguel Lazada, acted in anger after he was kicked out by Elizabeth Ponce, the authorities said. Prosecutors said that Ms. Ponce was at a crack house when the fire started, and they would not rule out the possibility that she may face charges.

title: Showalter Getting Itchy To Pencil In Regulars
description: Buck Showalter erased the names of the replacement players from the depth chart hanging in his tiny office and in their place etched in the names of the real Yankees from the 40-man roster. Showalter wants to believe that Don Mattingly and friends will be here soon. He wants to be ready, so he erased and he etched.

title: Where To Buy A Monkey
description: AN amusing moment of the Academy Awards ceremonies Monday night came when David Letterman tried to convince the world that many celebrities competed with him for his cameo role as Earl Hofert, an old salt, in last year's flop movie "The Cabin Boy."

title: Brooklyn Philharmonic Names New Director
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic has appointed Robert Spano as its music director, succeeding Dennis Russell Davies, who will leave the orchestra at the end of next season. Mr. Davies, who has been principal conductor since 1991, oversaw a thorough revamping of the orchestra's programming, replacing conventional concerts with thematic weekends that include recitals, films and lectures as well as orchestral programs.

title: Shopko Stores Inc.(SKO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: Shopko Stores said that its latest fourth quarter gross margin included a LIFO credit of $ 5.6 million and a $ 5.5 million charge for inventory markdowns. The company also said that its gross margin for the latest year included a LIFO credit of $ 2 million and a $ 5.5 million charge for inventory markdowns. Gross margin in the prior year included a LIFO charge of $ 3.7 million.

title: Royal Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $ 50 million related to the sale of Argentine past-due interest bonds.The bank is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges with the ticker symbol RY.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: International Briefs; In Brief
description: Soekor, South Africa's state-owned oil and gas exploration company, said yesterday that the country's first oilfield development was expected to come on stream early next year. The field is off Still Bay, east of Cape Town.

title: U.S. Proposes Opening Power Cost and Supply To Competition
description: The Federal agency that oversees the nation's utilities approved a sweeping proposal today to force utilities to open their transmission systems to competitors.

title: Calendar: Exhibitions, Antiques Shows, a Talk
description: Flowers to Facades Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street; (212) 879-5500.

title: Sexual Harassmen And a Chief Executive
description: When J. P. Bolduc resigned unexpectedly on March 2 as chief executive of W. R. Grace & Company, his departure was described by the giant industrial corporation as a result of "differences of style and philosophy." Later, it was cast by Mr. Bolduc's supporters as corporate retribution for his insistence on airing the Grace family's generous perquisites and consulting deals.

title: Brown Is Told Sports Program Cheats Women
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Brown University had discriminated against female athletes by eliminating women's gymnastics and volleyball teams in 1991, a decision that could have broad implication for colleges that inadequately fund women's athletic teams.

title: House Panel Backs Easing Of U.S. Water Standards
description: A House subcommittee today approved sweeping revisions to the Clean Water Act that would give much greater weight to costs when deciding whether to seek further improvements in the quality of the nation's water.

title: If a Cow Had Mirrors
description: NEOTU, the French art-furniture gallery, is now ensconced in a town house at 409 West 44th Street, and its French owners, Gerard Dalmon and Pierre Staudenmeyer, see clients by appointment. Among their offerings: this cabinet of wenge wood with mirror and leather insets by the Paris-based designers Mattia Bonetti and Elizabeth Garouste ($8,700). Telephone: (212) 262-9250.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Boston University

title: The Stage Is Her World; Avid Theatergoer Attends More Than 200 Shows a Year
description: At intermission Friday night at Synchronicity Space, an Off Off Broadway house in SoHo, Ruth Rauch decided the show was pretty good so far. One or two of the performances were to her liking, and she knew one of the actors, always a special pleasure.

title: Journal; The Glamour Gap
description: Don't feel sorry for the sequestered O. J. Simpson jurors -- envy them. Thanks to an edict by Judge Lance Ito, they were not allowed to waste Monday night watching the Oscars.

title: Smith Is Leaving Tulsa To Coach at Georgia
description: TUBBY SMITH, who coached Tulsa to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Sweet 16 the last two seasons, got the basketball coaching job at Georgia yesterday and became the school's first black head coach. Smith, 43, succeeds HUGH DURHAM, who was dismissed on March 19 after 17 seasons.

title: Philharmonic Radio Forum
description: The public is to have a chance to ask questions about plans and workings of the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday, when the orchestra's music director, Kurt Masur, and executive director, Deborah Borda, are to take questions from listeners on the Philharmonic Radio Forum, 4:30 to 5:30 P.M. on WQXR-FM (96.3). Tom Bartunek, the station's vice president for programming and operations, is to be the host. Information: (212) 875-5709.

title: Just Try to Slow These People Down
description: A stroke of nonverbal inspiration gave Bill Einreinhofer, a veteran producer of public television documentaries, the title for his latest project.

title: G.O.P. Mobilizes for Contract Deadline
description: As the first 100 days of their revolution draw to a close, House Republicans are busily planning how to package their accomplishments for the voters. As a result, coming soon to a media outlet near you: One Hundred Days. A story of promises made and promises kept. Of hard work and real change. Of a Contract With America, and the men and women who delivered on it.

title: Single-Family Home Sales Lowest in Nearly 3 Years
description: Sales of new single-family homes fell a larger-than-expected 14.0 percent in February to the lowest level in almost three years, even as mortgage rates dipped below 9 percent for the first time in four months.

title: On Deck, Judge Sonia Sotomayor
description: After bouncing from the bargaining table to the White House to Congress without resolution, the baseball stalemate is headed toward Federal court just days before the season is scheduled to start. Whether Judge Sonia Sotomayor of New York can get the big-leaguers back on the field is unclear, but she should take a shot.

title: Bally Gaming Restrained in Use of Name
description: A Federal judge in Camden, N.J., issued a temporary restraining order yesterday that barred Bally Gaming International Inc., a gambling machine producer, from selling or distributing any equipment bearing the Bally name for up to 15 days.

title: Dmitri Kessel, 92, A Photographer
description: Dmitri Kessel, a photographer whose camera captured graphic scenes of warfare as well as the wonders of nature and great art, died on Sunday in Southampton Hospital on Long Island. He was 92 and had lived in Paris for 30 years before moving to Wainscott, L.I.

title: Suzy Shier Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: House Proud
description: ONE side of the two-family house has a new kitchen with a neon banana hanging over a grand piano. The other side also has a new kitchen -- with a sedate collection of Staffordshire plates over an oak table.

title: Times Settles a Suit Over Pressroom Hiring
description: A Federal judge approved a settlement yesterday requiring The New York Times Company to increase its hiring of women and minority workers in its pressroom to resolve a lawsuit brought by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission against the company and the pressmen's union.

title: Marshall Safir, 75, Shipping Executive
description: Marshall P. Safir, a businessman and former shipping executive who long opposed government subsidies to the industry, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 75 and lived in Floral Park, L.I.

title: Of G.O.P. Promises Made
description: Republicans in the House have begun an elaborate strategy to allay their abiding fear: that a disengaged public has yet to get the message of what was accomplished in the first 100 days of the new Congress. They want to get the full historic credit that they believe they are due for pushing hard to make the Contract With America a reality. Page A21.

title: Chaos for Some, a Diversion for Others
description: As smoke and soot brought an early dusk to the canyons of lower Manhattan yesterday, thousands of office workers and tourists who sensed more diversion than disaster flocked to South Street to gawk as part of the Fulton Fish Market went up in flames.

title: Haitian Officials May Have Plotted to Kill Opponent
description: The United States alerted the Haitian Government last week that a prominent opposition figure who was shot to death on the streets of Port-au-Prince on Tuesday was the target of a plot, Administration officials said today.

title: New World Communications Group Inc.(NWCG,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 2,010,000, or 4 cents a share, on early extinguishment of debt, in the quarter and year.(Loss)The latest year's results do not reflect the full year of stations acquired at the end of 1994 and financial results for station acquisitions that will close in 1995.The 1993 year was not comparable because the company's predecessor, the former SCI Television, emerged from bankruptcy in May 1993, at which time the company acquired New World Entertainment, later forming New World Communications Group in March 1994.New World Communications Group said 1994 results included numerous financing activities, other acquisitions and internal investments that were part of its on-going plan of building a vertically integrated television entertainment company.Management believes the per share amounts are not meaningful prior to the plan effective date due to the May 25, 1993 reorganization.Revenue is net revenue.

title: Classes for Young Gardeners
description: Knowledge about plants and ecology can be at your children's fingertips this spring. Gardening programs designed for children ages 3 to 17 are starting this week at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx and next week at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: New I.B.M. Chip for Digital Video Images
